PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

Mr Sinclair-Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Quite obviously the noise that is presently coming from King's Hall will affect the proceedings of the Parliament. I wonder whether some action might be taken so that Parliament can meet in a proper way and without interruption.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of order raised by the Leader of the House is, of course, not a surprise to me because I heard the noise as I came into the chamber. I have been aware of the noise all morning and I have considered very seriously what action should be taken. I have come to the conclusion that to take any action which would result in any forcible removal would probably be exactly what the protestors would wish. I am not prepared to allow the protest to prevent the Parliament from continuing to sit. Therefore, I think it would be best for us all if we proceeded with the business of the House forthwith.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CAMPBELL; HUMPHREYS; HURFORD; JOHNSON; JONES; MCMAHON; MORRIS
PETITION.NAMEIDS: CF4; FH4; AV4; 6G7; KH4; DL7; HI4
PETITION.TITLE: Trans-Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Trans-Australia Airlines
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell,Mr Humphreys,Mr Hurford,Mr Les Johnson,Mr Barry Jones,Mr Les McMahon and Mr Morris.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The hotel industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The hotel industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The hotel industry is almost entirely within the private sector and makes a large contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The hotel industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry's 5811 hotels in Australia.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian hotel industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increase to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The hotel industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives:
1. Recognise the importance and place of the Australian Hotel industry in the social and economic life of the nation.

2. Accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bourchier and Mr Les McMahon.

PETITION.TITLE: Bendigo College of Advanced Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully petition:

That the government will act to reverse the decision to cease funding professional engineering education at Bendigo College of Advanced Education, since the removal of engineering studies from this College would seriously restrict educational opportunity for citizens in a large region of Victoria.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully calls for:
The immediate and unconditional withdrawal of any proposals to deny unemployment benefits to unemployed people under 18 years old.
That the level of benefits for all unemployed people, and including people receiving sickness benefits and pensions, be raised to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line.

That future employment policies be devoted to job creation and the restoration of full employment rather than the evasion of this responsibility by hiding the unemployed in short term training and education schemes.
Public acknowledgement of the fact that unemployment is the result of insufficient jobs and not the fault of any minority group, the education system or the unemployed themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
A substantial contribution to Australia's economy by the payment of taxation and to the quality of life of fellow Australians, is made by parents in the work-force who have pre-school children.
Taxation relief for adequate child-care is necessary to enable these parents to avail themselves of child-care facilities in order to take paid employment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that tax-payers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other tax-payers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under ''Cosmetics'' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That there is an urgent need to ensure that the living standard of pensioners will not decline, as indeed, the present level of cash benefits in real terms requires upward adjustment beyond indexation related to the movement of the Consumer Price Index, by this and other means your petitioners urge that action be taken to:
1. Adjust all pensions and benefits quarterly to the Consumer Price Index, including the 'fixed' 70's rate.
2. Raise all pensions and benefits to at least 30 per cent of the Average Weekly Earnings.
3. Taxation relief for pensioners and others of low incomes by:
(a) The present static threshold of $75 per week for taxation purposes be increased to $100 per week.
(b) A substantial reduction in indirect taxation on consumer goods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens showeth:
That the last increase in the Supplementary Assistance or rent allowance payable to Invalid and Age pensioners was made in 1974;
That since that time, average weekly rents, as gauged by increases in average Queensland Housing Commission rents, have risen by approximately 150 per cent and continue to rise at an alarming rate.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will at the earliest opportunity index Supplementary Assistance to increases in the cost of living by the same biannual process applied to increases in the pension itself.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rosemount Repatriation Hospital
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned Australian citizens showeth:

Rosemount Repatriation Hospital has been of inestimable value to eligible repatriation beneficiaries for many years, and the closure or dispersal of the facilities available at the hospital would be a retrograde step.

The proposed decision to close Rosemount Repatriation Hospital through active discouragement by departmental administrative officers of any further referrals by medical officers of patients for medically prescribed occupational therapy is objectionable.

Closure of Rosemount Repatriation Hospital would severely disadvantage veterans in Brisbane's northern suburbs, as well as their relatives and friends who would be required to travel a great distance in order to visit hospitalised veterans at either of the two alternative repatriation hospitals.
Closure of Rosemount Repatriation Hospital and transfer of patients to Greenslopes would greatly add to the administrative burden of that repatriation and general hospital.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will reverse its announced decision to close the Rosemount Repatriation Hospital.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public investment in tertiary education in the form of Federal Government funding is an investment in Australia's future and enables Australia to meet the demands of technological innovation.
That grave concern has been generated as a result of the Government's decisions to:
(a) abolish the education research and development committee,
(b) terminate special support for educational research,
(c) scale down in-house and contracted research activities of the Department of Education,
(d) scale down participation in international education activities, particularly UNESCO and OECD,
(e) further tighten already restrictive eligibility guidelines for TEAS,
(f) supplement TEAS assistance by means of a loan scheme,
(g) phase in tuition fees for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification,
(h) reduce grants to universities and colleges to take account of fee income,
(i) completely abolish 30 colleges of advanced education and
(j) scale down various engineering schools in colleges of advanced education around Australia;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive decisions and desist from obvious attempts to pave the way for a complete re-introduction of tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy and Personal Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Paragraphs 107 and 108 of the Privacy and Personal Information discussion paper number 14, brought down by the Law Reform Commission in June 1980, undermines the family unit and the authority of parents, which is the Christian basis of our society, by proposing that ''between 12 and 16 years, a child should be entitled to object to disclosure of information to a parent.''
It is your petitioners sincere belief that:

(a) an adolescent between the ages of 12 and 16 is not at a mature enough stage of life to decide whether or not the disclosure of information to a parent will be in the best interests of the adolescent.
(b) as a record keeper has no responsibility for the child, and as his moral standards may be different to those of a parent, he should not be permitted to come between child and parent.

(c) a parent has a unique position which may enable him/her to perceive a situation that the record keeper does not. The parent must therefore be aware of the problem if remedial action is to be taken, and has the right to guide the child in the direction he/she feels fit.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Members of the House of Representatives will reject the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission and find some other means to protect children from the excessive abuse of some parents.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legisate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Hospital Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That the Federal Government's shifting of responsibility for funding of public hospitals onto the State Governments has placed a disproportionate and onerous burden onto lower income groups, but particularly on large families; single income families; the chronically ill; those with recurrent illnesses and those on fixed incomes.
2. That included in the undesirable effects on the public hospital system in Queensland will be:
(i) long waiting times for non-urgent surgery
(ii) long waiting periods in out-patients
(iii) services, e.g. X-ray and Pathology will be reduced
(iv) staff will be reduced
(v) possible abolition of teaching hospitals and centralisation of training facilities for doctors and nurses
(vi) closing down of small country hospitals

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to re-examine its public hospital funding arrangements, the impact of these arrangements on lower income groups mentioned in (1.) above and increase funding to the States to ensure that the undesirable effects mentioned in (2.) above do not occur.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That merchant seamen have in the past served in theatres of war; they have been decorated for valor following war action; they have been prisoners of war and should therefore be entitled to similar pension rights and medical benefits as regular servicemen.
(2) That by being denied the entitlements, such as pensions and medical benefits, which other war veterans receive, they are thereby being discriminated against.
Your petitioners therefor humbly pray that the Federal Government amend the Repatriation Act (1920) Section 100 (d) (iv) to take account of war-related service by merchant seamen during World War 2.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed mining leases against the advice of conservationists and a State Government sponsored Public Inquiry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose any expansion of the facilities of Kingsford-Smith Airport which entails the building of a new runway as it would have the following detrimental effects.
(1) The loss of one mile of waterfront including Lady Robinson's Beach and a huge part of Botany Bay.
(2) The loss of up to 1,230 houses and a drop in value of remaining neighbouring properties.
(3) The creation of more noise pollution in the area.
(4) The creation of more traffic congestion on streets leading to and from the airport.
(5) The forced diversion of Cook's River and further damage to the ecology of the area.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will not consider satisfying the airport needs of Sydney by extending Kingsford-Smith Airport and that any decisions related thereto are not taken before there is an opportunity for adequate consultation with any community particularly affected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Georges River: Pollution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That the pollution problems caused by the proliferation of the Brazilian weed Salvinia molesta in the Georges River, New South Wales:
(a) poses a serious health risk to the community;
(b) has caused severe damage to the environment;
(c) poses a potential additional threat to the famous Georges River oyster industry already affected by oil spills in Botany Bay.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Commonwealth will provide immediate financial assistance to the State and local government authorities combatting the problem and ensure that all Commonwealth instrumentalities along the Georges River are not contributing to the pollution problem.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Botany Bay
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of certain citizens respectfully shows that:
(a) The continued despoilation of the natural environment of the Botany Bay region will result in the loss of a unique part of the National Estate.
(b) The oil spills from ships and from installations adjoining Botany Bay have threatened the viability of the valuable export orientated oyster industry in the region.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government supply the funds required to acquire additional land for parks in the region to augment the natural environment, and take action to minimise the incidence of oil spills in Botany Bay.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.
(ii) The imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling in such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich.

(iii) The introduction of a loans scheme, subsequent review of the level of TEAS and the tightening of the eligibility criteria for TEAS will cause great financial hardship and will deter students from enrolling in tertiary institutions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. Post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
2. The visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
3. The Government reverse its decision to introduce a loans scheme and instead increase and extend TEAS scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Georges River: Pollution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are gravely concerned by the state of the Georges River, the failure of authorities to ensure that the river flows pure and unimpeded, the hazard to health posed by the river and the fact that the river has become a drain rather than remaining a natural stream.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament appropriate funds to the New South Wales Government and relevant authorities so that effluent from the Glenfield Sewerage Treatment Works can be piped to Malabar and that measures can be put in train which will remove weed growth and allow the river to be cleaned up and made the beautiful waterway it once was.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should:
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Romanian Government is committing genocide against the three million strong native born Hungarian population in Romania, as defined in Articles II and III of the United Nations Convention on the Crime of Genocide, which facts are well documented in the reports of the Amnesty International, the Minority Rights Group, the International League of Jurists, et cetera.

That the Article IV of the Convention states that: 'Persons committing genocide or any other acts enumerated in Article III shall be punished, whether they are constitutionally responsible rulers, public officials or private individuals.'

That the Article VIII of the Convention states: 'Any contracting party may call upon the competent organs of the United Nations to take such actions under the Charter of the United Nations as they consider appropriate for the prevention and suppression of acts of genocide or any of the other acts enumerated in Article III.'

As Australia is a Contracting Party to the Convention on Crime of Genocide, and that the Joint Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defence has already established precedents by having investigated Human Rights violations in other countries,
Your petitioners therefore pray:

(1) That the Joint Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defence to take up an investigation into the alleged genocide activities of the Romanian Government against its three million native born Hungarians in Romania; and

(2) That if such investigation should establish that Romania has been engaged in acts of genocide against its Hungarian minorities to call upon the competent organs of the United Nations to take such action under the Charter of the United Nations as they consider appropriate for the prevention and suppression of acts of genocide or any other acts enumerated in the United Nations Convention on Crime of Genocide.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of childrens services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 budget. And further, that annual budget allocations in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Owing to an overwhelming and continuous demand by the Australian people for a cruise service within the economic scope of the working man and his family, we request the Government to lift the ban placed on Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels entering Australian Ports.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are gravely disturbed by the actions of militant unions and the ACTU, the failure of the President of the ACTU to assist positively in settling the dispute which has caused massive losses to Qantas our National Airline, and we applaud the action of the Government in using RAAF planes to rescue Australians stranded abroad.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament and the Government should be of firm resolve not to permit such unions to hold the country to ransom and continue to take a forceful and resolute stand against such union militancy.

PETITION.TITLE: Vitamins and Minerals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That this is a petition of protest to the proposed legislation to change the standards of vitamin and mineral remedies, which if implemented will make such remedies therapeutically insignificant. Remedies with therapeutic significance are proposed to be prescribed by medical practitioners only.
We as tax payers respectfully demand the right to eat and purchase the vitamins and minerals we choose without Government or medical intervention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
1. That we are gravely concerned at the lack of Children's services within the City of Northcote.
2. That we are dismayed at the refusal of the Department of Social Security (Child Care Division) to fund a Family Day Care Program within the City of Northcote.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will ensure adequate funds for Children's Services will be made available so that Family Day Care may be provided within the City of Northcote.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Fares
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:
1. That we oppose the massive increase of 30.7 per cent in air fares from Canberra to other capital cities compared with the average increase of 7.4 per cent.
2. That this will cause serious hardship for many Canberra families who will not be able to afford to see their relatives from other parts of Australia.
3. That the ordinary families of Canberra should not be singled out for such massive increases and should receive equal treatment with the rest of Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government take immediate action to adjust air fares to and from Canberra in line with the average increase of 7.4 per cent or to compensate the citizens of Canberra for this massive increase in air fares.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vehicle Testing Service: Phillip, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned electors of the Division of Canberra respectfully showeth that:
(1) Members of the public are seriously concerned at the drop of the high standard of vehicle testing, when this service is handed over to private enterprise.
It is well known that State testing of vehicles, where it occurs, is considerably inferior to that which takes place in the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) Considerable capital has been expended to further improve the service at Phillip. This taxpayers money should not be wasted.
(3) If vehicles are to be tested by private enterprise, the public will have to pay a fee.

If given the option, they would rather pay this fee to a government agency in the knowledge that the findings of the test would be completely un-biased, whereas through private enterprise, this may not always be the case.
(4) Southside population of Canberra are entitled to the service provided by the Phillip office. It would be difficult to give this service at Dickson due to the limitations of the building.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rodeos: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:

That we are opposed to rodeos as we believe them to be cruel and to cause animals to suffer needlessly. We can see no useful purpose to humanity by rodeos nor do we feel that animals should be exploited in this manner.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all rodeos be banned within the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Staging of American B-52 Bombers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and Rest and Recreation base for American B-52 bombers:

Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it established a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the USA and another power.
Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B-52's:
(a) Carried nuclear weapons
(b) were engaged in bombing missions against another State.
Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconceivably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy.

Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region.
Jeopardises the welfare of the Citizens of Darwin, in that noise pollution and the threat of accidental radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents.
Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of Peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraw the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B-52 bombers. And that furthermore will ensure that any request of such usage by the US Government be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Two-airline Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members iof the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the present two airline domestic policy of the Commonwealth Government.
That this policy has resulted in expensive airfares and poor service and discourages tourists from the Eastern States visiting WA and vice versa.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition and formulate an airline policy providing for greater competition so that prices and service are determined by free market forces.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) left Australia on 21 May to attend the fortieth anniversary celebrations of the battles of continental Greece and Crete. He will also be visiting Britain for talks with British defence authorities as well as visiting Malaysia and Singapore for discussions with government and defence leaders. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) is acting as Minister for Defence until Mr Killen returns on 6 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. That this House reaffirms its support and notes the support of the Australian people for the basic objectives of the Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea and urges the United States Administration to complete without delay the review of its policies in order that the conference can finalise its work when the Tenth Session resumes in Geneva in August 1981.

2. That this House conveys to the United States Administration its view that Australia has vital economic and strategic interests which can only be protected by the expeditious conclusion of these negotiations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. That this House expresses its concern that the Commonwealth Government has for the first time in Australia's history interfered with the autonomy and independence of Australian universities.

2. That the action of the Government in directing Deakin University on academic content and scope of courses offered by the University constitutes an unacceptable interference with the autonomy of Australian universities which has no parallel in democratic nations and that only under totalitarian regimes have universities been similarly directed by governments.
3. That the House calls on the Government to withdraw this directive and thus remove the threat to academic freedom and Australian educational standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House requires the Government to include in its financial arrangements with Western Australia a provision to ensure that Western Australia receives no less in real terms than it did in 1980-81.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House insists that the Government maintain the existing hospital arrangements with Western Australia insofar as these arrangements guarantee open and free access for all Western Australians to the public hospitals of the State.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Prime Minister and refer him to the announcement that the right honourable gentleman proposes to send 12 Ministers and honourable members to some 40 countries to deliver invitations to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. In the light of the Lynch committee report recommending cut backs in expenditure on essential services provided to taxpayers, I ask: Why does the right honourable gentleman find it necessary to send these honourable members, their wives and members of their families overseas at such enormous cost when the matter could be dealt with by sending the same messages to diplomats stationed in Canberra?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Secretary-General of the Commonwealth had some discussions with me last week and I understand that he also had discussions with the Leader of the Opposition which I hope were as constructive as the ones he had with me. Since 1973 at least it has been the practice of the host country for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting to send an emissary to certain countries. It is not a question of delivering an invitation. It is a question of discussing the up-coming agenda, the important matters for discussion and matters that might be sensitive within the general practice of consensus which is so important to the Commonwealth. Therefore, it has become a practice to do this very thing so there can be the widest possible input into the agenda and into the framework of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: I should add also that this meeting is the second largest heads of government meeting held in any organised and regular way in any forum. The meeting of non-aligned heads of government is, I think, a larger meeting with a larger number of heads of government attending. But in many ways the Commonwealth meeting has some capacities that I think go beyond those of similar meetings. People from different groups, continents and races-from North and South-attend the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting and give it the capacity that people from one particular world grouping, meeting alone, may well not have. Therefore, it gives the Commonwealth a value which I believe is a very real one. It is the responsibility of the host government-a responsibility which would come to it maybe once every 50 or 60 years-to make sure that the Commonwealth meeting is held in the best possible climate, with the agenda properly worked through and with the widest possible input from as many of the Commonwealth members as possible. That is why senior members of this Parliament-Ministers and private members-are undertaking a mission which I and the Government regard as an important one, and an important part of the process. It ought to be remembered that I will be in London at the end of July and I will then be having further discussions with the Secretary-General. The agenda for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting will not be finalised at that point but it will start to take very real shape. The draft agenda probably will be sent out early in September. All of this is part of the preparation for a meeting which is relevant and important.

If anyone had doubted the relevance of the Commonwealth to the problems of the world in the 1980s and beyond, quite plainly the Lusaka meeting should have put those doubts very much to rest. It does the Commonwealth no service whatsoever for people to suggest that Australia is taking too much trouble with this particular meeting or is seeking to pay too much attention to it. It is an important meeting which can contribute seriously to current problems and especially to North-South economic problems. The more input there is to it by the 40-odd members of the Commonwealth in the preparatory stages, the better it will be. In relation to the Review of Commonwealth Functions, it ought to be noted that that review did not cut expenditure across the board. In a very large measure it is a rationalisation of Commonwealth functions and that rationalisation will enable the Government to do better the things that governments ought to do well. Holding this Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting is something that this Commonwealth Government will do well and it makes no apologies for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Transport seen reports of a statement by the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, Mr Hinze, claiming that the Commonwealth will make road construction a private enterprise function and that local councils will be prevented from tendering for road works? Is this the situation and, if not, what is the real situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the statements made by the Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police in Queensland, Mr Hinze. I have also seen a copy of a letter that has been sent to a number of parliamentary members. I must say that I am at a loss to know what Mr Hinze is belly-aching about. The first truth of the matter is that, in accordance with the provisions of the legislation that is before the House, the Queensland road making authorities and also local government authorities will have the right to bid for any national road construction work that is put out to tender and contract by the State authorities. The other truth is that 90 per cent of road construction work in Queensland happens to be in the local government main roads area and 10 per cent of road construction work is in the national roads area. So, it is quite wrong for him to suggest that the implementation of the Government's policy will create chaos, unemployment and so on in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The real test of Mr Hinze's contention in this matter is whether Mr Hinze would bother to have a home built or any work done in his own area of business by day labour. I am certain that he would call for tenders from contractors to build his own home. I believe that he, as a roads Minister, has a responsibility to ensure that the public funds that are being expended on roads are expended to the best possible advantage of the public. He is dealing with taxpayers' funds-public funds. It is necessary to ensure that we get the greatest length of road possible from the funds which have been made available to carry out those works.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Primary Industry. When presenting the ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Prime Minister stated that the interest subsidy of the Australian Wheat Board 'is to be reduced by one percentage point'. The Minister for Primary Industry has since claimed that the statement referred only to a one per cent increase in the rate charged by the Reserve Bank of Australia's Rural Credits Department. Did the Government instruct the bank to increase the rate? If so, when will the Government table the instructions, as required by section 11 of the Reserve Bank Act? If not-that is, if it was an autonomous Reserve Bank decision-why was it misrepresented as a razor gang decision? Why did the Prime Minister refer only to the Australian Wheat Board when several other statutory bodies, including the Australian Dairy Corporation, will be affected by the Rural Credits Department's interest rates? Finally, why did the Prime Minister use the future tense-he said 'is to be'-when the Rural Credits Department rate was raised by one per cent a month before he spoke and by 0.5 per cent a fortnight after he spoke?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a long-standing practice, because of the significant policy implications, particularly to Australian primary industry, of variations in the interest rate charged on Rural Credits Department advances, for there to be very close consultation between the Government, normally through the Treasurer of the day, and the Reserve Bank of Australia regarding the level of interest although, as the honourable member has correctly implied, the final decision on the level of Rural Credits Department advances is a matter for the Reserve Bank to determine. There has been no section 11 notice, letter or whatever one likes to call it written; nor indeed is that in contemplation. I have written a letter to the Governor of the Reserve Bank informing him formally of the decision that was the subject of the Prime Minister's announcement.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the past few months there have been changes in the rate of interest charged on Rural Credits Department advances. There was one in March and there was one, I think, on 15 May. Also there have been some fluctuations in the market rate of interest charged on borrowings by the Australian Wheat Board to the extent that it is borrowing on the commercial market. The intent of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee's decision and the intent of the Prime Minister's announcement was to indicate a view on the part of the Government that the differential ought to be less by reason of a further rise. The question of any additional increase which would at some time be needed to give full effect to the intent of the Government's decision-a further increase of one per cent-is something that the Reserve Bank itself must determine, taking into account a variety of factors, some of which have been canvassed in the honourable gentleman's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction whether his attention has been drawn to recent claims that this year the States will pay the Commonwealth more money in interest and redemption payments arising from the previous welfare housing advances than they will receive from the Commonwealth to finance current welfare housing programs. If so, can the Minister advise the House whether these claims are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the statement. I am grateful to the honourable member for Bendigo for drawing to the attention of the House the scurrilous statements made by people who obviously flirt with the truth. Let me state the facts. Each year since 1945, the Commonwealth Government has made available to the States certain sums of money to assist them with welfare housing. The total sum of money made available over the 35 years of the agreement has been in excess of $5,000m. The Commonwealth Government, particularly in recent years, has been very generous with its advances on highly concessional interest rate terms and also by giving a significant part of its contribution through grants. The net result has been that in each year-if we take 1980-81 as an example-the States have been able to repay to the Commonwealth the interest and redemption on the year's loan in addition to meeting all their own administrative expenses and the cost of upkeep and maintenance on the dwellings. Yet they still have-I stress this fact-a credit of $142m. That is a significant sum of money that has been made available by the Commonwealth Government through its generous advances and its grants system.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the agreement the States are required each year to pay back to the Commonwealth one fifty-third of the annual advances. When we look at that we note that each year the agreement is in existence obviously there is a requirement to pay back more funds. But there is no basis in logic or in justice to compare the repayments of interest and redemption by a State for a total lending period of 35 years with the annual contribution of the Commonwealth Government. If those honourable members who sit opposite advance that claim quite obviously what they are suggesting in fact and in essence is that if one gets a loan from someone with a firm commitment to repay it, one does not have to repay it. I repeat that through the generosity of the Commonwealth Government much has been done to assist in the area of welfare housing. It is blatant idiocy or untruthfulness in the extreme even to infer that this year the States will be repaying more than they are receiving from the Commonwealth.

Finally, the Government has given a firm commitment of $1,000m to the States, coupled with the surpluses that they receive each year-I instance this year the sum of $142m. I hope that in some States-I name New South Wales-that would act as a catalyst for them to do something about overcoming the problems of welfare housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Communications to proposed amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act announced by him on 9 April and ask whether he will inform the House of any communication the Government had with sections of the industry between that date and the meeting of the Government's back bench committee last Thursday. Did such communication include any drafting instructions, detailed explanations, or draft copies of the Bill being made available to the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, Major Television of Australia, Regional Television of Australia, or any individual media interests?

—There still is no final draft of the Bill but, yes, there have been very detailed discussions with every section of the industry. The Bill and the way in which the legislative intent should best be translated for parliamentary approval have been discussed very widely and will continue to be so discussed. The Government is most anxious that in the way in which the Bill is ultimately introduced into the Parliament there should be to the maximum both an ability to meet the intentions of the Government and an assurance that what is intended meets with the general approval, as far as possible, of those who are affected within the community including, of course, all the stations which are represented through the bodies mentioned in the honourable gentleman's question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport. I refer to the Government's announced policy to offer all national highway construction to tender. Will the State departments of main roads be free to tender in competition with private contractors? Will preference be given to tenderers from the State in which the road works are to be constructed? If the departments of main roads are to compete with private contractors for road works, will the departments be free to compete for construction tenders for works other than road works?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The departments of main roads, or the appropriate authority in each State, and local government will have the right to bid for works under the contract system for the construction of national roads. That provision will apply, of course, in Tasmania and in each of the States. There will not be any State preference; it will be an open tender arrangement. We anticipate, of course, that those local contractors in Tasmania or in any other State would have an advantage over those contractors who were tendering from a distant point.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the last part of the honourable gentleman's question, I am not sure to which other works he referred. The Bill refers specifically to national road construction works, not to maintenance works. The Government firmly believes that by adopting the tender and contract principle, in the longer term we will see much better progress in respect of our national roads program than we have seen in the past. I might add in passing that this is not a new principle. Quite a lot of work done by the various departments of main roads is, in fact, let out to tender. What we insist upon, since all national roads are eligible for 100 per cent Commonwealth government funding, is that the money we allocate to this purpose obtains the maximum length of road possible. We believe that the tender and contract system will ensure that. If the local governing bodies and the departments of main roads are efficient enough, there is no doubt that they will have every chance of winning in their bids. One needs to remember that local government, and, indeed, the departments of main roads, have an advantage that private contractors do not have-that is, they do not pay sales tax on the equipment that they purchase.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the statements made by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs at a Press conference in Hobart on 16 May and reported on Australian Broadcasting Commission national radio that evening. At that conference the Minister admitted that Australia's youth unemployment was high compared with other countries and that the Federal Government 'may not be doing enough for the young jobless and that existing training programs may not be good enough to help school leavers make the transition from school to work'. Firstly, does the Prime Minister agree with this assessment by his Minister of the Government's failure to deal adequately with the problem of youth unemployment? Secondly, does he regard this assessment as a serious indictment of policies which have had now more than five years to work and yet proved singularly unsuccessful? Finally, is it now the Government's intention to rectify this totally unacceptable situation and adopt the recent recommendation of the Schools Commission for the triennium 1982-1984 that 'an assessment of the existing pattern of youth training and support programs be undertaken with the view of developing a comprehensive youth policy'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable gentleman was picking up a part of a Schools Commission report that came out either late in 1980 or very early this year--
—I was talking about your Minister, first of all.

—I thought that the honourable gentleman was referring to a Schools Commission report. I think it is worth drawing attention to the fact that that Schools Commission report emphasised the very serious matter that many Australian schools, if not all Australian secondary schools, were giving inadequate attention to large groups of young Australians. The Schools Commission made it plain that the schools were providing an adequate education for those with academic talents who might want to go on to a college or a university but that many other young Australians were going through school with a sense of failure and frustration, probably compounded by difficulty in getting work after leaving school. They had a sense of failure and frustration at school because courses and curricula related to that particular person's talents and inclinations were not available. Quite plainly that was a very serious indictment by the Schools Commission of many Australian secondary schools.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that, the Minister for Education and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs have had extensive discussions with State governments about ways to improve the opportunities open to young Australians who are now lacking those opportunities. It is not just a question of jobs, it is also, for many young Australians, a question of adequate training. We earlier began the school-to-work transition training programs which are starting to make an impact. As my colleague has indicated, the Government is not satisfied with the progress that so far has been made. It has an open mind in relation to our training programs. If the honourable member for Wills or anyone else can come forward with positive proposals to improve the opportunities for training of young Australians or of other Australians in need of new or improved job skills, those suggestions will be examined in all seriousness. The honourable gentleman asked a serious question and deserves a serious and proper answer in relation to it. Our approach to the young unemployed has been one of evolution, the development of programs over a period aiming specifically, when we can, at the groups finding least satisfaction and least opportunity in the present system.

To the extent that my colleague indicated in his remarks that we have an unsatisfactory situation-we are not satisfied with it because young Australians are unemployed and there are people at school who do not get adequate opportunities-obviously we want to improve it. I can only suggest that honourable members wait a little while until my colleague the Minister for Education makes a statement on education matters. That will show the shape of some of the initiatives that the Government believes should be carried out. The honourable member also suggested that the general programs to improve employment opportunities in Australia have not been successful. That, of course, is where I part company with him. I believe Australia has demonstrated very plainly that under Australia's policies private enterprise over the last two years has provided more jobs than it has provided for a very long while. If one compares Australia's economy with the United States, Germany, Britain and a number of other countries, one will find that Australia's economy is growing and employment opportunities are growing whereas in many places around the world those opportunities actually are shrinking. Over the last two years Australia's private enterprise has provided 250,000 additional jobs. That is much more than could ever have been provided by anyone's make-work schemes which, of course, would have been provided at vast additional cost.

The Government will be pressing forward with those economic policies which have been demonstrated to be successful and which a number of other countries are now starting to emulate. The Government also will press forward with seeking to provide more opportunities for young Australians who find themselves in difficulty either at school or after they leave school. As part of that examination, I remind the House that we also indicated that we want to examine the allowances available to low income families to make sure that people staying in full time training longer will not unduly affect the wellbeing of low income Australian families. The basis for action in that case, of course, is that over a long period the secondary allowance scheme will help low income parents put their children through the last two years of secondary schooling. That allowance was increased very significantly at the time of the last Budget. We are not necessarily satisfied that those arrangements for low income families are adequate. So the allowances available to people in full time education or training are also under review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. Is the report in today's Press correct that the Australian Industries Development Association has put a submission to the Department of the Treasury suggesting that the Government tax petroleum products at up to a 15 per cent a year increase for the next five years, even above the current Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries price? If so, what is the Government's present position on increasing the tax on petroleum products used in Australia above OPEC's price for crude oil?

—As the honourable member knows, industry bodies and others in the community put a lot of submissions to the Government about revenue and other matters. I understand that a submission dealing with that broad subject has been presented to my Department. I have not seen the submission. I do not think it will surprise the honourable gentleman for me to say that I will not respond affirmatively or negatively to specific areas of speculation on revenue matters.

—I ask the Prime Minister whether the reports are correct which appeared yesterday and today to the effect that two Government members were to be beneficiaries of an overseas trip sponsored by a self-interested media group and that according to one of the Government members-the honourable member for Bowman-'selection for the trip had come through Mr Sinclair's office'. If these reports are correct, is it usual for a senior Minister's office to be used to channel invitations of this nature in circumstances where it could be concluded that the offerer might believe he, she or they stood to gain some subsequent government advantage from the offer being accepted? Are the circumstances surrounding this matter consistent with the declared policy of the Government? Is it the Government's intention to allow this practice to continue in future? Finally, will the Prime Minister instruct the two Government members concerned not to accept the offer, especially in view of the potential blatant conflict of interest involved and as spelled out in rules 8 (b) and 8 (c) of the code of conduct laid down in the report on public duty and private interest?

—At the outset, I believed that the question would be out of order but I allowed it to proceed in case there were elements of it which were in order. Only one element of the question is in order and that relates to the part of the question addressed to the Prime Minister concerning the actions of the Minister for Communications. I inform the House that it is out of order to ask any Minister a question about the attitude, behaviour or actions of a member of the Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of your ruling, Mr Speaker, am I permitted to answer the whole question or only part of it?

—The Prime Minister has asked whether it is permissible for him to answer the whole question. The answer to that is no. However, if there is anything that he needs to say in order to make his answer in relation to the actions of one of his Ministers meaningful, it is relevant to the question and may be said.

—What I will say will all be relevant to that central point. I think I should draw the attention of the House to the fact that there are different kinds of sponsored trips. There are many trips sponsored by governments. There have been leader grants to the United States of America. There have been visits to Japan at the request and as a guest of the Japanese Government. Many honourable members have participated over the years in both of them. I do not think anyone would have any doubt that a trip which is openly sponsored by another government-I emphasise the words 'openly sponsored by another government'-so long as it is within the judgment of a member of parliament, could be accepted. It has happened both ways on a number of occasions. I think we then start to get into a category of sponsored trips which can have some doubt cast over them. It has been customary for members of all parties, over many years, to participate in Qantas Airways Ltd inaugural flights or the launching of a ship. They are commercial in their nature. I do not think anyone would want to cast any doubt in relation to them.

ANSWER.PARA: I think this invitation was one that was cast in the public domain. Nobody was seeking to do it in any secret way. Quite plainly members' travel is a matter that members themselves must decide. I think that this instance and the publicity that has related to it have made it quite plain that the sooner this Parliament discusses in detail the Bowen report and applies it to the members of this Parliament the better it will be. That is under discussion at the moment with members of the Parliament. I draw attention to the fact that the Bowen report has been applied in relation to Ministers and the Commonwealth Public Service. Of course, commercially sponsored trips by Ministers would be outlawed under the Bowen report. But I emphasise again that members of parliament are in a somewhat different position. I believe that they need to make their own judgments about these matters for themselves against the background of experience in the Parliament generally and also against the background of their own common sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of the Minister for Defence, I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that prior to the recent visit of Prince Charles to the Army base at Puckapunyal a special toilet block was built for his use and that the cost was $60,000? Is it also a fact that there was an existing toilet situated only 150 yards away from the new toilet and that the new facility was dismantled immediately after the Prince had left the base? If the facts are correct, would not the Prime Minister agree that the erection of this facility represents a poor reflection on the physical endurance of the Prince--
—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. He is not entitled to make those comments in seeking information.

—If the facts are correct, would not the Prime Minister agree that, particularly in view of the present demonstration in King's Hall by the women's refuge group, this represents a poor reflection on the financial priorities of the Government?
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. You will recall that I was ruled out of order for even mentioning the Prince of Wales in respect of an expedition trip down the Franklin River.
—The honourable gentleman's recollection of events is faulty.

—I doubt very much whether the facts allegedly related in the question are accurate. But let me ascertain the position. I will advise the House or ask my colleague the Acting Minister for Defence to advise the House at the earliest opportunity. Also I would only want to say that I think that if the facts are as related, which I very much doubt, His Royal Highness himself would have been disturbed to believe that such unusual lengths had been gone to for his alleged covenience.
—I have two questions for the Minister for Communications.
—The honourable gentleman may ask one.

—They are both related matters. The first concerns the non-existent radio services on the west coast of Tasmania. The second concerns Access 80 at Dover, which is in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Franklin. When will we see some action to solve these serious Tasmanian problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to the first question, the honourable gentleman has certainly been most assiduous on behalf of his constituents in trying to press for some extension of radio communications into that very mountainous area. I know that there have been extensive discussions to try to overcome those problems. I am not sure of the exact state of their progress, and I will advise the honourable gentleman in due course when I have checked. I can assure him that there is a recognition of the difficulties of the people there, and I hope that an early resolution of the problem can be secured. Of course, once the satellite is available the problems of people who live on the west coast of Tasmania, and in many other isolated and remote areas of Australia, will be alleviated as a result of the ability to place an earth station and a transmitter on site to overcome the present transmission difficulties that occur in some areas of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to Access 80 and Dover, the position is slightly different. Many communities around Australia would like an extension of their present local call access. The whole concept of Access 80 was to provide an opportunity for everyone to have access to a main business centre. As I understand the position in Dover, many people would like access to another business centre, but that does not deny the fact that, within the definition provided by Telecom, access is already available to a business centre. In those circumstances there seems little prospect that the Access 80 extension suggested by the honourable gentleman's question is likely to be realised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister, and I ask it by virtue of the second paragraph (b) of Standing Order 144, which provides that questions may seek an explanation regarding the policy of the Government and its applications. I ask the question particularly in relation to past policy concerning the matter of propriety of conduct by members. Does the Prime Minister recall the letter I wrote to him on 9 February 1978 in which I pointed out the concern of my colleague the honourable member for Newcastle about the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety and the offer of a trip to Japan which had been extended by the Japan Automobile Association? I said:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Jones is concerned about the propriety of a Parliamentary Committee being sponsored in this way by organisations which might well be seen by the public, whether rightly or wrongly is not important, as being self-interested parties in the subject matter being inquired into by that Committee.

I also pointed out in the letter that the evidence suggested that the invitation was in response to action initiated, perhaps, by a member of the Committee. Does the Prime Minister recall replying to me on 20 February 1978 and concluding his letter in these terms: 'I also, however, expressed my view to Mr Katter that this invitation should not be accepted'. That is a view which I applauded then and still applaud. Will he apply that practice on this occasion, as the circumstances are entirely similar?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order.
—Mr Speaker, that is sheer nonsense. I raise a point of order against your ruling.

—Mr Speaker, can I help the honourable gentleman. I think that if a question such as this is asked and then is ruled out of order, it leaves something hanging in the air which I for one, in this instance anyway, would sooner answer, if I may be allowed to do so.

—I must inform the House that my task is to apply the Standing Orders. No Minister is responsible to this Parliament for the actions of any member of the Parliament, unless it be the Minister for Administrative Services in some way relating to remuneration or allowances or expenses paid. Accordingly, I allowed the question to be asked in full in case it raised some issue which brought it into order. I fully accept the point made by the Prime Minister that, having allowed the question to be asked, something is left hanging in the air, so to speak. I will permit the Prime Minister to answer. I indicate that there is no way in which I can judge whether a question is out of order except by hearing the question, and in that respect the Standing Orders need to be upheld. As a matter of indulgence, I will permit the Prime Minister to reply.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker, and I thank the Leader of the Opposition for reminding me of that occasion. It might well indicate the kind of view that I hold in relation to these matters. I also emphasise again that it is a question of members ultimately making up their own minds about what they do. I do not believe that the Executive-the Government-should seek to direct members of parliament in these matters, and I believe that members are elected to this place in many instances to exercise their independent judgment.
—Did you tell David that?
—A conversation between myself and a member of parliament is a matter between the two of us.
—Does he go with your support? Answer that one.

—The honourable gentleman has asked his 'out of order' question which, Mr Speaker, with your indulgence I am answering. I think he is having a fair enough go. I emphasise again that this instance serves to remind us all that we should get ahead and process the Bowen report in relation to members of this Parliament because then there will be publicly known guidelines which can held in the guidance of honourable members in making their decisions or the Opposition in relation to its criticism.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to media reports stating that the University of Adelaide Council will refuse to administer the recently announced student loans scheme and that that University is unwilling to charge fees for second and higher degrees? Is this an unprecedented stance by a governing body of a university or college of advanced education? What action will the Minister take to ensure that an effective loans scheme works to the advantage of students in institutions that follow such discriminatory action? Will government grants to tertiary institutions that refuse to charge appropriate fees for second and higher degrees be reduced?

—I am aware of the reported views of the Council of the University of Adelaide. I am surprised, to say the least, that the University Council would have made the reported statements without first being fully aware of all the conditions and details of the Government decisions. Of course, the Government has announced its intention to reintroduce fees in a limited way. I refer, of course, to the decision to reintroduce fees for second and higher degrees. Within that area there are certain exemptions-for example, for recognised double degrees and also for holders of Commonwealth and university post-graduate awards. So far as the published comments from the University of Adelaide are concerned, I will have discussions in the near future with representatives of the Vice-Chancellors Committee. I hope that all universities will co-operate with the Commonwealth in this regard. Indeed, I believe that the proposed student loans scheme will prove to be of great benefit to a large number of students throughout Australia. I hope that the University of Adelaide would not take any action that would perhaps deny the benefit of this scheme to its students. So far as the honourable member's question concerned action that the Government might take if the University failed to co-operate, I am not prepared at this stage to comment on what actions we might take to ensure that students are not disadvantaged. I can give the honourable member and the House an assurance that the Government will pursue the implementation of this loans scheme as rapidly as possible so that it will be in place to operate from the beginning of 1982. Whatever decisions are taken will be decisions to ensure that no student is disadvantaged by the actions or views of a university.
