—I direct my question to the Minister for Education. Having in mind that the Newcastle-Hunter region is the sixth largest centre of population in Australia with enormous growth based on coal extraction, aluminium smelters and other industrial development, can the Minister give some explanation of the reasons why the multipurpose Newcastle College of Advanced Education is to be integrated with the University of Newcastle? Why should this integration take place when out of a total enrolment of 2,748 students there are 505 effective full time students in areas other than teacher education? On these figures, how can the Minister substantiate that this College of Advanced Education is a single-purpose college? Finally, will the Minister give details of the cost benefits that will accrue from the integration of this low-cost CAE with the higher cost university of Newcastle without a substantial reduction in staff?

—For some time now, the Tertiary Education Commission has drawn attention to the need for rationalisation within the Australian university and college sector. In its most recent report, for the 1982-1984 triennium, the Tertiary Education Commission drew attention to the need for some 30 colleges to be integrated in one form or another. The TEC has listed these 30 colleges which it believes should be integrated either one with the other or with other institutions. Of course, the Government has taken the decision to which the honourable member for Newcastle has referred and, in that context, I want the honourable member to know-indeed, the House and the wider community to know-that in the first instance there will be consultation between the Tertiary Education Commission and the co-ordinating bodies within the States.
—When?

—In the very near future. Following that, there will be consultation between myself and State Ministers. I emphasise to the House that it is the Government's view, as it is the Tertiary Education Commission's view, that rationalisation is necessary. Rationalisation will take place but the details of the implementation of the decision will first be discussed between the co-ordinating bodies at Commonwealth and State levels, and then between myself and State Ministers.

—I so move for the suspension of Standing Orders. I am grateful to the Government for allowing this discussion to proceed. Whilst it is enormously important, it will not require a great deal of development. The facts, I believe, stand for themselves. Reports which have been published in the last two days, initiated by Miss Cromie in the Australian Financial Review yesterday and followed up today by other newspapers and the Australian Financial Review, again by Miss Cromie, make it clear that the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) and Senator Collard, described as key members of the Government's back bench committee on communications, had received invitations, which presumably they have accepted, to attend a conference in the United States of America which will discuss cable television. It is well known that a number of consortiums in Australia and overseas consortiums which have been to Australia recently have been pressingly putting--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition may now move his motion in substantive terms.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House is of the opinion, that in view of Rules 8 (b) and 8 (c) of paragraph 4.9 of the report 'Public Duty and Private Interest', viz-
An officeholder should not:

(b) solicit or accept any benefit, advantage or promise of future advantage for himself, his immediate family or any business concern or trust with which he is associated from persons who are in, or seek to be in, any contractual or special relationship with government;
(c) except as may be permitted under the rules applicable to his office, accept any gift, hospitality or concessional travel offered in connection with the discharge of the duties of his office,

and the clear potential for the conclusion to be drawn that the honourable member for Bowman and Senator Collard could be seen as transgressing those provisions by accepting free overseas travel from an unidentified business consortium, they should reject this offer forthwith.

I am sure there is no need to go over the episodic nature of what I want to present to the House as it has developed so far. The point I was making is simply that there is a matter of very high principle involved in relation to the propriety of the conduct of members of parliament. It is hackneyed, I know, to repeat the old axiom that justice must not only be done but seen to be done. Similarly, just as hackneyed but no less important is it as principle to declare that not only should there be proper conduct by members of parliament but also it should be seen as proper conduct by members of parliament. We should take every reasonable and proper step to put as much distance between ourselves and any sets of circumstances which may appear to compromise-even if, in fact, they fail-our integrity and independence as members of parliament.

For that reason the report 'Public Duty and Private Interest' was drawn up. I see many defects in it but it is better than nothing. It is stronger in its proposals than anything the Government is prepared to adopt. It is not our fault that this report has not been fully canvassed in this House. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that he wanted a full debate on it. We would welcome that opportunity. But I remind honourable members that it is more than 18 months since the report was brought into the House. I outlined in the wording of the motion, which I will not repeat, the concern felt by members of that committee-I might mention that they are quite conservative members-in relation to the potential for a member of parliament, or other people, such as office holders or Ministers, to be compromised by certain circumstances and that, therefore, a code of conduct ought to be followed.
When introducing the report in the Parliament on 22 November 1979 the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) said, among other things:
The Government has accepted virtually the whole of the Committee's recommendations in regard to Ministers, public servants and other officials.
This would include us. In that statement 'virtually' means 'effectively' and 'totally'. Recommendation 8 (c) of the report declares that people such as members of parliament should not:
. . . except as may be permitted under the rules applicable to his office, accept any gift, hospitality or concessional travel offered in connection with the discharge of the duties of his office.

There is no other way to interpret the acceptance of such an invitation as I have mentioned-the conditions of which are familiar to honourable members-but as concessional travel which is associated with the discharge of the duties of office of those two members, Senator Collard and the honourable member for Bowman. They are both members of the Government's committee on communications. It has been said by the honourable member for Bowman, at least in newspaper reports, and no effort has been made by the Goverment to repudiate these statements, that the offer to him came through the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). I refer to a report in yesterday's Australian Financial Review which states:
His selection-
That is, Mr Jull's selection-
For the trip had come through Mr Sinclair's office, he said.

Not only do members have to disengage from this quite undesirable practice but also the Minister is responsible for conduct which is highly questionable in these circumstances on the face of evidence which is publicly available. The Government should take the first opportunity available to repudiate these statements if they are not correct. At least the Minister should repudiate them. He will have the opportunity to do so directly. But the key point at which I am getting is that these sorts of invitations are inappropriate invitations for members of parliament to accept. It seems to me that there is a vast difference between an invitation at an official level offered regularly by a government such as the Japanese Government to members of this Parliament, which I understand is reciprocated by the Australian Government, where it is clear that the objectivity of members of parliament is not in any way sullied.
The Opposition also received an invitation from Mr Rosenhain of Myer Emporium Ltd in the following terms:

I am quite prepared that the same terms and conditions be offered to members of the Federal Labor Party to travel to the same convention for the same length of time, e.g. departing Australia 27 May, returning to Australia in time for Government sitting 9th June.

I have arranged for a response to go today rejecting that invitation. Two wrongs will not make a right. Both the honourable member for Bowman and Senator Collard are quite wrong in their behaviour if they accept these invitations. Sufficient official trips are available to members of parliament. As well there is an overseas travel entitlement for each parliamentary term which would more than adequately meet the travel needs or travel lust of members of this Parliament without allowing themselves to be compromised in the way in which the honourable member for Bowman and Senator Collard seemed determined to be.

I repeat, more leisurely, the communications between myself and the Prime Minister on a similar matter in 1978. On that occasion my colleague the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Charles Jones), as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, contacted me about a letter received by the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). I quote from this letter at some greater length. It stated:

It seems to me that what the letter boils down to is a proposal that a Parliamentary Committee should be sponsored by, and thereby become a beneficiary of, the Japan Automobile Association Inc. in making a trip to Japan. If my information is correct, it might seem that action may have been initiated by a member of the Committee--
The honourable member for Kennedy-
to encourage this offer of sponsorship.
That is a quite improper action in my view. The letter continues:

Mr Jones is concerned about the propriety of a Parliamentary Committee being sponsored in this way by organisations which might well be seen by the public, whether rightly or wrongly is not important, as being self-interested parties in the subject matter being inquired into by that Committee.

I share his concern and I know that those of my colleagues with whom I have discussed this matter share my concern. I should think that the principle is that if it is necessary for a Parliamentary Committee to travel overseas to further its investigations then the cost of any such travel ought to be exclusively supported by Parliament.
The Prime Minister's response came on 20 February. I repeat it. The Prime Minister stated:
I . . . expressed my view to Mr Katter that this invitation should not be accepted.

There can be no quibbling about the directness and the firmness of the Prime Minister's expression of view to the honourable member for Kennedy nor can there be any gainsaying that it was influential, because the honourable member for Kennedy desisted from any further purpose in this respect. The trip was not undertaken. I suggest that if it had been, there would have been enormous compromising of the members of the Committee who were participating in that way. Exactly the same set of circumstances apply in this case. We are surely not in such a mendicant position that we have to go around cap in hand soliciting for trips overseas or holding our breaths trusting that some wealthy and self-interested-I say this without any reservation-sponsor comes forward to promote us on a trip overseas. That immediately compromises our impartiality in any matters before us related to the self-interest of those people.

There is another aspect: Whilst I have the greatest respect for Mr Rosenhain of Myer Emporium Ltd, to the extent that I have been able to gauge his character on the few occasions I have met him, the fact is that he is a member of a consortium which has a vast interest in communications in an area which is directly a concern of the communications committee of the Government and, therefore, one which implicated very much the attention of the honourable member for Bowman and Senator Collard. Again, there is the aspect that the other members of the consortium are unknown to use. There is a very high degree of anonymity about that association. If we put all these scores together, there is the potential for people outside the Parliament who harbour reservations from time to time about just how independent members of Parliament might or might not be, to draw the most seedy and undesirable conclusions and then to broadbrush the lot of us as a result of those conclusions. The conclusions may not be justified but on the basis of superficial evidence there is a case to justify them and to draw the worst possible conclusions. At least, many of those people will believe this and so the suspicions will develop. I repeat: When it is all washed up, we all suffer to some extent as a result of that sort of thing happening. There is no need for any member of this Parliament to become a beggar or a mendicant, looking about for free overseas trips sponsored by self-interested parties, hoping that one will turn up or, if one does fall his way, to grab it with both hands and refuse to give it up.

The recommendations in the report of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest make abundantly clear the proper standard of conduct in these matters. The standard of conduct which has been adopted in this instance by the honourable member for Bowman and Senator Collard is quite improper.

Finally, the behaviour of the Minister for Communications in acting as a sort of channel, as it were-a post office-in passing on these invitations, if the reports are correct, to the benefactors of this largesse is quite improper too. I believe that there can be no quibbling by members of this House about how they vote on this motion. After some preamble, the motion requires that the honourable member for Bowman and Senator Collard should immediately withdraw from being sponsored to engage in this undertaking-this trip. If honourable members vote against that motion, they vote against consistently proper standards of conduct being applied in matters such as this-proper standards of conduct which applied in the case of the honourable member for Kennedy when on one occasion he was soliciting for a free trip overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) had not said that, Mr Speaker, I probably would not have been interested in this debate. What actually happened and the purpose of my taking part-

—The honourable member for Kennedy will resume his seat. I made an assumption that the honourable gentleman was going to seek leave to make a personal explanation. He is speaking to the motion. Therefore, before I call him to speak, I must ask for a seconder to the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I second the motion and I will make my remarks now. I will be very brief because I understand that there are time contraints. Let me deal with the matter on the basis of what has already been elicited at Question Time. I would think that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is very much against any members of the Parliament, including the Senator mentioned and the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull), taking part in the trip that has been mentioned. I refer to the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest which has been mentioned earlier today. The Committee's report clearly indicates that the terms of reference of that inquiry concerned what procedures should be followed to determine whether there has been any breach of the high standards which are properly required of those in public office.

SPEECH.PARA: If we start by talking about the standards required of those in public office, those standards apply to every member in this Parliament. It just begs the question to argue about whether members of Parliament can accept offers made through a Minister or directly without being tainted by the fact that there were some pecuniary advancements for the member or members concerned. I refer to the Code of Conduct and the Committee's report which states:
The impression should be avoided that any person can improperly influence an office holder . . .
That would apply to a member of Parliament-
or unduly enjoy his favour.

I think it is very clear when we are talking about the Government at the present time that we have to be very stern about the fact that the Bowen Committee was set up way back in February 1978. It reported as far back as two years ago. Nothing has been done about that report by this Parliament. There has been no discussion or no implementation of the Code of Conduct. Is it any wonder that the honourable senator and the honourable member concerned might feel that they can avail themselves of a generous offer overseas because no rules have been laid down?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable gentleman to excuse me for just a second. I should indicate to the House that when the Leader of the Opposition moved his motion he included in it a reference to a statement. There was some confusion, I think, on the part of some members of the House as to what the actual terms of the motion were. I propose to read the motion in the form which the Leader of the Opposition has given. The motion stated:

INTERJECT.PARA: That this House is of the opinion, that in view of Rules 8 (b) and 8 (c) of paragraph 4.9 of the report 'Public Duty and Private Interest', and the clear potential for the conclusions to be drawn that the honourable member for Bowman and Senator Collard be seen as transgressing those provisions by accepting free overseas travel from an unidentified business consortium, they should reject this offer forthwith.
The particular items Rule 8 (b) and 8 (c) read:
An officeholder should not:

(b) solicit or accept any benefit, advantage or promise of future advantage whether for himself, his immediate family or any business concern or trust with which he is associated with persons who are in, or seek to be in, any contractual or special relationship with government;
(c) except as may be permitted under the rules applicable to his office, accept any gift, hospitality or concessional travel offered in connection with the discharge of the duties of his office.
The impression should be avoided that any person can improperly influence the officeholder and unduly enjoy his favour.

I hope that clarifies the matter for the House. I call the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and indicate to him that I will subtract the period I have spent in explanation from the time allowed to him to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker. I was making the point that the Bowen Committee reported on this and other matters as far back as July 1979. It is virtually a censure of the Government to find two years later that there has been no implementation or intelligent discussion of that report. If we had implemented the code of conduct recommended by the Bowen Committee, whether by statute or under Standing Orders, it would be very clear that no member of parliament could avail himself of offers such as those made to an honourable member in this House and a senator in the other place.
—You could not even accept a tea cosy under those rules.

—As the honourable member has pointed out, he could not accept any gift at all. There are rules and regulations governing the sorts of gifts that Ministers may accept. Gifts to Ministers create the impression that there is a way to buy favours. We cannot run a democracy if that is the case. We are talking about the implementation of cable television. Any of us who have had an interest in the communications field in the past, as many of us have, know that it is the most profitable aspect of television. It is highly centralised. Ownership is controlled. It will make enormous profits for a select group of people. In the time of the Labor Government enormous influences were brought to bear. People wanted cable television implemented in Australia because it would benefit certain proprietary interests, not the general public. There is great advantage in having cable television. It gives all sorts of benefits to those owning the cable and deciding what comes through it.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member and senator concerned in this matter will not find out anything new. If they want to know about cable television they will find that people involved in the telecommunications system in Australia have enough input into this area. They know what it means, how it is implemented, who owns it elsewhere in the world and why these multinationals want to bring it to Australia and own and control it. This is not in accordance with a number of principles which we hold on this side of the House. We should consider communications from the point of view of public ownership, public control and public benefit, not private ownership, exploitation and profit. If the two gentlemen concerned accept this offer, saying that they will give us information that we cannot get ourselves, they will leave themselves wide open to the belief that they are beholden to those who paid their way. It would be a stupid thing for them to do. It would determine whether they held their own seats and what public opinion of them would be.

Not one of us in the Parliament can escape the fact that if we accept a trip from anybody, other than a trip provided by the Parliament, it will be deemed by public opinion that we owe something to those offering the trip. Of course we would. It is unbusinesslike of the Myer Emporium Ltd or anyone else to suggest that this is an intelligent thing to do. The Myer Emporium is interested mainly in domestic and retail sales. Communications come within the national network in respect of which a fair amount of public money has already been expended in setting up the base frame. It is important that nobody should intrude into this area by offering a fringe benefit in order to gain profits for shareholders or some select group. What we think should have been done has been made very clear by my leader.

The Parliament went to a lot of trouble to set up the Bowen Committee. It set out its terms of reference in 1978. The Committee reported in 1979. Nothing has been done since. There is a responsibility on the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the whole Cabinet to implement quickly in the Parliament the codes of conduct recommended by the Bowen Committee, whether by statute or Standing Orders. This would remove the necessity to move a motion in this House urging two members of parliament, in their own interests and in the interests of the dignity and stature of the Parliament, not to accept an offer of private travel. Anybody in his right mind would know that such offers should not even be considered. The offer has been made and the members concerned are obviously interested in going. It makes it so much worse that we have to take the time of the Parliament to move a motion suggesting that they do not go. If they go their seats should be forfeited. They say that they will come back with clean hands and that they will have learnt something they could not have learnt in Australia. If they want to go, let them get some intelligent advice from the communications research group in Australia.

It is dangerous for the private sector to offer trips to Ministers or back bench members of parliament so that they may take an interest and inform themselves. On many occasions local government throughout this country has been the subject of litigation on the basis of conspiracy, fraud or the suggestion of private commissions. It is considered that if something is offered to a person, perhaps he will be under an obligation to treat an application favourably. Mr Speaker, you will know that if anybody offers a person a trip, even in a taxi, to look at a property it is deemed to be an infringement of the Local Government Act in most areas. It is as serious as that, even at a lower level of government. It is beyond comprehension that trips overseas can be sponsored by the private commercial sector with a view to gaining a benefit for that sector.

I urge the Prime Minister, when he next answers questions in the Parliament, to say that he will do something about the recommendations of the Bowen Committee. It is his task to do so. The Committee reported two years ago. It is important that we now implement the code of conduct it recommended. As my leader said, if we had implemented it there would be no question of these gentlemen undertaking such a trip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest needs to be looked at, first of all, in relation to the motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and seconded by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). In particular, the two sections to which you, Mr Speaker, adverted in explaining the motion need to be examined. I think we also need to have an understanding of the recommendations of the Bowen Committee report that the Government has accepted and those parts of it yet to be considered. There is no doubt that with respect to those people we customarily know as office holders-Ministers and public servants-the recommendations of the Bowen Committee report have been adopted. Other sections of the report applying to the private members in this place at this stage have not been adopted. However, a code of conduct has been recommended. It is to that code that the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition addressed itself. The Leader of the Opposition drew attention to section 8(c) in paragraph 4.9. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: 8. An officeholder should not . . .
(c) except as may be permitted under the rules applicable to his office, accept any gift, hospitality or concessional travel offered in connection with the discharge of the duties of his office.

I think we all know that whatever the definition of public duty and private interest, people at all levels in this place accept some form of hospitality or concessional travel. Let me illustrate two areas. Very few members in this place have not been to some of the areas of developing resources in Australia. In those developing areas, particularly in the remoter parts of Australia, it is often not possible to travel by ordinary vehicle. It would be extraordinary if honourable members had not travelled by whatever farm or company vehicle was made available for the purpose. Similarly, very few members of parliament would not at some stage have accepted a meal from one or other of the people involved in many of the diverse activities associated with the business of Australia. There has to be a definition of the rules applicable to the office of a member of parliament. I see this as a necessary part of the determination that the Parliament will be required to undertake with respect to the recommendations of the Bowen Committee.

At this stage, however, let me assert again that there has been no acceptance by the Parliament of any of those rules relating to private members. Therefore, it is for the private member himself to determine whether and to what degree he will accept concessional travel, hospitality and gifts. To the degree to which he accepts them, of course, it is, without any doubt, obligatory on him, if he feels that in any way they compromise him on matters that come up for consideration in this place, to declare his interest. Those laws do not relate to the Bowen Committee proposals. At this stage they have not been adopted. I received a letter on 1 May 1981 from Mr K. A. Rosenhain, the Corporate Managing Director of the Myer Emporium Ltd. It read:

There are many people including some Members of Parliament, who have no appreciation of exactly what Cable Television is or can be. As far as I can see this condition will not change significantly unless some corrective action is taken.

Given that the deliberations of the Broadcasting Tribunal will be news for the months before, during and after the hearings, it would seem that at least those Members of Parliament involved with communications should understand Cable Television.

I interpolate that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) a few moments ago addressed himself to the fact that there would be no advantage in people finding out about cable television. Let me assure him that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal at the moment is conducting a public hearing into cable television and subscription television in order that the community can be better informed on the matter and so that we can take decisions in this place on what steps are necessary for the advancement of those two communication developments in Australia. There is a necessity for members of this place to know something more about cable television and subscription television than, I suggest, many now do. The letter continues:

If you agree, therefore, I would like to propose that provisions be made, from private enterprise, to send from three to five members of the Back Bench Committee for Communications as a study team to the 4-day Cable Television Convention from May 29 through June 1 in Los Angeles, California.
Again, if you agree, would you please nominate those members of the committee you feel should comprise the study team.
I am sure the results of their deliberations will be beneficial to both the Parliament and the people of Australia.
May I please hear from you.
Yours faithfully, K. A. ROSENHAIN
A response was sent on 14 May 1981 in which I stated:

DEBATE.TITLE: THIRD UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE LAW OF THE SEA: AUSTRALIAN DELEGATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table two reports of the Australian Delegation to the Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea. They are the the reports of the Ninth Session of the Conference held in New York from 3 March to 4 April 1980 and of the Resumed Ninth Session which was held in Geneva from 28 July to 29 August 1980. With your leave, Mr Speaker, and the leave of the House, I would like to say a few words about the reports and about the Law of the Sea Conference itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ever since the first substantive session of the Conference in Caracas in Venezuela in 1974, the Australian delegation has produced detailed reports of developments at the Conference. These reports contain an account of the negotiations and have annexed to them copies of the most significant statements that were made during that particular session as well as copies of the negotiating texts produced by the Conference. Since the Fourth Session of the Conference in 1976, the Delegation's reports have been published in bound volumes and have been tabled in this Parliament. The result is that we now have available to us a detailed history of the Law of the Sea Conference, as seen through the eyes of the Australian Delegation. As far as we can ascertain, no other delegation has prepared such comprehensive reports and few governments have tabled the reports of their delegation to the Law of the Sea Conference in their Parliaments. Honourable members may be interested to know that the reports are also widely read in sectors of the community interested in the Law of the Sea, especially in Australian universities and in fishing and conservationist bodies. They are also studied closely by State governments and by the mining industry, both of which have had representatives attached to the Australian Delegation at the last few sessions of the Conference. Furthermore, the reports are provided to a number of foreign governments. I understand that they are found to be of considerable use, particularly by our neighbours in the South Pacific region.

SPEECH.PARA: In short, the reports of the Australian delegations to the Law of the Sea Conference represent what I believe is a successful attempt by successive Australian governments to make information, on a complex subject of great significance to Australia, comprehensible and accessible to the Australian community. I commend them to the attention of honourable members. The Law of the Sea Conference is perhaps the largest, certainly the longest running, diplomatic conference that has been convened since the founding of the United Nations. It is an ambitious attempt by the international community to try to bring order and certainty to an area covering seven-tenths of the earth's surface-an area where legal doubts and uncertainty currently exist. The draft Convention, which is now being considered by the Conference, has been painstakingly put together over the last six or so years. It contains over 350 articles on every aspect of the Law of the Sea. There are articles defining the limits of national jurisdiction over the territorial sea, exclusive economic zone and continental shelf; there are articles providing for freedom of passage through straits used for international navigation and through archipelagos; there are articles on the protection and preservation of the marine environment and on the conduct of marine scientific research; and of considerable significance for the future, the Draft Convention proposes a regime to govern the recovery of the mineral riches of the deep seabed beyond national jurisdiction, which the United Nations has agreed should be regarded as 'the common heritage of mankind'.

It is self-evident and needs no emphasising by me that, as an island continent with extensive off-shore areas and a heavy dependence on international trade, Australia has a vital interest in the issues before the Law of the Sea Conference. It is an objective of the Australian Government that the International Law of the Sea be cleared of the doubts and uncertainties that exist today and that some new concepts around which a wide measure of agreement has grown up should be recognised. To this end, successive governments of Australia, both on this side of the House and on the other, have taken the view that our very substantial interest in the Law of the Sea would best be protected by the early adoption of a comprehensive and widely-accepted Convention. Australian delegations have worked hard to ensure that our interests are met in the texts that have been prepared by the Conference. I am pleased to report to honourable members that these efforts have largely been successful.

Before the start of the Tenth Session of the Law of the Sea Conference, which was held in New York from 9 March to 24 April this year, there was reason to hope that it might be possible to conclude the negotiations on the outstanding issues, so that the way would be cleared for a Law of the Sea Convention to be opened for signature at a special meeting of the Conference in Caracas, perhaps later this year. As honourable members may be aware, however, the new United States Administration decided to review its policies towards the Law of the Sea Conference and indicated that it would not be able to participate in further substantive negotiations until that review was completed. Because the Conference is proceeding on the basis that the provisions of the new Law of the Sea Convention should, if possible, be adopted by consensus, one of the consequences of the American decision was that it was not possible to conclude the negotiations at the Tenth Session. As I indicated in response to a question in this House on 30 April, the Government has taken available opportunities to explain to the United States Government that, while we fully understand its need to review its policies on the Law of the Sea, we hope that the review will be completed quickly so that a Convention, in which Australia has vital interests, can be adopted as soon as possible. Indeed, I spoke in these terms to Secretary of State Haig during my visit to Washington in March.

The next session of the Law of the Sea Conference will be held in Geneva in August this year. I understand that it is unlikely that the United States review will be completed by that date. The Government is hopeful, nevertheless, that it will prove possible to make more progress at that Session than at the last, so that the great advances that have been made in recent years in drawing up the Draft Convention can, as I said here on 30 April, be translated into a document which governments can ratify. I can assure honourable members that the Government will do its best to keep them fully informed of developments on a matter of such importance to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-The statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) is important. He referred to the long history of the Law of the Sea negotiations which have gone on for six years to eight years. Tremendous efforts have been made by over 150 countries to bring the negotiations to a successful conclusion. Yet, we find ourselves in this position, without any consultation, of the United States effectively stalling the completion of the Convention on the very eve of its success. We have to be very critical of this situation because the reason given was that the new Reagan Administration virtually wanted time to consider its position. In the process of so doing, the Administration also sacked all its negotiators. The point that ought to be emphasised is that these negotiations have been going on, as I said, for six years, seven years or eight years.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I gave notice of a motion which I hope we will pass. It related to the Law of the Sea and to the fact that we will want this House to say that the Australian people want the Convention adopted. We would like this to be done when the Tenth Session resumes in Geneva in August 1981. We want to do that to convey to the United States the views of the Australian nation. I add that a motion in similar terms was passed unanimously by the Canadian Parliament. I think that we can say on this matter that we have a bipartisan issue and that we want to see it carried into effect on the basis of Australia's fundamental interests. It is important. The Government should applaud our views on this matter. Australia has a lot of economic and strategic interest hanging on the successful conclusion of these negotiations. For a start, the territorial sea will cover 12 miles and not three miles, as is now the case. In addition, there will be a 200-mile economic zone which will give us effective, if limited, sovereignty over an additional million square miles of territory off the Australian coast which undoubtedly is rich in mineral, hydrocarbon and marine resources. It will guarantee freedom of passage for our merchant fleet and navy through international straits and archipelagic waters and it will provide for internationally regulated and ordered exploitation of the resources of the high seas and deep sea bed which will be not only to our advantage but also to the advantage of underdeveloped and poorer countries. There will also be protection and preservation of the marine environment.

The Opposition can think of nothing more important than that element. But, in the process of expressing our views, I advert to the fact that the Government has given away a lot of its national interest by legislating domestically in an area which I think might well tie the hands of our negotiators in the international conference if they are asked whether their own Government has passed legislation pursuant to its sovereignty virtually to give title for the offshore areas to the States. We are not here to berate the States but, if we are at a negotiating table, at least we ought to be consistent in our views. If, in the national interest, the Law of the Sea Convention is adopted speedily, for the reasons I have mentioned, how ridiculous we would look because the territorial sea for the first three miles would belong to the respective States and the next nine miles would belong to the Australian national government. That is how inconsistent our legislation is. In regard to the protection of the marine environment against dumping, there will be no legislation to restrict dumping outside the three-mile limit but if we adopt the Law of the Sea Convention we will not have that constraint. It is important that we clearly make the point now that, unless something is done urgently, we will face continual delay. There is some suspicion that the Reagan Administration deliberately decided not to go ahead with the adoption of the Convention because of certain financial interests in the United States which were concerned about a restriction on seabed mining.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oil companies.

—Oil companies. If that is the position, it is reprehensible conduct. We have to say so forcefully because, if 150 countries of the world can agree, why is it that the major superpower can say that it has to have another look at it? It does not help its own interests from the point of view of its leadership in the world and it will not engender support from many of the nations that have spent so much time trying to rationalise the many problems associated with these measures. We regard the whole of the Law of the Sea Convention as extremely important. Many of the world's resources are connected with the sea and difficult questions concerning the balancing of interests between national and international considerations must be resolved. We pay tribute to our own representatives who have played such a splendid part but we ask again: How tenuous is their situation if we have a divided national position and not a united international standing? In other words, we are saying internationally that we want the Law of the Sea Convention to give clear sovereignty to our Australian nation; yet, as I have said, in the process we have become prone to fragmenting the many parts of this Convention. A number of countries have three-mile territorial seas, a number have 12-mile territorial seas and a number vary considerably. The territorial seas of one country vary between three miles and 12 miles. One can see immediately that, if we are to talk about international control and the effective rationalisation of resources and their development, we should at least have a clear, unanimous decision such as we would have had if the United States had agreed to the most recent Convention. I say in the strongest terms possible, that, if the United States cannot see its way clear to agree to this Convention at the next sitting, it will be deemed to be one that should not be pursued any further. To delay it further would create the suspicion that it was not wanted in the first place. I think that would be quite a tragedy for the world and it would create serious difficulties for Australia and all other nations involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The purpose of this statement is not to announce a decision by the Government on Australian participation in the proposed force-Australia has still not yet formally been invited to participate in the force-but to set before the House the facts and information additional to that available when I last spoke on this subject on 14 May, and to indicate the issues which the Government will take into account in reaching a decision. Honourable members will be aware that the focus of Middle East peace negotiations over the last three and a half years has been the process begun by President Sadat when he visited Jerusalem and addressed the Knesset in November 1977. President Sadat's unprecedented and dramatic visit to Jerusalem led to negotiations between Egypt and Israel, with the United States also involved, which culminated in the Camp David Accords in September 1978 and the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty of March 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially the Camp David Accords and the peace treaty can be divided into two parts. The first dealt with the Israeli occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza and set out a procedure for implementing 'full autonomy' for the inhabitants of those two areas after the establishment of an elected self-governing authority. The Government regrets that progress on this aspect of the peace process has been disappointingly slow. Nevertheless this aspect of the peace process, while proving extremely difficult to implement, has helped to isolate the issues involved and has contributed to a greater understanding, by those outside the Middle East as well as those directly involved, of those issues. It must be emphasised that the undertakings concerning the return of occupied territory in the Sinai must be met if progress on these complex issues is to be made. The Government, for its part, believes that successfully carrying out the accords as they relate to the Sinai could be crucial in influencing those sections of the Arab world which have strong reservations about whether the complex problems of the Middle East can be resolved by means other than conflict.

Undoubtedly the major achievement of the peace process has been the bilateral peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. This has proved that Israel and an Arab country, despite 30 years of bitterness and war, can negotiate a substantive peace agreement involving basic concessions on both sides. There is no doubt that as a result both Israel and Egypt have received substantial benefit. Israel's security interests have been enhanced substantially while Egypt has regained a good part of the Sinai and is now able to concentrate on domestic economic reconstruction. This is a significant achievement and must not be put at risk. Progress on the second part of the accords, the bilateral aspects of the peace treaty, has been good. Diplomatic relations have been established, Ambassadors exchanged and civil aviation, commercial, telecommunications and other links have been established. In addition, and most importantly from the Egyptian perspective, Israel has withdrawn from approximately two-thirds of the Sinai. Egypt now controls all of the Sinai west of an interim line running from El Arish in the north down to Ras Muhammed on the southern tip of the Sinai. Annex 1 of the peace treaty stipulates that Israel will complete its withdrawal from the Sinai 'not later than three years from the date of exchange of the instruments of ratification of this treaty'. Hence by the end of April 1982 Israel is scheduled to have withdrawn completely from the Sinai. It is quite clear from the text of the treaty that Egypt, Israel and the United States envisaged that United Nations forces would supervise both the Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai and the implementation of the security arrangements agreed on in the treaty. Article VI of Annex 1 stipulates the role and functions of such United Nations forces.

Since the signing of the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty in March 1979, the United Nations has been unable to give any mandate which would enable UN forces to operate in a peacekeeping role in the Sinai. The United Nations Emergency Force-UNEF-which was carrying out peacekeeping operations in the Sinai ceased operations in July 1979 when the Soviet Union indicated that it would veto an extension of its mandate. Honourable members will be aware that an Australian helicopter unit was based at Ismailia as part of UNEF. The United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation-UNTSO-to which a number of Australian officers are seconded, still has about a dozen or so observers in the Sinai but could not be expected to assume the tasks of a Sinai peacekeeping force without a drastic revision of its mandate and a substantial increase in its numbers in the Sinai. Again it is clear that the Soviet Union, which has consistently opposed the Camp David Accords and the peace treaty, would not agree to an extension of UNTSO's mandate. In recent months there have been informal discussions in the United Nations about the possibility of obtaining a United Nations peacekeeping force to oversee the final Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai and to implement the peacekeeping functions as envisaged by the treaty.

On 21 April the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs of Egypt, His Excellency Kamal Hassan Ali, requested the President of the Security Council to initiate, as a matter or urgency, consultations with members of the Security Council. The purpose was to explore the role of the United Nations, and specifically whether the Security Council would monitor and supervise the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Egyptian territories, and participate in the reciprocal security arrangements through the establishment of the force and observers, provided for under the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. On 18 May in a letter to the Egyptian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Japanese President of the Security Council, Mr Nisibori, replied to the effect that following consultations with individual members of the Security Council, including the Soviet Union, the members of the Security Council were unable, for various reasons, to reach the necessary agreement to facilitate the withdrawal of the Israeli forces and to participate in the security arrangements provided for in the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the letter from the Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Kamal Hassan Ali, to the President of the Security Council and the President's reply to the Egyptian Minister.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
Following are the texts of the Egyptian letter of 21 April to the Irish president of the Security Council and of the reply dated 18 May from the Japanese president of the council:
Begins:
18 May 1981 Excellency,

With reference to the letter dated 21 April 1981 from your excellency addressed to the president of the Security Council for the month of April, I should like to inform your excellency that the individual consultations I have undertaken lead to the conclusion that the members of the Security Council are unable, for various reasons, to reach the necessary agreement on the proposal contained therein.
Accept, Excellency, the assurances of my highest consideration.
MASAHIRO NISIBORI President of the Security Council His Excellency
Mr Kamal Hassan Ali
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister
for Foreign Affairs of the
Arab Republic of Egypt
Cairo (Egypt)
21 April 1981 Excellency,
Upon instructions from my government. I have the honour to bring to your attention a matter which is directly related to the maintenance of peace and security in the Middle East region.

Ever since the inception of the United Nations, the organization has been called upon to ensure the maintenance of peace and security in the Middle East. At this time, when serious attempts are being made to bring the Middle East closer to a comprehensive peace, it is legitimate to expect that the United Nations, particularly, the Security Council whose primary responsibility is the maintenance of international peace and security, should continue its established practice in undertaking its constructive role to ensure the durability, and consolidation of peace and security in the Middle East.

The Security Council was seized with the situation in the Middle East since armed hostilities erupted, on November 22, 1967 the Council unanimously adopted resolution 242, a resolution which is considered the universally agreed basis for a just and comprehensive settlement to the Middle East problem. Security Council Resolution 242 (1967) required that the establishment of a just and lasting peace in the Middle East should include the application of both the following principles:
Quote: (1) withdrawal of Israel's armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict.

(2) termination of all claims or states of belligerency and respect for and acknowledgement of the sovereignty, territorial integrity and political independence of every state in the area and their right to live in peace within secure and recognised boundaries free from threats of acts of force. unquote . . .
The resolution further prescribed, as security arrangements:
. . . guaranteeing the territorial inviolability and political independence of every state in the area through measures including the establishment of demilitarized zones . . .

In accordance with this resolution, the Secretary-General appointed a special representative to promote agreement and assist efforts to achieve a peaceful and acceptable settlement. Towards this end, the special representative submitted, on February 8th 1971 an aide memoire, to Egypt and Israel. The aide memoire called upon Egypt and Israel to enter into a peace agreement as a first step towards a comprehensive settlement of the Middle East problem. Such an approach was endorsed by the general assembly with increased majorities when it adopted resolutions 2799 (XXVI) and 2941 (XXVII).

In this context, Egypt and Israel concluded a peace treaty on March 26th 1979 and registered it with the Secretary-General on 15 May 1979 in accordance with article 102 of the charter. Consistent with the underlying principles and basic provisions of security council resolution 242 (1967) the treaty stipulated that Israel will withdraw its armed forces behind the international boundary between Egypt and Israel by April 1982. Within this context and to ensure the durability and further consolidation of peace and security, Egypt and Israel agreed to reciprocal security arrangements and a request that the United Nations provide forces and observers.

In the light of the above, the government of the Arab Republic of Egypt views it timely for the Security Council to consider, on an urgent basis, the modalities for carrying out the required responsibilities for ensuring peace and security in the Middle East.

Towards this end, my government has instructed me to approach your excellency, with a view to consulting the members of the Security Council in order to ascertain the role of the United Nations, and specifically whether the security council, would undertake to facilitate the withdrawal of the Israeli forces from Egyptian territories and to participate in the reciprocal security arrangement herein referred to through the establishment of the force and observers provided for in the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.

In this connection, it may be important to confirm that Egypt's request emanates from its solemn commitment to the principles of the charter of the United Nations, from a deep conviction that the presence of the United Nations is the most appropriate formula for ensuring the maintenance of peace and security, and that this request falls within its sovereign rights in liberating its territories and pursuing a policy aimed at establishing a just, comprehensive and lasting peace in the Middle East.

As we have been conducting informal consultations with Security Council members for several weeks, I would appreciate receiving at the earliest possible date, the results of your excellency's consultations.
Accept, Excellency, the assurances of my highest consideration.
(Signed) KAMAL HASSAN ALI Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Arab Republic of Egypt His Excellency
Mr Noel Dorr
President of the Security Council
Unitel Nations, N.Y. 10017

TALK.START.PARA: —I deeply regret that the letter of the President of the Security Council effectively rules out, for the immediate future at least, any United Nations involvement in the withdrawal of Israeli forces from the Sinai under the terms stipulated by the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. United Nations involvement in this crucial area is therefore not an option. The House will be aware that Security Council Resolution 242, which was agreed on after the 1967 Middle East war, called for an Israeli withdrawal from occupied territories. Egypt has expressed the hope that a non-United Nations multinational force will only be of a temporary nature and that the way should be kept open for its replacement by a United Nations force at a later stage. Against the possibility that the United Nations would not agree to fulfil the role envisaged for it, President Carter in letters dated 26 March 1979 to both President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin undertook, and I am quoting directly, 'to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force'. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letters from President Carter to President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
THE WHITE HOUSE
Washington
26 March, 1979 Dear Mr President:
I wish to confirm to you that subject to United States Constitutional processes:

In the event of an actual or threatened violation of the Treaty of Peace between Egypt and Israel, the United States will, on request of one or both of the Parties, consult with the Parties with respect thereto and will take such other action as it may deem appropriate and helpful to achieve compliance with the Treaty.
The United States will conduct aerial monitoring as requested by the Parties pursuant to Annex I of the Treaty.

The United States believes the Treaty provision for permanent stationing of United Nations personnel in the designated limited force zone can and should be implemented by the United Nations Security Council. The United States will exert its utmost efforts to obtain the requisite action by the Security Council. If the Security Council fails to establish and maintain the arrangements called for in the Treaty, the President will be prepared to take those steps necessary to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force.
Sincerely, JIMMY CARTER His Excellency
Mohamed Anwar El-Sadat,
President of the Arab Republic of Egypt
THE WHITE HOUSE
Washington
26 March, 1979 Dear Mr Prime Minister:
I wish to confirm to you that subject to United States Constitutional processes:

In the event of an actual or threatened violation of the Treaty of Peace between Israel and Egypt, the United States will on request of one or both of the Parties, consult with the Parties with respect thereto and will take such other action as it may deem appropriate and helpful to achieve compliance with the Treaty.
The United States will conduct aerial monitoring as requested by the Parties pursuant to Annex I of the Treaty.

The United States believes the Treaty provision for permanent stationing of United Nations personnel in the designated limited force zone can and should be implemented by the United Nations Security Council. The United States will exert utmost efforts to obtain the requisite action by the Security Council. If the Security Council fails to establish and maintain the arrangements called for in the Treaty, the President will be prepared to take those steps necessary to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force.
Sincerely, JIMMY CARTER His Excellency
Menachem Begin,
Prime Minister of the State of Israel

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been suggested that the formation of such a force is not a part of the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty accords. Nothing could be further from the truth. President Carter's letter is and remains an essential document accompanying the peace treaty ratified by both Egypt and Israel. The failure of the United Nations to fulfil the role envisaged for it in the peace treaty represents the basis for the current endeavours by Egypt, Israel and the United States to fulfil their obligations to the peace treaty through the establishment of an alternative multinational peacekeeping force.

SPEECH.PARA: In the absence of any effective United Nations peacekeeping force the United States concluded an agreement in September 1979 with both Egypt and Israel on interim arrangements in which the already existing Sinai Field Mission, which is an American establishment, staffed by American civilians, would continue its monitoring functions in the Sinai. The Israelis whilst agreeing to these arrangements made it clear that they were acceptable only in the interim period while they still had a substantial force stationed in eastern Sinai. It is essential that the Parliament understands that Israel regards the establishment of an effective peacekeeping force as an integral part of the Treaty, indeed as an essential prerequisite for their final withdrawal from the Sinai.

Put bluntly, in the absence of United Nations involvement, failure to form an effective multinational force would risk provoking a refusal by Israel to withdrawal from the final third of the Sinai. The consequences of such a refusal cannot be overemphasised. It would be a very severe, if not catastrophic, blow to the Camp David peace process and the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. Beyond this, and in the absence of any progress on the crucial Palestinian issue, it could imperil future prospects for attaining a comprehensive, negotiated peace in the Middle East. Further, It would seriously dent the faith of two nations which, after decades of conflict and death, have deliberately chosen the path of peace through negotiation and compromise as an alternative to mutually ruinous conflict.

The fundamental reason why Israel agreed to withdraw from the Sinai was that a satisfactory set of arrangements to guarantee its security had been agreed upon. These arrangements quietened Israel's legitimate fears about its security and gave it the confidence to take the decision to withdraw. With an effective peacekeeping force in place in the Sinai, Israel's southern flank will be secure. It is the Government's hope that in these circumstances the Israelis would move with greater confidence to negotiate on outstanding issues affecting the future status of the West Bank and Gaza, including the right of the Palestinian people to a homeland.

Since President Sadat's visit to Jerusalem in November 1977 he has pursued bold and imaginative policies in the cause of a negotiated settlement with Israel. Any failure to implement fully the provisions of the peace treaty could react adversely on Egypt's ability to carry out its commitments. Moreover, the uncertain and volatile situation in Lebanon reinforces the urgency of dissipating, by peaceful means, the atmosphere of suspicion and conflict which has dominated the Middle East for so long.

Amongst the factors which will be taken into consideration by the Government if and when a formal approach is made to Australia to participate in a multinational peacekeeping force in the Sinai are: First, that Australia's overall interests are served by maintaining the momentum for the peaceful resolution of conflict in the Middle East. Secondly, the Government will need to consider the means available to maintain the momentum for peace. As I stated earlier, the inevitability of a Soviet veto has once again effectively removed United Nations involvement from consideration. Thirdly, is the proposed multinational peacekeeping force in accordance with the Camp David Accords and the spirit of United Nations Resolution 242, both of which enjoy the unreserved bipartisan support of this Parliament? Fourthly, can the Government support the formation of such a force? Finally, if Australia is formally invited to participate in such a force, are the conditions of participation such as to warrant consideration of Australia's involvement?

Australia has established a record of participation in international peacekeeping operations, both within and outside the United Nations context, which the people of Australia can be justly proud of. By their very nature peacekeeping operations involve risks. The safety of any Australian force associated with the proposed peacekeeping operation in the Sinai, as well as the possible effects on our overall interests in the Middle East, would weigh heavily in any deliberations by the Government. The factors outlined above accurately reflect the present level and current state of the Government's thinking. I emphasise again, as I did in my statement on 14 May, that any communications between Australia and the parties concerned can be described as being only exploratory at this stage. Even as I address the House today negotiations proceed between Egypt, Israel and the United States about the membership, structure and detailed functions of such a force.

In my statement to the House on 14 May, I said that the Government believes that such an exploratory approach is both justified and prudent in the present circumstances. It was in accordance with this exploratory approach that in response to an earlier message from the United States Secretary of State I wrote to Mr Haig, on 27 April. In my letter I pointed out that the Australian Government's preference remained for a United Nations peacekeeping force. I referred to allegations in the media in this country and the United States that the proposed multinational force would have a role beyond the Sinai itself. I also referred to speculation about the future use of air bases located in that part of the Sinai which Egypt is scheduled, under the terms of the peace treaty, to recover in 1982. I stated that it was important to dispel such suggestions.

I noted that before the Australian Government could make any commitment to participate in the force it would have to be assured that other participants would give the force a broad geographical and political balance. Moreover, I pointed out that Australia's relations with the Arab world will have to be taken into account. Whilst almost all of these governments have opposed the Camp David peace process they have not been opposed to all aspects equally. I said that the Government would welcome advice about the command structure of the force, its controlling authority and the proposed relationship between that authority and the force. I sought information about the financing of the force and asked for advice about the proposed duration of any commitment, mentioning that it would obviously be difficult for the Australian Government to consider an open-ended commitment. Finally, I mentioned that because the force would be operating on Egyptian and Israeli territory, any formal approach to Australia should be extended by those two countries.

As I stated earlier, it has become apparent from the information we have obtained that there are a number of aspects of the proposed multinational force on which final agreement has not yet been reached. Negotiations are still continuing, and whilst I understand that Egypt, Israel and the United States are close to agreement, the final details of the force are still to be concluded. I ask the House to keep this in mind.

On 19 May the Secretary of State replied to my letter and dealt with some of the general concerns and provided answers to some of the specific questions I had raised. Additionally, Australian officials both here and overseas have sought, and are continuing to seek further information concerning the proposed Sinai force. It is apparent from the Secretary of State's letter to me, that the United States Administration shares the Government's view on a wide range of issues related to the force. Like us, it believes it to be important that a sufficient range of countries participate to ensure that the force is not narrowly based politically or geographically. The United States believes that Third World participation is important. We understand that a number of countries from Asia and Latin America are currently being approached to consider participation and we expect states from other parts of the world, including Europe, to be invited in due course.

Secretary of State Haig has clearly stated that the only role of the proposed force is that of peacekeeping in the Sinai. He assured me that any contribution of the United States contingent is for the specific purpose of peacekeeping. Furthermore, the peace treaty states that the airfields in the Sinai will be transferred to Egypt for civilian use upon Israeli evacuation, and that these facilities will be under full Egyptian sovereignty and control. The mandate for the proposed force will be Article VI of Annex 1 of the peace treaty. The Government understands that details concerning the command and control arrangements, as well as the composition of the force including its civilian elements are still being negotiated. The Government will require further information on this aspect. This would include details concerning, for example, mechanisms for resolving disputes between the parties, and other aspects of co-ordination.

The parties are presently negotiating the establishment of a peacekeeping force of a size sufficient to carry out the functions agreed by Egypt and Israel. Precise details are being worked out at this time. As we understand current thinking, the force is likely to consist of about two thousand men. In addition to infantry battalions, it is envisaged there would be a need for support elements including logistics and communications units. One or more of these elements might be provided by one of the countries contributing to the infantry battalions, or they could come from different states altogether. As was envisaged in the peace treaty, it is anticipated that units of the force will be located in the north in the Rafah area and at Sharm Al Shaykh. The contingents would man check points and observation posts and operate patrols in Zone C as defined in the peace treaty. The observers would perform verification functions in Zones A, B and D.

The financial arrangements are yet to be finalised, although the hope has been expressed that those contributing states that are in a position to do so will contribute their services, or some part of them, free of charge. The duration of participation by contributing countries remains unclear. It is not expected, however, that national contingents will be required to serve indefinitely although there is likely to be a requirement that an acceptable force be maintained in the Sinai so long as either party believes it to be necessary. Current planning is based on the hope that various contingents would agree to serve for a specific duration.

As I mentioned earlier, the reaction of other Arab countries will also be important to us. Their major disagreement has been over the mechanism for solving the Palestinian issue which they regard as the core of the Middle East issue. They have not taken exception to, nor do they dispute, Egypt's right to regain its territory from Israel. This, I believe, is a major distinction when considering likely Arab reaction to possible Australian involvement in a multinational Sinai peacekeeping force.

In setting out the above details I have sought to give as full an account as possible of the current state of play concerning the proposed peacekeeping force. I emphasise again, that at this stage Australia has not been invited to participate and I have already referred to the negotiations which are still proceeding between Egypt, Israel and the United States. It is clear, nevertheless, that Australian participation would be welcomed by those countries and that it may only be a matter of time before a formal invitation is extended to Australia.

I believe it would be appropriate to make a further brief mention of Australia's interests in the Middle East. In my statement on 14 May I explained that whilst Australia has limited influence in that area our interest in the maintenance of stability in that region is not limited. The Government believes that this interest is best served by the process of agreement through negotiation and compromise rather than recourse to war. For many years Australia has had important links with the Middle East. These links included our dependence for many years on the Suez Canal as a major trade route to the Mediterranean and Europe. Thousands of Australians fought in Egypt, Libya, Palestine and Syria in two world wars in the cause of peace and, over the last 25 years thousands of migrants from Arab countries have settled in Australia in search of peace. In more recent times this country has contributed with distinction to peacekeeping operations under United Nations auspices in this region. An opportunity now exists for Parliament to express its views on whether Australia has a possible further role in the same cause. In this context I quote from the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) on 21 September 1978, Hansard page 1308, in which he said, inter alia:

Camp David has been a first step but a critically important one. President Carter's initiative in convening the meeting, and his political skill and courage in keeping it going, have created the essential momentum for the next steps, which may well be even more difficult. Our hope is that all the parties, and others who must necessarily become involved now, will maintain the momentum.
Further in his speech he stated:

The Prime Minister's statement on this matter is a carefully considered one, as is proper in such a complex, sensitive and important matter. I commend him for that and assure him, this House and the nation that on this great matter genuine concern for the achievement of lasting peace in the Middle East is a matter of bipartisan commitment.

In conclusion, I hope that, on such an important issue, the debate will be a well informed and rational one. The Government is hopeful that it will be possible to maintain a bipartisan approach towards the Camp David Accords, the Egypt-Israeli peace treaty and the need to maintain the momentum for peace in the Middle East. I present the following paper:
Sinai Peacekeeping Force-Australian Participation-Ministerial Statement, 26 May 1981.
Motion (by Mr Hodgman) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition notes the remarks made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). We wish to place on record the fact that we are of the opinion that a statement would not have been made at this stage if we had not raised this matter in recent weeks in this Parliament seeking information as to what transpired by way of negotiations between the Government and the United States. The Minister referred to the remarks made by my colleague, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) which are deemed to be, and were, supportive in 1978. We wish to make it very clear that the remarks made in 1978 were made in the context of what the Camp David Accords might have been expected to achieve. Obviously, the framework for the achievement of any solution in that area was with the United Nations Security Council acceptance of the Camp David Accords, and the approval of any force in that area by the United Nations Security Council, not only in accordance with the Accords but also in accordance with the treaty and the framework attached thereto. We can place on record that none of that has been achieved. It is a bit improper to suggest, by quoting the Leader of the Opposition's remarks out of context, that we can now say: 'There should be a bipartisan attitude in this matter'.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal at length with some of the matters. In fact, let me advert to remarks made at the time of the signing of the Camp David Accords. No Arab head of state supported the Camp David Accords or spoke out in support of Sadat. We also have the position, in accordance with the framework, that the factors to be taken into account, says the parties, are in accordance with Security Council resolutions 242 and 338 in all their parts. Those resolutions, as all honourable members know, relate to the fact that the question of peace and stability in the Middle East is to be under the control of the United Nations, and the United Nations Security Council in particular. In fact, the representative of the United Nations was to report periodically as to the progress of the peace negotiations and the peace implementations. Further, the Minister adverted to the Palestinian problem. Let me refer again to the framework for the Camp David Accords. It is stated:
Egypt, Israel, Jordan and the representatives of the Palestinian people should participate in negotiations on the resolution of the Palestinian problem in all its aspects.

Is it not a fact that the Minister's statement raises many more questions of a very serious nature than it purports to answer? Let me deal with them. I refer to the question of the United Nations participation in the Middle East. When I raised the matter in this House and subsequently in statements outside the House, I referred to the importance of the fact that the Camp David Accords of 1978 and the peace treaty of 1979 clearly specified that the United Nations was to play a role. Even more than that, Article VI, paragraph 8 of Annex 1 of the peace treaty unequivocally stipulated that the United Nations force could not include permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, that is, it could not include troops from either of the super-powers-in other words, troops from the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics were barred. I believe it is abundantly clear that adequate efforts have not yet been made to secure a United Nations force and that there is still a great deal of room for positive diplomacy in which Australia should actively participate.

The Minister made reference to such efforts. Let us have a look at the facts. The Minister said that there had been informal discussions in recent months. We must ask why only in recent months? It is over two years since these agreements were concluded. In terms of concrete moves in the United Nations, the position is even worse. Let me emphasise this point. The best that the Minister could do was to refer to approaches made on 21 April, a few weeks ago, and on 18 May, a few days ago. Those are the only approaches made to the United Nations. This is incredible!

Are we really being told that formal approaches were made only in the last couple of weeks to have the United Nations participate in the major role which was clearly envisaged for it some two years ago? I am aware of the earlier efforts of the United Nations Emergency Force-UNEF-and the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation-UNTSO. I am also aware of the role which has been played in southern Lebanon by the United Nations International Force in Lebanon-UNIFIL.

When we talk about Lebanon, let us place on record that it is only a matter of miles away from this area with which we are concerned. There is the greatest hostility there. The Lebanese community in Australia is divided on the basis of war taking place around Beirut, the problems of the Syrians and their missiles and the question of the Israeli's suggesting that they will take immediate action against the missiles. This is all taking place a matter of a few miles away from the area we are talking about. The point I am making is that the international community, including Australia, should make every effort to secure United Nations participation in the present phase, if that is at all possible.
