Let us have a look at the Camp David Accords of 1978 and this suggestion of President Carter's letters being part of the 1979 treaty. If we look closely at the Camp David Accords we realise several things. In the Minister's speech he quoted President Carter as undertaking:
. . . to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force.
That was done by way of a letter of 26 March 1979. The Minister might also have quoted the preceding sentence which committed the United States to:
. . . exert utmost efforts to obtain the requisite action by the Security Council.
I believe that there is room to do this. Australia should independently be exerting efforts in that direction.

What is more important is the question of the relationship of the letter to the treaty and the Accords. I do not think the Minister is well advised in this matter. He said that the establishment of an American led force is 'part of the peace treaty and accords'. It is not. It is very clear, if we look at the Accords and the treaty, that it is prohibited.

Firstly, I make the point that, whilst the letter was written on the same day the peace treaty was concluded, it is in no way a formal part of the treaty. Secondly, and more importantly, we cannot have an ancillary document to an international treaty which contradicts the treaty and still claim that it is part of the treaty. Let me repeat that Article VI paragraph 8 of Annex 1 of the treaty provides for the forces to be drawn from countries other than either of the super-powers.
Further, and equally importantly, Annex 1 continues:
The parties have agreed as follows:-

With respect to the provisions of paragraph 8 Article VI of Annex 1 if no agreement is reached between the parties they will accept or support a United States proposal concerning the composition of the United Nations force and observers.

But the letter contradicts the treaty on both points. It not only envisages a non-United Nations force but also a force led by the United States-one of the super-powers. Everywhere we look-in the 1978 Camp David Accords, in the 1979 peace treaty and in Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338-the reference is always to a United Nations force.

Thirdly, the Minister claims that President Carter's letters are essential documents accompanying the Egypt-Israel peace treaty. This is not the case. There is no evidence for that claim; indeed, there is evidence to the contrary. The treaty states that the papers which are attached to the treaty are protocol, annexes and maps. It in no way refers to letters-in particular, the Carter letters to President Sadat and Mr Begin. Those letters are clearly not part of the treaty. Therefore, there can be no reliance placed on them by this or any other government as a legal basis for supporting a non-United Nations force.

The key point in the Minister's statement comes at page 14 of his advance text. The Government's case in making a decision to contribute to forces to Sinai will have to rest on this point, but the point is false. The Minister says that the mandate for the proposed force will be Article VI of Annex 1 of the 1979 Egypt-Israel peace treaty. In fact, there is no mandate in that article for anything but a United Nations force.

One can read and re-read Article VI and read and re-read the peace treaty and the Camp David Accords. In Article VI, which the Minister claims to contain a mandate for a non-United Nations force, there is no mention of anything but a United Nations force. There are nine paragraphs in Article VI. In those nine paragraphs there are no fewer than nine references to a United Nations force. There is no reference whatsoever to any other force but a United Nations force. There is not one sub-clause which does not refer specifically to such a force. How then can the Minister claim that Article VI of Annex 1 of the treaty is a mandate for the proposed force? In fact, there is no mandate. If there is no mandate the Minister should admit it. It is irresponsible to claim a mandate where it does not exist. It is misleading to claim a mandate when none exists. It is misleading this House and the Australian people to claim a mandate where none exists.
I refer to the attitude of the Arab world and west European countries. The Minister said in his statement:

The Government, for its part, believes that successfully carrying out the Accords as they relate to the Sinai, could be crucial in influencing those sections of the Arab world which have strong reservations about whether the complex problems of the Middle East can be resolved by means other than conflict.

I do not think that is a fair statement. Firstly, it implies that those sections of the Arab world which have strong reservations about the Camp David Accords believe that armed conflict is the only solution. That is just not true. That it is not true is amply and dramatically illustrated by the fact that the Western European allies of the United States are searching at this very moment, and have been for the last 15 months, for an alternative to the Camp David Accords because they believe that the Accords do not provide a realistic answer. To put it at its lowest, there are very serious questions not only in the majority of the Arab states but also in the capitals of Western Europe about whether the Camp David Accords any longer provide a realistic solution.

As to the attitude of the Australian Labor Party, after the conclusion of the Camp David Accords the Australian Labor Party conference welcomed the signing of the treaties as an important step in the search for a just, comprehensive and lasting peace. We emphasise the importance of United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338, which referred to the role of the United Nations. Further, we emphasised that both the Israelis and the Palestinians are entitled to independent states and homes of their own. The Labor Party welcomes steps towards peace in the Middle East, but we must be sure before we commit Australian troops that we are really involving ourselves in a process which will be constructive and not one that could easily heighten tension between the super-powers and the countries of the region and possibly drag Australia into the maelstrom of fighting in the Middle East.

The Minister claimed that the Government has made no decision. It is quite clear from his statement that, as was the case with Vietnam, this Government is anxious to get involved. Let me point out to the Minister the sort of public reaction any decision to send Australian troops to the Middle East is likely to receive. Editorial writers and commentators in at least six of the largest newspapers have spoken directly or indirectly against this venture, and I suggest that they are espousing the views of the Australian people, irrespective of their politics. They are conservative newspapers and commentators who in the past have supported the overseas adventures of conservative governments. This time they are showing that, unlike the Government, they have learned from past mistakes. These leaders and shapers of public opinion include the Age, which has pointed out:

. . . all of Egypt's fellow Arab nations are opposed to the Camp David pact and that many of the Europeans see the Accords as bankrupt and inadequate to the task of moving towards comprehensive peace.
The Canberra Times stated:
There is no good reason why Australian forces should go all the way to the Middle East just to prove that this country is an ally of the United States.
It added:

Australia ought not to encourage Washington to think that it may be able to assemble under its own sponsorship an international force which is independent of the UN. Australian policy should work independently for the UN force which the Egypt-Israel treaty envisaged.
In the Sydney Morning Herald, Mr Guy Harriott said:
I think we should not touch the Sinai force with a forty foot pole. It is simply too much of a risk.
Mr Harriott added:

South East Asia is within Australia's sphere of direct interest; the Middle East is not . . . I thought that argument had been settled in the early 1950s when Menzies was reluctantly forced to concede that Australia's strategic concern was no longer primarily with the Middle East and the Suez Canel, but with our own region.

Many similar comments have been made elsewhere. I have quoted those today because they are sound and sensible expressions of view, and to warn the Minister of the cristicism he will face and the storm that will burst about him if his Government decides to send Australian troops to the Sinai. The Minister's statement shows that the Government is set on that course. In the 1960s and 1970s the rice fields and jungles of Vietnam proved to be a political and military quagmire for the United States and Australia. Why should we venture back into that quagmire? In the 1980s this Government again seems ready to risk the same sorts of difficulties.

The Minister indicated in his speech some of the factors that will be taken into consideration by the Government if a formal approach is made, and I should like to consider those for a moment. Firstly, he said that Australia's overall interests should be served by maintaining the momentum for the peaceful resolution of the conflict in the Middle East. The Labor Party agrees, but we believe that we must be extremely careful about the vehicle we choose before we become involved. The Minister went on to refer to the Camp David Accords and United Nations Resolution 242. I have already pointed out that those documents refer only to a United Nations force. The Minister asked: Can the Government support the formation of such a force? (Extension of time granted). I suggest that on an issue of such importance to the country, and given our tragic history of involvement with the United States in Vietnam, a more appropriate question would be this: Can the Government and the Opposition support the formation of such a force? Let us consider Namibia. Already we have committed a peacekeeping force of some 300 in what we hope will be the resolution of the dispute between South Africa and the South West African People's Organisation. The Government has not yet explained how we will discharge both obligations, and again I come to the point that both forces will be far from our shores and, apparently, under somebody else's command. At the same time, we are pulling out our forces at Butterworth and apparently rationalising our military commitments in the immediate region.

In conclusion, I have made it clear that the Labor Party has a sincere and fundamental commitment to peace in the Middle East on the basis of involvement of the United Nations, as envisaged in the Camp David Accords, and with due regard to the principles laid down in United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 238. I have also made it clear that the proposal being considered by the Government cannot be said, from the point of view of either international law or political reality, to be in any sense a proposal which involves the United Nations. The Opposition believes that in these circumstances the proposal is fraught with danger and may well contribute to the escalation of tension in the Middle East rather than to a real solution of the problems of that tortured region.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Leader of the Opposition claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) in his statement to the Parliament some minutes ago quoted extracts from a speech I made in this Parliament in September 1978-nearly two years ago-at page 1308 of Hansard. They were comments of a somewhat hopeful expectation on the basis of the outline of the Camp David Accords as we understood them and, more particularly, in terms of the actual Accords as we were made aware of them. I shall not go over the ground that has been well developed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen). I shall refer merely to Article 6, which exclusively develops a series of points. Essentially, they boil down to the joint commitment between Israel and Egypt that the disengagement, the settlement, will be based on United Nations involvement, United Nations forces. At that time we certainly were not made aware of any unilaterally provided letter by the United States of America. However, in that respect the point should go on the record that the Camp David Accords are between Israel and Egypt and do not concern the United States, which was only a witness. A letter from a non-party to an agreement can scarcely be regarded as forming part of that agreement in the legal sense. I do not wish to dwell on that any further.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I wish to make is that I am concerned about the condition of the Camp David Accords. I believe that they are sagging badly and are in danger of imminent collapse because of the poisoned atmosphere in relation to the West Bank and Gaza, which has been contributed to by the policies of the Begin Government. Since the signing of the Camp David Accords 39 settlements have been established in the area. I conclude by quoting the words of Agriculture Minister Ariel Sharon, which appeared in the Washington Post on 28 September:

You just can't do anything about it any more. That is why it is impossible any more to talk about the Jordanian option or territorial compromise. We are going to leave an entirely different map of the country that it will be impossible to ignore. I don't see any way any government will be able to dismantle the settlements of Judea and Samaria.

Therein lies the nature of so many of the difficulties with which we are confronted and the reason for many of the reservations which have been expressed not only by the Opposition but also, I believe, by every editorialist who has written on this subject and, from what I can see, the informed commentators too. It is a shame.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy Speaker:

SPEECH.PARA: The standard of health of Aboriginals is far lower than that of the majority of Australians and would not be tolerated if it existed in the Australian community as a whole.

This is the main finding of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs in its report on Aboriginal health. The same message comes through in two other reports now before the Government: The National Trachoma and Eye Health Program and the Government's own program effectiveness review on aboriginal health. Both show that the health of Aboriginal Australians is unacceptably low. The Government agrees with this assessment and reaffirms its objective of raising the health status of Aboriginals to that of the rest of the community. The hard fact is that while we have channelled many millions of dollars into Aboriginal health and health-related programs, and in spite of all our efforts-and despite some improvements which have occurred-the level of Aboriginal health is still unacceptable.

Whilst there have been some improvement in the health status of Aboriginals, health services alone cannot provide the solution for all the problems nor are they the responsibility of any one government. The problems will have to be overcome by a co-operative and co-ordinated effort involving many arms of the Commonwealth and State governments as well as Aboriginals themselves and their representative organisations. It is important that we look at what we are doing and ensure that we are not just providing services and nothing more. We must evaluate existing programs to ensure that they are directed towards, and actually do result in, an improvement in Aboriginal health and social well-being. To this end, Commonwealth support for Aboriginal health programs will be made conditional upon a set of specific goals and objectives which include Commonwealth Aboriginal affairs policy, being drawn up for each program, against which its attainment can be measured.

The Government has received timely offers of assistance from professional health organisations. The Royal Australasian College of Physicians, whose members have undertaken much of the original research on respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, metabolic and paediatric problems among the Aboriginal population, considers that Aboriginal health is a major social issue in which its involvement could be increased. The Australian Medical Association has also expressed its concern and offered assistance. The Government appreciates the interest shown by these and other professional bodies and intends to pursue the offers, particularly in relation to evaluating health services to Aboriginals.
The Reports

There have been numerous reports on Aboriginal health. They have all painted much the same picture. I turn now to the background of the three reports which the Government has considered. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs received references on Aboriginal health from the House of Representatives on 1 December 1976 and 10 March 1977. On 16 March 1978 the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Ian Viner, gave the Committee its terms of reference. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted
The document read as follows-
House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs Terms of Reference-Aboriginal Health
(1) Examine the health problems of Aboriginals with particular attention to-
(a) the prevalence of different types of disease suffered by Aboriginals and Aboriginal communities;
(b) the relationship between Aboriginal health and environmental, social and cultural factors;
(c) the effectiveness of existing health care programs for Aboriginals generally, and the adequacy of Western European-type health services to cope with the health problems of Aboriginals; and
(d) alternative methods of health care delivery that take account of Aboriginals' lifestyles, including camp situations.
(2) That the Committee consider ways and means by which-
(a) persons with appropriate qualifications can be encouraged to assist Aboriginals achieve a better standard of health, and
(b) Aboriginals including traditional healers can participate in the development and delivery of health care services to their own communities, and in any modification of existing services.
(3) That the Committee recommend possible courses of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Having taken evidence through submissions, public hearings and community visits, the parliamentary Committee presented its report on 20 March 1979. The trachoma report was prepared by the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists. It describes the most extensive screening, diagnosis and treatment coverage of eye disease ever undertaken in this country. The field teams involved in the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program also detected and arranged treatment for a variety of other illnesses. The report was presented to the Parliament by me on 1 April 1980. A program effectiveness review was conducted by Commonwealth officials during 1980 to determine, as far as possible, the health status of Aboriginals and the effectiveness of current Aboriginal health programs and of other programs which affect Aboriginal health. The review team drew information about the programs from Commonwealth departments and took into account the findings of the two reports I have already mentioned as well as other related reports. The officials also visited Aboriginal communities and consulted with people directly involved in community-based health care programs. The officials' report was completed during 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: Main Findings of the Reports

These three reports are obviously interrelated and it is appropriate for the Government to consider them together in its response to the parliamentary Committee's report. They contain common fundamental concerns and recommendations but differ considerably in detail. We have, therefore, felt it necessary to give careful attention to the major themes of each and the various proposals advanced. The reports all confirm three things:

The unsatisfactory health status of Aboriginals; the urgent need to improve the environmental conditions affecting Aboriginals' health; and the importance of increasing Aboriginal involvement in the design, control and delivery of health care services.
Environmental Improvements

Each report referred to the need to increase efforts to improve the environmental conditions in which many Aboriginals live. Much of the ill health experienced by Aboriginals is directly associated with a substandard physical environment. The parliamentary Committee recommended that 'the highest priority be given and immediate action taken to provide clean and adequate water supplies to all Aboriginal communities'. The trachoma report found in rural Australia that when the hygiene of Aboriginals approached that of non-Aboriginals so did the prevalence rate of the diseases measured. So for those people living in unhygienic conditions it recommended that appropriately designed and equipped houses be provided and that houses should contain a water supply to cater for all necessary uses and should also have efficient water-based sewerage systems and garbage disposal facilities. The officials' report also recommended that greater priority be given to the provision of housing, water supply, sanitation and electricity.

The disruption of Aboriginals' traditional lifestyle has given rise to a number of widespread health problems, especially where Aboriginals have been obliged to live on reserves or settlements, camps, or in rural or urban areas, under conditions of poverty. The problems include poor water supplies, dangerous sanitary conditions, overcrowding and limited access to nutritious food. The spread of illness and disease has been facilitated, especially respiratory, ear and skin infections, and intestinal parasite illnesses. The disruption of their society and lifestyles and its effects have also produced despair, chronic disadvantage and alcohol abuse. This situation is not amenable to short term solutions. Government programs over many years have sought to improve services and facilities in such ways as will encourage Aboriginals to assume responsibility for decisions about their lifestyles and their futures. The effort must be maintained and expanded while the problems remain as serious as they are.

Once preventive measures begin to take effect, succeeding generations will not be saddled to the same extent with the wide spectrum of diseases-eye, ear, respiratory, gastro-intestinal, skin, et cetera-that are less frequent in the non-Aboriginal population. Of course, in the meantime, health services play an important role by alleviating distress and improving the quality of life. It is our intention that all children, including Aboriginal children, will have a much better start to life than has been the case for so many in the past and which is so important in the long term for improved health status.

Aboriginals themselves have stressed the prime importance of adequate housing. That priority has been, and continues to be, reflected in the programs of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. For example, since 1975-76, the Government has provided $298.2m for Aboriginal housing, including hostels. During the last full financial year, 1979-80, 1,632 houses were built or purchased for Aboriginals and 205 home loans provided throughout the States and the Northern Territory with Commonwealth funds totalling $59.9m. The last Budget provided in excess of $72m for Aboriginal housing and accommodation. These substantial increases in funds for Aboriginal housing show how determined we are to respond to Aboriginals' own priorities.

The figures give the lie to uninformed claims that funds have been cut. The Government has considerably expanded funds for Aboriginal housing and accommodation even while these reports have been under consideration. Those increased funds are flowing into this priority area of need. We have not delayed action; we have accelerated it. Much remains to be done and we do not deny that. But the Government's achievements in Aboriginal housing are substantial and are growing each year. In fact, in some States, the time is now within sight when the housing backlog will have been overtaken.

Increasing attention is also being given, within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs allocation, to programs administered under the general heading of community management and services for municipal-type services to Aboriginal community organisations, reserves and settlements. Here our role has been essentially a topping-up of State and local government activities. However, the Commonwealth expects the States and the Northern Territory also to honour their responsibilities towards their Aboriginal citizens. Aboriginal people, like other citizens living in a particular State or Territory, are entitled to expect basic municipal services to be provided by State or local government. The Commonwealth has done much to help overcome past neglect, but it is not, and should not be regarded as, the only source of funds for providing services to Aboriginal people. Whilst we expect the State and Territory governments to take up this challenge, we understand that a special effort will be needed. That is what the Government had in mind in committing an extra $50m over five years for environmental health improvement.

I mentioned earlier that the efforts which have been made have not always been as effective as we would have liked. The Government is looking to shared funding arrangements under this program in a joint Commonwealth-State effort to eradicate at least the worst of the environmental conditions under which many Aboriginal communities in rural and remote areas live. Finding, storing and distributing clean water supplies and installing waste disposal systems are costly exercises. We must get our priorities correct and make sure that Aboriginal communities' priorities are fully known. The technology used must suit the community environment. Good planning here may take time, but it will pay off. It will be necessary to co-ordinate planning for the environmental improvements which are needed so that we can determine which projects should be funded under this program in terms of national as well as community priorities. The Commonwealth intends to discuss these matters with relevant State Ministers and with Aboriginal representatives. I expect that there will be a range of subsequent discussions involving officers. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has a regular program of consultation and co-ordination with State authorities and with Aboriginal organisations leading up to the preparation of its program for each financial year. At that Department's request, some proposals have already been identified for additional environmental health projects in the normal Budget process for 1981-82. Again, we have not waited or delayed action. The job is under way and we want to accelerate its progress, in co-operation with State and local authorities and with their financial support.

In considering projects for inclusion under the new program, we will be looking to concentrate the additional funds on those larger-scale water supply and waste disposal projects which have the highest priority of need but which are difficult for the Commonwealth or the States to accommodate in their normal ongoing budgets. Special needs arise in the increasing number of small outstation communities in traditional areas. It is not appropriate in these cases to provide permanent major capital works which would disrupt the preferred lifestyle. We are much encouraged by reports received that the health and well-being of Aboriginals at outstations is, on the whole, an improvement on the health of those people in the past. Nevertheless, the Government believes there should be adequate water supply and waste disposal to supplement the provision of basic services by members of outstation communities. With major works being undertaken through the Environmental Health Program, relatively minor works which are also of high priority will be able to be accommodated within ongoing programs, where increased emphasis is already being placed on such measures.
Aboriginal Involvement in the Planning and Delivery of Services

We know that conventional health services have real difficulties in winning the confidence of Aboriginal people. That confidence and familiarity are essential to effective and early use of health services. The reports before us all confirm that services which Aboriginals perceive as remote or impersonal have not been acceptable and therefore are not effective in tackling their serious health problems. Because non-Aboriginals share the culture and outlook of most health personnel and have a lifelong familiarity with the institutions and values of mainstream society, we find it difficult to understand the alienation of many Aboriginals. This is particularly true of our health system, which is strongly based on scientific research, institutional care and professional structures. I have not yet mentioned the daily reality and the historical experience of disadvantage, the evidence of which Aboriginals see all around them. What they see compounds the problems and makes our task in Aboriginal health a uniquely demanding one. We must do everything possible to strengthen Aboriginal responsibility and participation.

The Government therefore wishes to see, and will actively work towards, a marked increase in the degree of Aboriginal involvement in the control, management, design, delivery and evaluation of health care programs affecting Aboriginal people. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has been involved in supporting Aboriginal health care services through two channels: Assistance to the States to provide an adapted general service more appropriate to Aboriginal needs and more accessible by Aboriginals; and the funding of Aboriginal organisations to provide health services run and controlled by Aboriginals for Aboriginals. More recently, my own Department has also assisted some established Aboriginal medical services by payment of health program grants designed to meet salary costs of clinical staff. These services have tried to close the gap between the general medical services and the health needs of Aboriginals.

Whilst we want to encourage the development of programs which serve the whole community, rather than segregated services, our fundamental objective is the improvement of Aboriginal health, using the most effective means available. We will need to monitor carefully the impact of the Government's proposals on the effectiveness of the various means of service provision. There is not only a need for Aboriginals to be better informed about the availability of health services, to understand the services, to feel confident in approaching them and to feel at ease in using them, but also a very real need to improve the understanding and empathy of non-Aboriginal staff who supply the health services and control the facilities. Finally, the services must modify and adapt themselves to Aboriginal values and needs-we must not make the assumption that only Aboriginals must change.

The parliamentary Committee recommended that 'Aboriginal cultural beliefs and practices which affect their health and their use of health services . . . be fully taken into account in the design and implementation of health care programs'. The Government supports this view. The people best equipped to advise on relevant cultural beliefs and practices and the appropriate adaptation of health services are Aboriginals themselves. They are also best equipped to undertake important bridging roles in health service delivery. Their responsibilities in the health care services which they use must be rapidly expanded.

In supporting Aboriginal health programs, the Commonwealth will require greatly increased Aboriginal involvement in the design, control, management, delivery and evaluation of services. There is a need for the States and the Northern Territory to provide greater opportunities for Aboriginals to play significant and expanded roles. To achieve this goal, increasing numbers of Aboriginals will have to be trained for, and employed at, all levels. Aboriginals must also take a real and decisive part in policy and program decision-making. The way each State government meets this goal may be different. We are firmly committed, however, to ensuring that the goal is met, and we will be taking these questions up with State Ministers. In the same spirit, I should like to mention that some State colleagues with responsibilities in Aboriginal affairs have, in the past, expressed their concern that, in administering programs on behalf of the Commonwealth, they may not have enough flexibility. For example, they may wish to reallocate funds to reflect changing circumstances. The Commonwealth would be prepared to examine this problem with any of the States which wish to redirect priorities towards mutually-acceptable policy goals, and especially Aboriginal involvement.

It is unacceptable that, at the present time, there are no qualified medical practitioners of Aboriginal descent, and insufficient numbers of Aboriginal people qualified for other professional and para-professional roles. We propose to have discussions on a number of fronts to make sure Aboriginals have greater opportunities in these areas. It is vital that Aboriginal doctors, nurses, administrators, nurses' aides and other health care staff should be available. We acknowledge that the necessary education and training will take time. In the short term, however, we can also look at redefining existing practical responsibilities of Aboriginals presently employed in health care. Both the States and the Aboriginal medical services need to be involved in the provision of opportunities through the National Employment and Training System and other programs. Nor should the role of traditional healers, who are intimately involved in services in traditional communities, be overlooked. Opportunities must be found to make use of their particular skills, which can be built on or adapted according to circumstances. We shall continue to give strong support to the employment of Aboriginal health workers, who have important preventive and primary care roles to perform, now and in the foreseeable future.
Availability and Awareness of Choices

Most of us would take it for granted that we can choose the kind of health care we think appropriate. The parliamentary report makes it clear that more needs to be done to make a range of choices known and available to Aboriginal people. One difference between Aboriginals and other groups in Australia is that Aboriginal people are not fully aware of the range of health care options available. The parliamentary Committee recommended that 'Aboriginal communities be given the opportunity to determine the type of health service that will best suit their needs and available resources.' We endorse this view and commend it to State governments. The Government will propose to the States and the Northern Territory discussions between officials, and with Aboriginal people, on this matter of choice. These discussions will be looking for a co-operative basis for increasing Aboriginal awareness of the health service options and expanding the opportunities for Aboriginal communities to influence the types of services provided to them. This is a fundamental commitment and one which is supported by each of the reports on Aboriginal health to which I have referred. In fact, the Commonwealth and Victoria and Aboriginal organisations are now co-operating in a State government working party which has these very objectives. There is also scope for improving the relationship between general practitioners and Aboriginals, and increasing the use of primary care services by Aboriginals.

I mentioned before Commonwealth grants to Aboriginal medical services. These organisations provide primary health care services which are acceptable and accessible. Some of them have also begun to provide preventive services and ancillary programs in response to community needs, expressed through the close involvement of many Aboriginals in the services. The Aboriginal medical services are a fine example of Aboriginal initiative and of readiness to assume responsibility to improve their own health status. The Government endorses their valuable role in this field and commends also professional co-operation between Aboriginal medical services and State services so that their work is complementary. The Aboriginal and Islander Medical Service in Darwin, which is funded jointly by the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments and works in closely with existing health services, is a good example of what can be achieved through co-operation. The Government will be prepared to consider provision of assistance to similarly innovative approaches elsewhere.

We shall, of course, continue our existing support to Aboriginal medical services. We shall also consider, together with the States and Aboriginal people, the expansion of complementary community-based services where they offer the most effective form of health care, and work towards an expanded range of options for primary medical care. Aboriginals must be involved to the fullest possible extent in selecting the most appropriate health care options. This policy is consistent, the Government believes, with a cardinal principle of the Government's health policy, that people should have freedom of choice in an integrated and comprehensive system. That is something the Government wishes to see for all Australians, not the least of whom are the Aboriginal people.

The officials' report had proposed that future funding arrangements should be focused away from State programs to Aboriginal medical services. The proposal envisaged this being done at a predetermined rate or by reference to a set formula. The Government looked carefully at the proposal. We considered these issues when we were drawing up the new arrangements for general health care funding and administration. Conscious of the fact that many Aboriginals are dependent, to some extent, upon the States' general health care systems, we took the view that we should direct more effort into encouraging the States to involve Aboriginals in the planning and provision of all health services to their people. In the case of Aboriginal medical services, of course, this is already a settled matter.
Aboriginal Advisory Body

The Commonwealth, for its part, in demonstrating that Aboriginal involvement is so central to Government policy and so crucial to improving Aboriginal health, will seek ways of ensuring that it received the best possible advice from Aboriginals in relation to Aboriginal health matters. We acknowledge the advice that has been provided from time to time by the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, a federation of Aboriginal medical services. However, we also wish to have a more formal arrangement for advice on the whole range of health and health-related problems and needs, including medical needs. We shall therefore discuss, with the National Aboriginal Conference, arrangements to ensure that the Government receives appropriate and comprehensive advice about Aboriginal health, through the Conference. It would be fitting for the National Aboriginal Conference, as an all-Aboriginal elected body, charged with that responsibility of transmitting the views and advice of Aboriginals to the Government, to undertake this special task.

The parliamentary report recommended that a new unit be established in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It was proposed that a group of experts on middle level technology should be set up to advise on, amongst other things, the most practical means of providing communal and household facilities in Aboriginal communities. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs is essentially a policy co-ordination and funding body. It does not have specific functional expertise but rather draws on the resources of other departments or agencies when professional advice is needed. The same is true at the State and local levels. Where necessary, private consultants may be engaged. The Government considers, therefore, that it would not be appropriate or necessary for the proposed special group to be located within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

A second proposal was for an evaluation team to have responsibility for maintaining a check on the effectiveness of Aboriginal healtha care services and programs, and for the provision of standardised statistics on Aboriginal health. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has in its central office structure an evaluation branch, which conducts evaluations as an entity distinct from the rest of the Department. That branch will be able to participate, as it has in the past, in evaluation of programs and projects, in close consultation with Aboriginal people. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs will continue to draw on resources already available, including those in other specialist departments as the need arises in undertaking evaluations against defined objectives. It will be seen, therefore, that the objective of the Standing Committee is capable of achievement under present arrangements.
Aboriginal Health Statistics

The officials' report recommended that a national system of Aboriginal health statistics be developed along the lines proposed by Dr L. R. Smith. It recommended that the Department of Health allocate, as a matter of priority, the necessary resources for the system's implementation. The lack of a uniform, national data collection system, to provide an accurate measure of Aboriginal health status, is a deficiency which cannot be allowed to continue. In order to assess the effectiveness of Aboriginal health programs, including those which will take into account the measures I have outlined, it is essential that we measure Aboriginal health status on a uniform basis. As a matter of priority, I propose to implement a uniform system of national Aboriginal health statistics through the Department of Health. Such a system is absolutely essential for monitoring and evaluation of effectiveness. There have been discussions with State and Northern Territory authorities on this matter in recent years and the co-operation of the States and the Territory will lead to its speedy achievement.
Special National Programs

Finally, mention must be made of the valuable work done by the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program, undertaken by the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists. The report highlights many adverse conditions suffered by Aboriginals which both Commonwealth and State governments must rectify. It also graphically illustrates the relationship between environmental and other conditions suffered by Aboriginals and their health status. The Government supports the recommendations from the report for the continuation of the work commenced by the trachoma program and recognises that, without follow-up through both therapeutic and preventive intervention, much of the effort to date may be lost. We are, therefore, taking steps to ensure that the improvements in Aboriginal eye health achieved by the trachoma program are consolidated by means of effective follow-up and regular reporting.

Commonwealth officials and representatives of the College have met with Northern Territory and Western Australian authorities and the College is hopeful that a re-screening and minor surgery program will be commenced in the Northern Territory shortly. Similar meetings are proposed with other State authorities. This program, supported by the Commonwealth to the extent of some $2m, has shown us how much improvement can be made, given a concentrated effort. The three reports highlighted prevalent illnesses to which this approach would be suitable. A further group of illnesses, because of their chronic nature-for example diabetes-would need to be the subject of long-term care programs. The Government will investigate the need for additional funds for national programs which will have a special focus on prevalent illnesses. We wish to have the advice of Aboriginal people and of the States in determining the needs, appropriate programs and priorities.
Conclusion

The matters I have touched on represent the Government's general reactions to the many points made in the three reports. We are determined to play our part in bringing about a substantial improvement in the health of all Aboriginal Australians. As I said earlier, our long-term objective is to raise the level of their health to that of the Australian community generally. This aim requires the co-operation of the State and Northern Territory governments, with which much of the responsibility lies. Of equal importance is the co-operation of the Aboriginal people themselves. Action must be taken now to provide the training needed for Aboriginals to assume wider professional and semi-professional responsibilities in health services and also to expand the roles and skills of existing health workers. This is in addition to the contribution which Aboriginals can and now should make to the planning, administration and evaluation of such services.

We will be reporting to the Government in mid-1982. Therefore we propose immediately to open discussions with the States and Aboriginal organisations to explore ways of getting on with the job. While not denying the achievements to date, much still remains to be done. We are ready to play our part. I present a statement showing in detail the Government's responses to the House of Representatives Standing Committee's report on Aboriginal health. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES STANDING COMMITTEE ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS, REPORT, ABORIGINAL HEALTH
Government response to the Committee's Recommendations
Canberra, May 1981
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES STANDING COMMITTEE ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS
Report: 'Aboriginal Health'
Recommendations
Response/comment
The Physical Environment-
1. 'The highest priority be given and immediate action taken to provide clean and adequate water supplies to all Aboriginal communities.

Endorsed. In addition to the ongoing programs of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs which provide housing, water, sanitation and other community services, the Prime Minister announced in his election policy speech a commitment to provide an additional $50m over 5 years to meet highest priority needs for water supplies, sanitation and other environmental improvements.
2. 'A determined effort be undertaken to eliminate as soon as possible the unhygienic sanitary pan system in Aboriginal communities.'
Endorsed. There is a need to provide sewerage systems where these do not exist, and to ensure that the system provided matches the needs of the Aboriginal community.

3. 'An advisory group within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs comprising experts in middle level technology be established, and in consultation with relevant departments and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies to research various options for the provision of community and household facilities; consult with Aboriginal communities to assess their needs; advise them on the most appropriate facilities that best suit their needs; monitor implementation of its advice to communities; facilitate employment of technical advisors by Aboriginal communities; and report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.'

Professional advice on appropriate technology is available to Aboriginal communities and organisations from relevant Government departments and, where appropriate, private consultants. As far as possible, these arrangements are decentralised, to ensure their responsiveness to communities. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs does not itself provide professional expertise and would therefore be an inappropriate location for an advisory body on technology.
4. 'Priority for Aboriginals living in towns and moving into towns away from the fringes, be given to the provision of funds for meeting and upgrading their housing needs.'

Housing accommodation or shelter is a high priority for Aboriginals, not only for those moving into or living in towns. Existing policy affirms the importance of Aboriginal involvement in decisions regarding the number, location, design and arrangement of housing projects. Priority is currently given to the provision of housing for Aboriginals living on reserves.

5. 'The Department of Aboriginal Affairs consult relevant Commonwealth and State departments, local authorities and Aboriginal communities and organisations to define responsibility for safe water, public hygiene services, housing standards and inspection of premises in Aboriginal settlements and communities, particularly fringe camps.'

Endorsed. Such consultations will be part of developing a program for the expenditure of the additional funds committed by the Commonwealth for improvement of the physical environment of Aboriginal communities, as referred to in the comment in recommendation 1 above.
Cultural Factors-

6. 'Aboriginal cultural beliefs and practices which affect their health and their use of health services such as their fear of hospitalisation, their attitudes to pain and surgery, the role of traditional healers and the differing needs and roles of Aboriginal men and women be fully taken into account in the design and implementation of health care programs.'

Endorsed. Current policy supports the adaptation of services and programs to meet adequately the cultural beliefs and lifestyles of Aboriginals. The Government believes that the Standing Committee has correctly identified the major cultural factors affecting Aboriginal health. These will be specifically drawn to the notice of States and the Territory in the course of discussions on Aboriginal health program funding arrangements.
On Health Care Programs-
7. 'Savings to the State-funded health services which result from the Commonwealth-funded State Aboriginal preventive health programs be directed to the further development of preventive programs.'

The Committee's concern that State authorities should accept some financial responsibility for improving the health of Aboriginals is endorsed. The States have already been informed that the Commonwealth expects State Governments to provide at least a pro-rata share of general revenues for Aboriginals in their own programs and those supported by the Commonwealth, and to apply the 'priority of need' principle in all such programs. In the negotiations referred to in comments on recommendations 5 and 6, the matter of joint Commonwealth/State funding will be thoroughly discussed.

8. 'An independent evaluation team responsible to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs be established to evaluate the effectiveness of all Aboriginal health care services and programs in accordance with the World Health Organisation's definition of health and the principles of self-determination, and to establish suitable criteria so that standardised information can be collated and that funds be provided for the purpose where programs are funded by the Government.'

It is agreed that there is a need to standardise criteria for evaluation and to collate information. The Government supports reviews and assessments of Aboriginal health programs, and expects that their conclusions will be used in the modification of existing services and the development of new Aboriginal health services.

The idea of conducting evaluations against the World Health Organisation's definition of health and the principle of self-management is acceptable to the Government as a broad principle. The Government has reservations, however, about the usefulness of evaluations which are conducted without more specific terms of reference or criteria. These only provide evaluation criteria that are very broad and difficult to relate to the very large number of projects which may comprise 'all Aboriginal health care services and programs'.

A structure already exists within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to develop and co-ordinate assessments and program reviews. The Department has within its Central Office an Evaluation Branch which conducts evaluations as an entity distinct from the rest of the Department. The Committee's objective-the establishment of an independent evaluation team-is, therefore, capable of achievement under present arrangements. Aboriginals are to be involved in any evaluation.
9. 'The full range of choice of the various types of programs delivering health care to Aboriginals be maintained and, where appropriate, support increased.'
Endorsed. The degree of increased support will of course depend on available resources and on competing priorities in Aboriginal programs generally.

10. 'Aboriginal communities be given the opportunity to determine the type of health service that will best suit their needs and available resources and that a Task Force be established to place the full range of alternative health care services before them.'

The Government is committed to expansion of Aboriginals' involvement in all aspects of health services affecting them, including in the design, control, management, delivery and evaluation of health services for Aboriginal people. The Government supports the development or expansion of Aboriginal responsibility in relation to State Aboriginal health programs. The recent initiatives of the South Australian and New South Wales Governments in these aspects are examples. In the context of these developments, there is no need for a 'Task Force' approach. Nor does the Government see a centralised body as necessarily the best means of ensuring what the Standing Committee has in mind.
11. 'An inquiry be held into the implementation of the policy of self-determination as it affects community development.'

Not endorsed. The Government's policies aim at Aboriginal self-management and self-sufficiency. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs assesses, on a continual review basis, the impact of the Government's policies and programs in Aboriginal affairs on community development.

12. 'Aboriginals be involved to the fullest possible extent in all stages of the provision of health care services and that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs assess the number of Aboriginals required, the time it will take to train them to assume responsibility for the health of their own people and, to this end, develop, in consultation with relevant Ministers, suitable training programs.'

The principle that Aboriginals should be involved to the fullest possible extent in the provision of health care services for them is strongly supported. The Government also supports the provision of suitable training, whether academic or on-the-job, to ensure the greatest possible Aboriginal participation in health care for Aboriginal people. The Commonwealth has funded training programs for Aboriginal health workers in State Health authorities and stands ready to discuss new initiatives.

The Government is particularly concerned to see the development of Aboriginal health professionals-doctors, dentists, nurses and para-professionals. Special measures may be needed to encourage Aboriginal students to go on to such training and Commonwealth Departments will take what steps appear appropriate.

Beyond the measures needed to train and employ suitably qualified Aboriginal people as health professionals, there is also a need to employ Aboriginal people in administrative and clerical positions, at all levels in Commonwealth and State authorities which have responsibilities in relation to Aboriginal health. The Commonwealth Government has taken several steps to ensure these objectives are met and will commend a similar approach to the States.

13. 'Training hospitals for nurses, university medical faculties and other tertiary institutions introduce into their curricula, both at undergraduate and graduate level, a component which deals with Aboriginal health.'

Endorsed. Whilst some hospitals and medical faculties already provide courses or segments on Aboriginal health, there needs to be a concerted effort to ensure that Aboriginal health and related matters are adequately dealt with in medical training institutions. These proposals will be taken up and actively pursued with the Tertiary Education Commission and with appropriate medical learned societies.

14. 'Comprehensive orientation courses be conducted for all non-Aboriginal staff recruited to serve in Aboriginal communities before commencing duty, that they receive regular inservice training, and that a formal diploma or certificate be provided by a tertiary institution for professionals actively involved in providing health care to Aboriginals.'

Orientation and inservice training courses are already provided by most State and some Aboriginal organizations, but there is a need for more comprehensive and more regular training courses for non-Aboriginal staff. The proposal for a formal diploma or certificate course will be pursued in the discussions envisaged in relation to Recommendation 13.

15. 'Governments introduce special allowances and entitlements which recognise the unusual working conditions and the geographical, social and professional isolation experienced by personnel working in predominantly Aboriginal communities in remote areas.'

Health personnel already receive the general standard allowances paid in recognition of isolation and residence in a tropical climate, but they do not receive, in their conditions of service, acknowledgement of the special difficulties they experience. Consultation with the States, Northern Territory and non-government organisations will be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following paper:

SPEECH.PARA: Report of Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs: Government Response, Ministerial Statement, 26 May 1981.
Motion (by Mr McVeigh) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Motion (by Mr McVeigh)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Melbourne Ports speaking for a period not exceeding 28 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has taken the Government over two years to respond to the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs contained in the report on Aboriginal health which was tabled in this Parliament on 20 March 1979. It is interesting to note that the reference was given to the Committee by the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Chaney. As the report was directed to that Minister, I would have expected that a reply to the House would have been forthcoming from him. It is interesting to note that one of the implications that flows from the statement by the Government is that it now clearly sees problems of Aboriginal health not so much as the responsibility of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) but rather the responsibility of the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar). That is not a view shared by the Opposition. For that reason, I am the principal spokesman for the Opposition on this matter rather than the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett).

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of events following the tabling of the House of Representatives Committee report, two other reports have been made. A trachoma report was presented on 1 April 1980 and in late 1979 the Government established its own Program Effectiveness Review Task Force to report on Aboriginal health. The Government has been sitting on the recommendations contained in the effectiveness review report since early last year. I believe that it says something about this Government's view of open government that because the program effectiveness review recommendations do not comply with the Government's predetermined attitudes under Fraser federalism, the document is not before the Parliament today. It is really extraordinary to contemplate that the Government will take a House of Representatives committee report containing a large number of recommendations and refer it for review. There is nothing wrong with that. A great deal of work was done by the effectiveness review committee but having regard to the importance of this matter, on what basis is it the case that the conclusions of that review committee are not directly available to the parties and not even available to the members of the House of Representatives Committee that produced the report?

I wrote to the Minister seeking the comments of the review committee. They were not available to me, as they were not available, I suspect, to any other member of the Committee. In order to get my copy, I had to obtain it, as I suspect other members did, through a Government department leak. Why should a government which is genuinely concerned about Aboriginal health want to take that kind of secret attitude towards a further report which could only widen the nature of the debate, only make more information available to the House and only lead to put other recommendations which ought to be taken into account by the House in its concern to reach conclusions on this very important matter. For many Aboriginals in the community, this is not just a matter of Commonwealth-State relations or of supporting or opposing this Government. For many Aboriginals the kinds of recommendations in all the reports are very much a matter of life or death.

I believe the reason that the House of Representatives has to debate the Ministerial statement today without the benefit of the recom- mendations of the Program Effectiveness Review Committee is that the recommendations of the Minister involve a very considerable and important shift in the nature of traditional Commonwealth responsibility towards Aboriginal citizens. The House of Representatives committee in its recommendations saw Aboriginal health programs, their innovation and support as being a primary responsibility of the Commonwealth. Of course, in the report comments were made about State and local government. If one looks at the full thrust of those recommendations, one will see that at no stage did any member of that Committee consider that both innovation and support, were not prime responsibilities of the Commonwealth. That is as it ought to be. That stems from the result of the 1967 referendum and from the view put very succinctly, I believe, to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Having regard to the fact that this submission was put to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs one would be entitled to believe that that view also constituted the Government's view. I seek leave to incorporate that submission in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DEPARTMENT OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS
Submission to Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders [Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-management] Act
(a) whether the constitutional conception underlying the legislation and the principle and structure of the legislation are consistent with the proper responsibilities of the Commonwealth;

As a result of the referendum held in 1967, the Australian Constitution (section 51[xxvi]) now provides that the Parliament of the Commonwealth may pass laws 'in respect of people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make laws'. The States have concurrent power to legislate in this area but by virtue of section 109, Commonwealth legislation prevails over any inconsistent State legislation.

The Commonwealth Government's policy in respect of Aboriginal affairs calls for the creation of opportunities by which the Aboriginal community may exercise control over its own affairs. In pursuit of this policy, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has been encouraging the development of autonomous local Aboriginal community organisations which receive grant funds to enable them to carry out programs which will express and enhance their independence. Such assistance is a positive response to Aboriginal aspirations and without it the Aboriginal community and its individual members would remain dependent upon Government assistance indefinitely and have no opportunity to redevelop the necessary self-confidence to enable them to take their place as equals within the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly that view of constitutional responsibility is, as I have already said, the view of the Opposition. Having regard to the importance of this matter, I also seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter of concern written on 8 April 1981 by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) expressing his concern about Aboriginal health.
—Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr McVeigh

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, leave is granted, but common courtesy usually dictates that such documents be shown to us in plenty of time to allow us to peruse them.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
8 April 1981
The Rt Hon. J. M. Fraser, CH, MP
Prime Minister,
Parliament House,
Canberra, ACT 2600
My dear Prime Minister,
You will recall establishing the Program Effectiveness Review Task Force to examine various reports on Aboriginal health and health services.

Recent representations made to the Opposition have demonstrated that the Government has not met its promised commitments to Aboriginal health services, especially in respect of community-controlled, self-managed services, which are completely in accordance with the Government's stated policy of 'self-determination' for the Aboriginal people of Australia.

It is apparent that, due to the Government's 'New Federalism' policy and a desire to sharply reduce Commonwealth spending that the Commonwealth's responsibilities (following the 1967 Referendum) are in danger of being abrogated in favour of the States.
I now seek your unqualified assurance that it is not your Government's intention to shift responsibility for Aboriginal health funding wholly or partially to the States.
I seek this assurance in view of two recent developments, namely:

1. Strong pressures on Aboriginal health services to accept Health Program Grants (H.P.G.) from the Commonwealth Department of Health Community Health Division (in lieu of continued funding from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs); and

2. The establishment of the Aboriginal Development Commission (which of course, has been given responsibility for Aboriginal enterprises run for profit, but has no charter to provide funds for non-profit public services).
My attention has been drawn to the letter from the Director-General of Health to Aboriginal Health services (dated 17 October 1978, ref 78/11247) which stated quite clearly that:
1. the acceptance of HPG's would prevent the continuance of bulk billing by doctors employed by these services;
2. Aboriginal Medical Services would be given the option of accepting either bulk billing or HPG's; and
3. there would be no compulsion on any service to accept HPG's.

The Government is apparently still using the numerous reports on Aboriginal health which it has received ('Aboriginal Health', House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, 20 March 1979; National Trachoma and Eye Health Program Report, 1 April 1980; and the PER Report) to postpone adequate funding to existing services and new initiatives by Aboriginal communities in the area of health care delivery.

Recent and current Commonwealth funding has been provided solely for primary (clinical) health care and education. This has meant that any service wanting to provide preventive health care programs has been forced to rely on private donations from individuals and local and international aid agencies.
This is in direct contravention of the WHO/UNICEF 1978 Alma-Ata Declaration which, inter alia, recommended that:

'All governments should formulate national policies, strategies and plans of action to launch and sustain primary health care as part of a comprehensive national health system and in co-ordination with other sectors.'
The Alma-Ata Declaration also clearly defined the relationship which should exist between primary, preventive and other forms of health care delivery.
The other assurances which I also seek are:
1. The continued commitment of Commonwealth funding, via the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, to community-controlled Aboriginal health services; and
2. The continuation of current bulk billing arrangements for those services who choose to use them, without prejudice to their Grant-in-Aid from DAA.
Yours faithfully, BILL HAYDEN, M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter simply emphasises the concern of the Leader of the Opposition on behalf of the Opposition and emphasises the importance of the Commonwealth, through its constitutional and fiscal responsibilities, seeing that self-managed Aboriginal health programs receive an appropriate level of funding. I believe that the shameful aspect of the Minister's statement to the Parliament today is that whilst recognising the unsatisfactory health status of Aborigines, the urgent need to improve the environmental conditions affecting Aboriginal health and the importance of increasing Aboriginal involvement in the control and the delivery of health care services, at every point the Commonwealth's own constitutional responsibility and moral obligations to our Aboriginal people are demeaned and those responsibilities and duties are subjugated to an appropriate State area. To put it more bluntly, what this Government is about is turning Aboriginal health care initiatives back to the States even though the Minister and the Prime Minister know that at least two States are on public record as perceiving self-managed Aboriginal health services-to use their own term-as a 'form of apartheid'. It is interesting to note the kind of logical slide contained in the Minister's own statement. Whilst supporting the concept as stated on page 8 of his statement, he described those very services as 'rather than segregated services'. That is the kind of logical slide between the view of some States such as Western Australia and Queensland which seek self-managed Aboriginal services as a form of apartheid and the kind of term used in the Minister's statement. When comparing the range of services, he gives support to a generality of such services but uses the very interesting phrase 'rather than segregated services', in regard to self-managed Aboriginal services. More than two years ago the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs reported:

SPEECH.PARA: 'The level of Aboriginal ill-health will only be reduced if there are dramatic improvements in the physical environment, if there is maximum participation by Aborigines in all stages of the planning and delivering of health care'.
One year later the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program came to much the same conclusion, after practical experience in the field throughout Australia.

The Program Effectiveness Review Task Force reached the same conclusion. Therefore there have been three reports, two of them public and one wrapped in a cloak of secrecy, which all reached the same conclusion.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting, I was making the point that the ministerial statement on Aboriginal health involved the diminution of Commonwealth initiative and a shift in emphasis towards the States. It also involved a shift in departmental control from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the Department of Health. In order to centralise the Opposition's concern on both these points, I wish to move an amendment to the motion 'That the House take note of the paper'. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following words be added to the motion:
'and that this House reaffirms-
(1) the continuing constitutional responsibility of the Commonwealth to fund, and give continuing support to, the raising of the health standards of its Aboriginal people, and
(2) the continued commitment of Commonwealth funding, via the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, to community controlled Aboriginal health services.
I believe that amendment will give the House an opportunity to express itself in terms of the real issues that we believe arise from this ministerial statement.

The underlying theme of the statement-it runs throughout it-presupposes that there is complete accord between the States and the Commonwealth on the objective for administering health services for Aborigines. That is not the fact. I can do no better in order to give a graphic illustration of the facts than to relate the history of Professor Hollows and the work that he did in the whole trachoma area. Quite apart from the events of the last few days, I am certain all members of this House, as well as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, would acknowledge the very real task done on behalf of the people of Australia by Professor Hollows in dealing with the problems of trachoma amongst our Aboriginal people.

By the time that program was over, the team had seen more than 100,000 people, some of them several times. More than 15,000 Aborigines had participated in month long treatment programs and more than 1,000 people had had eye operations, some performed in mobile hospitals erected by the Army. Eight million pieces of information had been collected and a computer analysis of the results demonstrated conclusively the environmental base of the disease. As Professor Hollows pointed out in his report, Aborigines were living outside the reach of present health care delivery systems, even where such systems were present. He often saw million dollar air-conditioned hospitals and clinics in the middle of the squalor of the Aboriginal camps. Professor Hollows has said that Aborigines were still alien and remote from those services.

Professor Hollows' report, which was prepared for the Commonwealth Government, has been with the Government since April 1980. Since then the Department of Health has been trying to negotiate with the States the sort of continuing program that he called for. As the Minister for Health and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs would know, the States have not complied. They have not been prepared to co-operate and they have made it clear that, even where they accept the findings of Professor Hollows, they want to run the programs themselves, irrespective of the international repute and capacity of Professor Hollows and his team. Professor Hollows has stated that the States want to do more of the same; they want to carry out programs which do not work and which will not work, and to freeze out the vital ingredient in any health care program that is concerned to uplift the standards of our Aboriginal people, that is, the critical question of Aboriginal participation. That was his experience and none of those arguments-compelling arguments they were, extracted in the field by a noted Australian authority-has been dealt with or even referred to in the ministerial statement.

What does the Government's own bureaucracy say about Commonwealth-State attitudes to Aboriginal health? The program effectiveness review-whose report should have been in the hands of every parliamentarian in this House-was an internal review of the issues raised by both Professor Hollows and a parliamentary committee and referred to the critical question of Commonwealth-State co-operation in raising health standards. I wish to quote from this confidential document. It is no wonder that the Minister was not prepared to make it public. It shows the paucity, the mendacity and the nonsense which is involved in the ministerial statement. At page 14 of the review, carried out by departmental officers at the request of the Prime Minister, it is stated:

The States have adopted a different stance about Commonwealth responsibilities, based on their interpretation of the agreements-that the Commonwealth is predominantly responsible for financing Aboriginal health programs, that the States are responsible for health policy and planning and for the co-ordination of health services, and that the States' general responsibility for health should not be abrogated by the Commonwealth's Aboriginal health policies.

It is not clear how far the State authorities subscribe to the principle of Aboriginal self-management. Insofar as the principle may apply to States Grants programs, the States are adamant that policy, planning and management of health care must be undertaken by properly qualified personnel, and this tends to exclude Aboriginals because of their lack of training and particularly of formal qualifications.
So, the Government's own internal bureaucracy agrees with the very conclusions that Professor Hollows made in the field. It has summarised those conclusions on page 15 of this confidential report.

If members of Parliament want to get their hands on it and read it, they have to go cap in hand to the Press Gallery and say: 'Please, the Prime Minister regards this report as so confidential and so damning of his policies that we have to get it as if it had fallen off the back of a truck'. This policy document goes on to say:
The PER saw three main areas of policy difference existing between the Commonwealth and the States:
appropriate division of financial responsibility and the role of supplementary funding;
co-ordination of policy and planning; and
the emphasis to be given to Aboriginal self-management and the level at which Aboriginals should be involved effectively.
This report complemented and supplemented the report of the parliamentary committee; but, more important than that, it came out with very specific proposals. It recommended:

Effective Aboriginal involvement in developing and implementing health programs be a key factor. This would entail setting up a national Aboriginal health body responsible to the ministers for health and aboriginal affairs.
Where is that to be found in the ministerial statement? It continues:
That States be granted less funds and the Aboriginal run medical services be given much more.

It could not be any more specific than that recommendation that the States be given less funds and Aboriginal conducted services be given more. But, that is not the principle we find in this ministerial statement. Further proposals are:
That Aborigines be represented on hospital boards in areas with substantial Aboriginal population.
That more Aborigines be employed in training in the Aboriginal health field.
It goes on to say:
More than $62m is spent on Aboriginal health in general State programs, including hospitals, but the report--
This is the report of the Government's own advisers-
claims that this is 'not effective'.

It is not just a question of the proposals outlined by the Minister today being bad health policy. It is also a question of its being bad medicine.
