That is the reason this report has been buried and is not available directly to the Parliament so that it can form a consensus on it, so that it can go forward and deal with this critical problem, this matter of life and death which reaches right into every Aboriginal community in Australia.

The Government's own program effectiveness review has made it perfectly clear that the health status of Aborigines is still bad. The effectiveness and perpetuation of many current State-run programs is clearly open to doubt. It suggests that the Commonwealth, by funding the States in this way, is throwing good money after bad. It is interesting to note that the Minister, at page 11 of his statement, gives what he regards as the new model which the Government believes ought to be adopted. He said:

The Aboriginal and Islander Medical Service in Darwin, which is funded jointly by the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments and works in closely with existing health services, is a good example of what can be achieved through co-operation. The Government will be prepared to consider provision of assistance to similarly innovative approaches elsewhere.

I do not propose in the short time available to me to be overtly critical of that service. I simply say this: The Aboriginal community was not consulted on the establishment of that service. I also point out that it is odd that in this very lengthy and substantial statement which refers to effective Aboriginal health care models, the Minister said that the new structure operating in Darwin was an excellent working model, when the Aboriginal community was not effectively involved in the decision to establish it. Not once in this very substantial statement did the Minister indicate as an effective working model-I name only one of them-the health service conducted by the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress in Darwin. It treats 30,000 Aboriginal patients a year at a cost of $12.50 per patient. The spokesman for the Northern Territory Administration, Mr Tuxworth, said that the cost to the Territory in a Territory-run operation is $40 per out-patient service. Should not this Minister say that perhaps we ought to be going for the service that seems to be working, which has the confidence of the Aboriginal people and which, most importantly, can be shown by the Aboriginal people to be run with cost savings and more effectively than the glitter and show of large structures which often are built to perpetuate the view of the prevailing State bureaucrat?

I believe those are the issues. In considering this ministerial statement, not the least of the points we have to make is that the Minister has said: 'We should hand it over to the States. We will work it out together. It will be all right.' It might have been all right 12 months ago, but if there is any area in present Commonwealth-State relations where there is not merely chaos but confrontation on almost a daily basis it is health care. The Minister for Health from my own State, a man whose political philosophy is the same as that of this Minister, said only today that if Commonwealth funding continues at the present level Victoria will have to cut back on its health services. Is the Minister for Health serious when he brings in a proposal and says to the Minister for Health in Victoria: 'Despite the fact that you will have to cut back on services, we have an entirely new policy for the treatment of Aborigines which will cost you more than you are paying at the moment'? Have honourable members ever heard such palpable nonsense?

It is not necessary that Government members support this statement. Perhaps it is not so important that the Parliament support it. But when we are talking about Aboriginal health care it is important that the Aboriginal people throughout Australia support the statement. What have they said about this report, this Minister for Health and this wretched Prime Minister? Mr Gary Foley, an Aboriginal who knows a great deal about Aboriginal health care services was reported in an article in the Press. He said:
We are being trodden down, and every effort we make to improve the serious health problems of our people is thwarted by the Government.
The article continued:

The Government is refusing to fund 10 key Aboriginal-run medical services-at Campbelltown, Taree and Wilcannia (NSW), Geraldton, Broome, Warburton and Kalgoorlie (WA) and Rockhampton, Mackay and Cairns (Qld) . . . The Aboriginal medical services are the most cost-effective programs and the ones which, on the evidence of several Government reports, are doing by far the most and best work . . .
No objective examination of those reports will contradict that statement. The article continued:
All 32 staff, including seven doctors and dentists, of the Victorian Aboriginal Health Service have been working for seven weeks without pay because of a government-induced funding crisis.

That crisis has been induced by this Government and this Prime Minister. The Minister for Health has made in the Parliament a lengthy statement telling the Aboriginal people that by the application of Fraser federalism all will be well. The Aboriginal people have reached, in the course of the last two decades, an understanding about their own rights, perspectives and self-dignity. They know the medical services in which they have confidence. More importantly, they know those services which reach out to meet Aboriginal needs and aspirations. This statement does not meet those aspirations, those hopes or the recommendations of the parliamentary committee. It does not fall within the purview of the Government's own internal review. It is a mediocre muddled statement which simply reflects the present trend of Fraser federalism. Just as that policy is failing in every other area it will fail the Aboriginal people of this nation.

That restructuring has involved merger negotiations by all the major private trading banks with the result that at this stage two mergers are now formally proposed. Those mergers are the Bank of New South Wales with the Commercial Bank of Australia and the National Bank of Australasia Ltd with the Commercial Banking Co. of Sydney Ltd. These mergers have enormous implications for Australia. They are the largest takeovers in our history. TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 7 (1981).

The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals No. 7 (1981), which operates on and from tomorrow, contains tariff changes resulting from the Government's decision on recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission in its report on wheelchairs. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations that the duty rates applicable to wheelchairs and parts will be reduced to 20 per cent over the next two years. This rate represents a duty reduction of 14 per cent for mechanically propelled and 16 per cent for manually operated wheelchairs. Before reaching this decision the Government gave careful consideration to the need to strike a balance between reducing costs for wheelchair users and providing a level and form of assistance appropriate to the existence of a viable local industry.

I draw the attention of honourable members to the Government's announcement in the 1980-81 Budget of a new program under which a range of aids to daily living will be provided to disabled people. This program is intended to benefit disabled people not eligible under existing Commonwealth, Commonwealth-State or State funded programs. A range of aids including conventional wheelchairs, manual and motorised, will be available on indefinite loan under the program without cost to the recipients. The necessary administrative arrangements for this program are currently being developed under the authority of my colleague the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) with a view to the program commencing later this year.

The proposals also contain changes which remove a tariff anomaly relating to raised nap cotton fabric known as flannelette. A new definition allows concessional entry of only genuine flannelette in accordance with a Government decision taken last year following the Industries Assistance Commission report on textiles, clothing and footwear. The new definition will ensure that cotton fabric with minimally raised nap falls within the quota system, as intended; but to avoid disruption to the industry making up bed linen, importers of raised nap sheeting which does not meet the flannelette definition will be issued with supplementary quota for the remainder of the quota period to 31 December 1981. A summary setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Proposals to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Garden Island, N.S.W., modernisation stage 2.

This proposal is for the second stage of an overall modernisation program which is aimed at improving the effectiveness and efficiency of the dockyard and the fleet base, providing each with a capability of operating independently without duplication, improving the aesthetic qualities of Garden Island while minimising undesirable effects on the environment and preserving historic buildings. The estimated cost of the proposed works is $79m at April 1981 prices. I table plans of the proposed work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the reference of the second stage of modernisation program for Garden Island to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works. We have always supported the examination by that Committee of the Parliament of propositions such as this which come from the Government. We trust that the work of the Public Works Committee will be facilitated by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) and his Department so that the report can come back to this Parliament and an early decision may be taken by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on the Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Bill I would remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, the Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill, the Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, and the Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuing my remarks on the Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Bill and the Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill I reiterate what I believe to be the Government's reason for imposing these charges. This Government is intent on raising funds to add to its revenue or on cutting expenditure to achieve the same aim. That is what this Bill sets out to do. For the last four months I have sat in this House and listened to ideological rhetoric which could lead one to believe that the Government is about lowering taxes and charges. Nothing could be further from the truth. This measure, although only dealing in small amounts of money, is another measure designed to collect funds from two industries which can ill afford to pay the extra charges.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) said that the purpose of the Bills is to have the fish and dried fruit industries pay half the costs of the services provided. The Bills set out the maximum amounts which can be charged. The previous speaker on the Government side, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), outlined the clauses of the Bills relating to these maximum charges. I will repeat them for the benefit of those who are listening at present. He said:
Clauses 6 (3) and (4)-
This is the Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Bill-

give details of the maximum charges allowed under this Bill. They are 15c a dozen for oysters and 30c per kilogram for fish other than oysters. In the dried fruit levy Bill, clause 6 (2) also allows for differential treatment and clause 6 (3) sets the maximum charge under the proposed Act at $11 a tonne. However, fish and dried fruit producers should not be alarmed by the amounts referred to as these are truly the maximum charges.

Fruit growers and fishermen would not want their livelihood to depend on this Government keeping any commitments. When the Government says at this stage that the charges are only 50 per cent it will be just a matter of time before we see a change. The honourable member for O'Connor also said that the maximum charges are introduced in line with the present policy and give a sensible life to the Bill. We could ask what he means by the words 'a sensible life to the Bill'. Virtually that means that any time in the near future when the Government sees fit, it can take necessary measures to collect the other 50 per cent thus doubling the charge in a very short time. Those are the policies to which he is referring. At this stage the charge is only 50 per cent of the services provided. No doubt, along with most of the other commitments made by this Government it will not be long before that will be changed and it will be charging the full 100 per cent.

At this stage I would like to refer to a few other points concerning the fishing industry. Recently, the Australian Fishing Industry Council and the Victorian Fishing Industry Council were formed. The fishing industry has as much potential for development as any Australian food industry. The December 1980 edition of the official Commonwealth journal Australian Fisheries shows the value of fisheries production at an estimated $281m. Exports of Australian fisheries products to the year ended 30 June 1980 were worth a record $256m. It can be seen that this industry is worth a lot to the export income of this country. However, the journal states:
Because of rising costs, particularly fuel costs, most fishermen were probably worse off in 1979-80 than in the previous year.

This applies particularly to the many fishermen catching the high value species such as prawns and rock lobsters where neither catches nor the pace of price increases matched those of the previous year. So from the 1980 edition of the Australian Fisheries we see that there is not a great deal of room in the industry for the Government to be imposing extra charges at this time, particularly when we are constantly told by this Government that it is reducing taxes and charges. The very facts point to the opposite happening.

In applying these charges to the industry the Government is adding to the already large increases in fees which at least one State government imposed at the end of 1980. I refer to the Victorian Government which increased fees for abalone divers and scallop fishermen by up to 100 per cent. Not only is the industry copping it from the Federal Liberal Government but also it is copping it from the Victorian Liberal Government. The fishing industry should be encouraged to expand. Whilst we are exporting fish to the value of $256m, we are importing fish to the value of $150m. The Government would be better advised to concentrate on fostering the industry as it has great growth potential which should be assisted by decreasing costs rather than unnecessarily increasing them.

I do not want to take up a lot of the time of the House tonight. In the time that is available to me I just want to make a couple of comments. I find it rather alarming that, with only a couple of weeks of this parliamentary session left, we have 47 notices on the Notice Paper with many more to come in. Time will be vital. We will need it to discuss some of the more important issues. At this stage I would rather leave my remarks at what I have had to say and I urge the Government to bring forward and to debate some of the vital issues that the country is wanting to hear debated. I have said enough on this matter. The eight minutes which are remaining to me can go to a more sensible debate perhaps for a bigger industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to deal with the Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charges) Bill. (Quorum formed). The continual disruptions by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) indicate the importance the Australian Labor Party attaches to these primary industry Bills. The Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charges) Bill and associated Bills allow for a maximum charge of $11 a tonne for the inspection of dried fruit. The actual charge being proposed by regulation in the Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charges) Bill is $5.50 a tonne for 1981-82. These charges aim to recover some 50 per cent of the cost of inspection of dried fruit and will yield some $259,000 in a full year. The charges will operate from 1 July.

SPEECH.PARA: The House will be well aware that this Government has made significant contributions to inspection services for primary industry as, indeed, it has made to research programs and promotion in many rural industries. I was interested to hear the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham)-perhaps we can excuse him because he has only been a member of parliament for four months-criticising the Government for the fact that it seeks to recover some 50 per cent of inspection charges. I have been a member of parliament for some nine years. I remember what happened after the report of the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government was presented to the Australian Labor Party Government. The beef industry was in its most serious depression ever. The Labor Government introduced a program for complete recovery of inspection charges for beef at that time. When we came into government it was necessary for us to abolish those inspection charges altogether.

TALK.START.PARA: —You put them back on again.
—What did you do for the beef industry?
—What are you doing for Aborigines?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. I also warn the honourable member for Hindmarsh and the honourable member for Murray. I call the honourable member for Mallee.

—Our Government abolished these charges on the beef industry altogether so that the very serious situation of the industry at that time could be resolved. I would like to make another point about this Bill: Where an industry is paying up to half of the inspection charges, I believe that it needs to be ensured and guaranteed that these inspection services are efficient and effective and that continual checks are provided to make sure that the amount of money that the industry is paying and the amount of money that the Government, through the taxpayers, is paying is being used in the best possible way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Primary Industry provides the export inspection services for the fried fruit industry. At the present time, there are some 29 DPI officers involved in inspection services. Most of these are stationed in the city of Mildura in my electorate of Mallee. Only a small number-two or three-are stationed in the ports of Adelaide and Melbourne. It is also interesting to note that in the dried fruit industry, Commonwealth officers perform both the domestic and export inspection services. The charges on the domestic side are accordingly given to the State governments to pay. I believe that this method of inspection could be applied to many more of our rural industries to overcome some of the duplication of costs and effort that occurs. Last year some 70,000 tonnes of dried vine fruit and 4,000 to 5,000 tonnes of tree fruit were involved in the inspection service. An average of 45,000 to 46,000 tonnes of dried fruit is exported each year. The cost of these inspection services is high. It has to be recognised that this cost represents only about one per cent of the value of all returns to the dried fruit industry.

It always amazes me when a shadow Minister for Agriculture-in this case the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin)-tends to talk down some of the smaller horticultural industries. He mentioned in his speech on this Bill almost a fortnight ago that the dried fruit industry is one of the weakest rural industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he say that?

—The honourable member for Werriwa did say that. I remember that when I entered this Parliament in 1972 the export value of a tonne of dried fruit was some $250. I remind honourable members that at the present time the price being received overseas for Australian dried fruit varies between $1,200 and $1,500 a tonne. I think this indicates the importance that this Government has placed on ensuring that adequate export markets are obtained and that industries are assisted in those markets.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, I read a study by Edward Gibbon, The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, in which he concluded that all taxes must fall at last upon agriculture. Even in Roman times, apparently, agriculture was obviously affected as much by the changes in political and economic life as by the variability of nature. (Quorum formed). Whilst man has proved that he is the equal of nature in some respects, he is also proving that he can cause instability and insecurity in world agricultural markets. Of course, this situation is very much reflected in the Australian dried fruit industry. The industry's exports, particularly to the European Economic Community, have been very difficult to maintain. It is a credit to that industry, both as a strong organisational group and as a marketing body, that it has over the last decade been able to place its total fruit crop both in the EEC market and in other new markets throughout the world.

It is, of course, of concern to the industry at the present time that Greece and Turkey are entering the European Economic Community, as both these countries are major producers of dried fruit. It is hoped that the subsidised arrangements that the EEC makes in respect of many of its agricultural products do not magnify and add to the difficulties that the Australian dried fruit industry has in placing its crops. The Australian dried fruit industry has retained its high reputation for quality and reliability of supply throughout the world. This has been done by a strong grower organisation in co-operation with government which has always sought to ensure high quality control through those inspection services that we are talking about tonight in the debate on this Bill. These services guarantee that our products are of a certain standard, both on the domestic and the export markets and, I believe, will ensure that this industry retains a very high reputation both here and overseas.

As you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Australian dried fruit crop is not a large crop in terms of acreage or in terms of total economic value. But it represents an income of some $80m to $90m a year in areas that contribute very much to decentralisation, economic viability and growth in our rural areas. Whilst tonight I recognise that we are placing a higher inspection charge upon an industry, I do know that this industry is increasing in viability and is making a major contribution both to the areas in which it is produced and to the national economy overall. I have much pleasure in supporting the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a serious student of Roman history, no doubt the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) would know that the fall of the Roman Empire eventually was brought about by the authoritarian and elitist policies of the power that be. I think there is a message there for the present Government. In dealing with the Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, I would like to talk a little about the fishing industry. I represent the electorate which has the largest fishing industry in Australia. It is an industry that has tremendous potential for growth. It is my belief that this Government should be encouraging that growth. Clearly this Government, with the imposition of these additional charges, is not doing that. It is an industry that has potential for export earnings and, probably more importantly, a potential to reduce the level of our foreign exchange. Unfortunately the industry is today in chaos. I had calls from my electorate today from the town of Carnarvon where, due to the dumping of fish on the Australian market, the price of snapper has fallen below an economically viable level.
—From which country?

—The countries are South Africa and New Zealand. I am not in favour of protection generally but this is a situation in which the Government should be supporting what is in fact an embryonic industry. It is an industry that is tremendously undercapitalised and an industry that needs to attract capital to improve the size and the quality of its fishing capability. This cannot be done unless there is some stability in the industry. This stability will not be enhanced by the effects of this Bill. One might wonder what will happen with the imposition of these extra charges to the presently flourishing abalone fishing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the tremendous difference between the policy of the Australian Labor Party and the policy of this present Government is worth bearing in mind. The Government does claim quite substantial income from royalties on the concessions for fishing within Australia's territorial waters. This Government puts that money into Consolidated Revenue. It is the policy of the Australian Labor Party to return that money to the industry, to make it available in the form of loans to the industry, so that fishermen can re-equip with better equipment and better boats to get out and compete with what is now a much better organised and a much better mechanised foreign industry. I think that illustrates the difference.

It is said that the maximum charges will not be applied immediately. I do not think anyone seriously believes that. We have seen this present Government grabbing, in the most grubby fashion, at every available dollar. It will be only a short time before people are paying the maximum charge under this legislation. I have no doubt that, once that maximum charge has been reached, the National Country Party and the Government will be only too pleased to introduce another Bill to raise the prices further. One of the things that should be remembered is that the fishing industry is a primary industry. It is one of the great primary industries of this country. Therefore, it is a little surprising that, when we are debating this Bill which relates so much to primary industry, members of the National Country Party in this chamber are noticeable by their absence. I do not know why this is so. I think that something fishy is going on. I think people are beginning to realise-certainly this applies to the people in my electorate-that for many years the National Country Party has not been serving their interests. Quite honestly, I do not think there is enough substance to these Bills to warrant the length of time spent on them by the honourable member for Mallee.

In conclusion, I say that we need to support this industry. It has the potential to reduce our foreign exchange. We are presently importing $150m worth of fish a year. This is a bill which could be substantially reduced. The industry could provide employment to a tremendous number of areas in Australia that today are areas of relatively high unemployment. Small country towns up and down the coast of my electorate would benefit substantially from a revitalised wet fishing industry. If the Government is serious about tackling unemployment-of course, I think it is a very big 'if'-this is one area in which a little consideration and the initiative that the Government is always talking about could be applied. The evidence is overwhelmingly present. With a little initiative and encouragement, the fishing industry in this country could develop substantially and could be providing substantial employment in areas which currently have a high level of unemployment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill and the Excise Amendment Bill, as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these measures? I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) has suggested, the Customs Amendment Bill and the Excise Amendment Bill are fairly parallel measures, and the Opposition is quite happy to proceed with a cognate debate. The first Bill, the Customs Amendment Bill 1981, amends the Customs Act in four principal ways. Firstly, there are provisions to clarify the powers of Customs to deal with illegal imports such as narcotics, and in fact those provisions follow the recommendations of the Williams Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. Secondly, there are provisions which clarify the powers and procedures of the Customs Bureau for clearing goods through Customs. Thirdly, the Bill invokes powers to the Bureau of Customs to deal with illegally imported vessels, particularly refugee boats which are condemned or otherwise unseaworthy. Finally, there is an amendment which aims to extend the validation period for tariff and excise proposals from the present period of six months to 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to deal in detail with those four main areas. Firstly, the clarification and extension of the powers of Customs in dealing with illegal imports such as narcotic drugs is welcomed by the Opposition. These changes in part reflect the administrative directions already issued, following the abolition of the Narcotics Bureau in 1979. They are in accordance with recommendations of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, which sought to delineate clearly the responsibilities of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs on the one hand and the Australian Federal Police on the other. The Bill also provides for an extension of Customs control over ships and aircraft at sea from the present three miles to 12 miles from the coast. The Opposition supports those provisions. However, we note with some concern some of the implications of the changes, which obviously are much more extensive than those few words might suggest. The area of responsibility insofar as surveillance is concerned is extended by a factor in excess of four. As an example, to comprehend the difference between a 3-mile zone and a 12-mile zone, the area involved increases from about twice the size of Tasmania to about twice the size of Victoria. It is difficult enough to provide surveillance in compact areas of that size, but the fact that the area extends around the 36,735 kilometres of Australian coastline greatly exacerbates the problem.

In answer to Opposition questions in the House of Representatives and recent Senate Estimates committees, we find that the surveillance effort of the Department remains very limited. I think it is a matter of some concern that the Government is not providing facilities for more extensive surveillance. There are only three Nomad aircraft-one at Townsville, one at Darwin, and one at Port Hedland. Notwithstanding that there are also capabilities relevant to Customs in the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre, the number of aircraft is clearly very limited. The siting of the planes in northern Australia reflects the highly questionable assumption that smuggling activity will occur only in that zone. Practical experience teaches us that that is just not the case. If I might refer the House back to the tabling in this House of the Williams report, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) noted that the report cited the case of a Taiwanese fishing boat sailing a considerable distance up the Brisbane River before it was detected. Apparently it had journeyed undetected from Darwin, using a school atlas. I well recall the classic remark of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) that the military capability of Australia was such that it could not defend Botany Bay on a sunny Sunday afternoon, but surely it is a ridiculous state of affairs when a flimsy Taiwanese fishing boat can sail around the coast of Australia and up the Brisbane River without anybody noticing it is there.

The Williams report also found that, in the two years to August 1979, there were 109 unresolved sightings of unidentified aircraft flying into Australia. Some of these, the Commission said, could reasonably be expected to have carried narcotics. That is not a very profound statement, but I am sure it carries a deal of truth. Similarly, in the eight years to June 1978, there were 12 proven illegal importations of drugs by small seacraft, leading to action in the courts and various people being incarcerated. With such limited surveillance capacity, it is reasonable to say that no doubt these sightings and captures were just the tip of the iceberg. It is interesting to note some of the recommendations of the Williams Royal Commission in relation to surveillance. The first recommendation I mention appears on page B441, and it states:
Surveillance of Australia's coastline should not be confined to Northern Australia.
That is something with which the Opposition agrees. It should be noted at once that the Government's placement of the Customs planes breaches this recommendation. The Commission also recommended:
The responsibility for three Nomad aircraft dedicated to coastal surveillance by the Bureau of Customs should be transferred to the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre.

We do not disagree with that recommendation either. Going further at page B383 the Commission noted that it was unable to ascertain with any precision the role of these three Customs aircraft. It noted in particular that the speed of the Nomad is very low. Some people say that someone on a hang-glider can almost rush past a Nomad. In fact, its speed is somewhere in the vicinity of 150 to 200 knots, while the only established case of an aircraft being used to drop narcotics in Australia involved an aircraft with a much higher speed capacity-in excess of 200 knots. We all know that that plane was detected because the damn thing crashed. No one caught it; it crashed quite by accident in Central Australia. The Department told the Royal Commission that the planes were response vehicles, 'response' being the operative word, and I would like the Minister to explain what response means. The Royal Commission was not convinced, and probably was not very amused either. I note that, in answer to a question in Estimates Commitee D on 29 August 1980, the Department again referred to these planes as response planes.

There we have it. Firstly, planes are operated by an agency which the Royal Commission recommended should not operate them. Secondly, they operate in areas of Australia which the Royal Commission found should no longer be the focus of attention. Thirdly, they operate in roles which the Royal Commission could not ascertain. That is not a very splendid record of service and devotion, I might say to the Minister. Added to that, we now have a fourfold extension of the surveillance area, which clearly means that the capacity to provide surveillance with such minimal resources is totally inadequate.

I suppose that this is what small government is all about. I hope that more and more Australians will realise that when the penny-pinching philosophy called small government really surfaces, it is an unabashed abdication of government responsibility. In this area of surveillance of our coastline as a means of keeping narcotics out of Australia and out of the reach of Australian kids, I am sure that the Minister shares my concern that the resources available to him are not adequate to do the job. In some other areas the Opposition welcomes the legislative improvements in respect of the role of Customs. We hope-I fear in vain-that the Government will match these improvements with an appropriate commitment of resources. I notice the Minister is smiling. I am sure that he agrees with me.

I turn briefly now to the second group of amendments provided in the Bill. These clarify the powers and procedures of the Customs Bureau and, again, the Opposition has no objection to them. One of the more important provisions in this group is that which makes principals liable for the acts of employees involved in the unauthorised movement of goods in a Customs area. An adequate defence is provided by the Bill to protect principals who take reasonable precautions and exercise due diligence in respect of such goods. The Opposition contacted the Customs Agents Federation regarding these provisions because obviously they have an important effect on the members of that organisation. I am happy to report that the Federation has no objection to them, but it should be noted that that is just as well because there appears to have been no consultation between the Federation and the Government. It seems to me singularly appropriate that, where legislation affects business in various ways, there should be consultation, but that seems not to be this Government's philosophy. It is trying to reduce consultation, and apparently it made no effort at all in this case. That is probably a failing of this Government in many other areas. Where changes are made which affect industries, the people who work in them and the people who run them, consultation with those industries should be mandatory before the decisions are made. You, Sir, might well remember the singular victory you had in this House in the case of the wine brandy growers and the certain consultation that was lacking in that area. I suggest to the Minister that he should not neglect this important need. If he does talk to the Customs Agents Federation he will find that its members do have problems with clearing goods through Customs. He should look at ways of improving this situation. I am sure that he will not find that so-called small government is the answer in this case either.

The third major series of amendments in this Bill relate to the powers of Customs to deal with illegally imported vessels, particularly refugee boats, which are condemned or otherwise unseaworthy. Problems arose with the Customs Act two or three years ago when several dozen refugee boats in Darwin Harbour presented a major disposal problem. I can well remember being in Darwin at that stage and seeing the harbour festooned with these odd craft which people had used to escape to Australia. Amending legislation passed last year with the support of the Opposition and these further provisions add to those new powers. Of course, the Opposition supports the provisions which give the Bureau of Customs the right to destroy those boats if necessary.

Finally, the fourth major provision of the Bill is that to amend section 226 to extend the validity period of customs tariff proposals from six months to 12 months. The Excise Amendment Bill, which is also a subject of this cognate debate, similarly provides for an extension of the validity period for excise tariff proposals. Customs tariff and excise tariff proposals are of fundamental importance to the Australian economy. They have two fundamental roles. Firstly, they are taxes, and vitally important taxes at that. Many of the excise tariff proposals relate to the crude oil levy, which, of course, has been a massive tax slug for one thing, but which has also been a massive advantage to the Government in reducing the deficit. The Government has trumpeted loudly about its great efficiency in reducing the deficit. We of the Opposition and the Australian public know that the deficit has been reduced only by means of the levy which has come out of the pockets of the public. Total customs and excise taxation revenue estimated for the current year is $7,762m, nearly one-quarter of the Government's total tax revenue.

The second fundamental role of customs and excise tariffs is the implementation of industry policy. Tariffs, of course, are the principal means whereby Australian industries are protected from import competition. The jobs of hundreds of thousands of Australians are at stake every time a customs tariff amendment Bill is passed by this House. We believe that legislation of such fundamental importance to the taxation and industry policies of Australia should not be tampered with lightly. However, the Government is proposing to halve the frequency with which the principal legislation enacting changes in tariff rates is to be dealt with and debated in this Parliament. Tariff and excise charges can already be implemented months in advance of parliamentary approval, but the Government wants to extend the period during which it can collect these taxes without legislative backing in the forms of customs or excise tariff amendments. The Opposition cannot agree to those provisions. We cannot accept that a government should reserve for itself an extended capacity to impose retrospective legislation to collect taxes while, at the same time, failing to act retrospectively against tax avoiders. This Government has been anything but backward in adopting a holier than thou attitude when it comes to retrospective legislation with regard to tax avoidance. However, here we find the Government cooly, coldly and blandly implementing this provision in this House to impose taxes retrospectively.

We do not believe that the Parliament's role should be further downgraded in this way. We acknowledge, of course, that it is not possible to change tariffs by legislation enacted in advance of the date such changes come into effect, but there is no reason to extend beyond a full sitting of the Parliament the period before legislation is introduced. If income tax on government spending decisions were treated in such a cavalier fashion we would have a constitutional crisis. The Opposition will not agree to these changes dealing with one-quarter of the Government's revenue. In summary, the Opposition welcomes the improvements in customs administration provided by this Bill in such areas as the clearance of goods, surveillance against illegal imports and dealing with illegally imported vessels. However, we oppose the Government's attempts to reduce further the role of this Parliament in scrutinising and determining excise and tariff rates in Australia. To assist the passage of this Bill and to assist the Government to clear the backlog of legislation, we will be doing our best not to hinder the House too much. We intend to oppose clause 28 of the Customs Amendment Bill in the Committee stage. We intend to oppose the Excise Amendment Bill in its entirety at the second reading stage. We will divide on each occasion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
