TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill and the Customs Amendment (Security) Bill as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each Bill at the conclusion of the debate.
—There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of these Bills is to bring the Australian anti-dumping law into conformity with the revised codes of conduct for international trade agreed to at the Tokyo round of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations. It will not be any surprise to the Government to find that the Opposition supports these measures because Australia's first venture into anti-dumping legislation occurred in the time of the illustrious Whitlam Government. So we are not about to oppose the Government's sticking to what we originally introduced. The Bills amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 in accordance with the revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade code on anti-dumping, subsidies and countervailing measures. These two codes are among several considered at the Tokyo round in the context of non-tariff barriers to trade.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the two principal objectives of the Tokyo round was to secure a series of multilateral agreements on the conduct of international trade. I think it is fair to say that the Tokyo round appears to have been successful in respect of its other main objective which was to achieve a substantial reduction in tariffs applying to industrial products. The first instalment of these tariff reductions took effect on 1 January 1980. The major industrial nations reduced tariffs on industrial products. Over the eight years to 1988, tariffs are to be reduced by about one-third. I can only applaud that as being a major breakthrough. This success on the tariff front has moved the centre of attention towards non-tariff barriers to trade. It is in this area that the success of the Tokyo round is less than certain.

It should be recognised that reductions in non-tariff barriers to trade are of vital importance not only to Australia but also to the economy of the entire world. Growth in trade has normally been associated with the growth in national incomes, increased productivity and an increased standard of living. Provided trade is conducted on a fair basis, it will almost always prove mutually beneficial to its participants. In this context the maintenance of Australia's anti-dumping law in accordance with internationally agreed principles is firmly supported by the Opposition. The purpose of the anti-dumping law is to ensure that trade is conducted on a fair and efficient basis. It is not a back door method for controlling imports or for erecting barriers to trade. However, we must always be aware of the fact that indiscriminate use of anti-dumping provisions invites retaliation against our own exports. There have been instances in recent history of this occurring, not necessarily in Australia. At the same time, indiscriminate use limits the effectiveness of our anti-dumping investigations because it prejudices co-operation with our trading partners.

The Opposition notes and welcomes the support expressed by a number of industry organisations for Australia's accession to the anti-dumping code. Of course, it is essential that this responsible attitude is taken if international agreement is to be maintained. I will refer later in my remarks to the subsidies and countervailing measures code to which Australia has not yet acceded. Overall, the new code probably makes it easier to prove a case of dumping against an exporter. The GATT code considers that a product is being dumped:

. . . if the export price of the product exported from one country to another is less than the comparable price, in the ordinary course of trade, for the like product when destined for consumption in the exporting country.

This is a very long-winded way of explaining the position. What is basically meant is that if country A wants to export to country B, then country B has the right to expect that the export price quoted by country A is in fact the price used for the sale of that commodity in country A. The code additionally requires that dumpings cause or threaten to cause injury before dumping action is appropriate to be undertaken. Clearly, the key concepts in the dumping law are export price, normal value and injury. It is the revised definition of these concepts which is at the heart of the new code and its amending legislation.

Clause 3 introduces new provisions which draw a distinction between export prices arising from what is known as arms length transactions on the one hand and transactions where the importer and exporter are associated on the other hand. Where the importer and the exporter are associated and hence the stated export price may be higher than the export price which effectively prevails, appropriate adjustments may be made. This clause also covers the contingency where, for example, goods may be sent to Australia for sale on consignment and an agreed export price struck which may not be valid. This clause should assist in the administration of the code enabling the Minister to find anti-dumping action more easily warranted where transaction prices appear to be constructed to avoid anti-dumping action.

Similarly, clause 4 strengthens the Minister's hand in relation to the assessment of normal value by inserting criteria which enable a fair assessment of normal value to be made in the home country. Obviously, this clause has been introduced to cover the case of countries that have centrally planned economies where it is difficult to establish what is, in fact, normal value.

TALK.START.PARA: —Joh told me about it.

—I presume the Minister means Joh Bjelke-Petersen told him about it; I will have to take his word for that. Obviously, there would be anomolies in countries with centrally planned economies where goods may be subsidised by all sorts of government measures. Obviously, it would be difficult to establish what real, normal value is. I will raise a matter of particular concern that the Opposition has in this regard. Obviously, to ascertain the normal value of an exported product, it is necessary to conduct inquiries in the exporting country. It would re reasonable to suggest that an adequate staff be maintained in appropriate locations by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in order for this to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before the House generally strengthens the provisions of the anti-dumping code. At the same time, the economic recession in Europe is likely to provoke some exporters to attempt to dump goods on the world market; obviously, that would include Australia. These two facts imply a need to take greater care and to devote more resources to anti-dumping administration. Yet it is my understanding that, as a part of the razor gang's determinations, the Australian Bureau of Customs staff in London, which also services continental Europe, is to be drastically reduced; in fact, I understand that the office is to be closed down altogether. I consider this another example of the stupidity of the 'small government' rhetoric of the Fraser Administration. Far from assisting the private sector we have here another example of harm to local companies which may face dumping from those countries where we may not have sufficient resources available to prove that dumping is in fact happening.

I ask the Minister to indicate what is happening to the Customs administration in the anti-dumping area and to explain to the House how a stronger code is to be backed up without an appropriate increment in the staffing resources devoted to its administration. I know that the staff of the Australian Bureau of Customs is extremely efficient. I am sure that the officers sitting in the advisers seats no doubt would support me in this view. However, they are not supermen, no matter how much they might try and even though the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) might look like an affable Clark Kent, I am sure that his men cannot do the work required unless they have extra staff. I am particularly keen to learn what the future of the Hong Kong, Tokyo, Auckland and New York offices will be, given the apparent decision to close the London office.

The administration of dumping law is of crucial importance, it if is to be at all effective. Recently there have been complaints of dumping by Japanese exporters of washing machines and by Korean exporters of steel. These complaints need to be dealt with quickly. If they are proven, action should be taken quickly. If they are not proven, that too should be quickly notified because trade should not be encumbered with false accusations and hostile attitudes. An efficient and speedy process which is as objective as possible is needed. In this light, I must raise the question of the Government's action in establishing a joint industry-government Dumping Evaluation Committee, in the case of the steel industry, and what that is likely to achieve.

I have with me a media release from the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs which speaks of the creation of a joint iron and steel industry-departmental Dumping Evaluation Committee. The Minister decided to set up this committee to look at the proposition that Korean steel was being dumped in Australia at a cheap rate. The chief appellant, of course, was Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd. That poses some interesting questions. Apart from being Australia's steel manufacturing giant, the BHP company is also interested in the export of iron ore and coal, amongst other things. I suppose it must sometimes wonder whether its customers in other countries, particularly Korea, might be tempted to dump steel back to Australia. I guess there would be some manufacturers of white goods or other implements in Australia which might be concerned that the only steel they can buy in Australia is at a price which is largely set by BHP. I guess that some of those companies might well be interested in buying some Korean steel.

So, when this anti-dumping action was promulgated, the Minister set up this committee. I wonder at the efficacy of that committee. I notice that the industry will be represented by Mr Cox, the Executive General Manager (Tube Division) of Tubemakers of Australia Limited, Mr H. R. Fowler, the General Manager of Australian Tube Mills Pty Ltd, Mr J. R. McGregor, the Chief Tariff Officer of Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd, and Mr G. A. White, the Secretary of John Lysaght (Australia) Ltd. It seems to me to be a peculiar state of affairs to have these people on a committee set up by the Government to investigate a complaint by BHP when they either work for BHP or for companies in which BHP has a very large interest. Whilst I am not doubting the honesty, sincerity or integrity of these gentlemen, I think any people who investigate themselves rarely come up with the right conclusion. I throw that in as an object of my interest, and perhaps the Minister might like to respond. I wonder whether it is a legitimate example of Government-industry co-operation or whether it is just another cog in the wheel without any clear function.

TALK.START.PARA: —You missed one member.
—Did I miss a member? I do not think I missed any.
—Mr Willett.

—I am talking about industry representatives. I know that the committee will be chaired by Mr Willett, the First Assistant Secretary of the Industries Assistance Division of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, but I was merely referring to the business interests on that committee which all seem to have a fairly vested interest in deciding that Korean steel is being dumped here too cheaply. If the Minister had managed to put on that committee a few other people from manufacturing industry, they may have had a countervailing view. I would appreciate a statement on this issue that might shed more light on it than that media release of 8 April.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to clause 5 of the Bill which amends the provisions in relation to injury. I am talking about injury in a financial sense, not in regard to BHP which has probably suffered an injury to its pride. Once again, the new provisions tend to strengthen the hand of those seeking anti-dumping action. The concept of injury is extended to include a threat of injury because the provisions also apply to the hindrance of the establishment of a new industry. The Opposition welcomes these provisions as they should enable more rapid action against dumping practices without extending unduly the scope of the law.

The three clauses to which I have referred specifically in my remarks relate to the provisions of the Anti-Dumping Code. Other provisions in the Bill relate to the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. These provisions are similar to the anti-dumping law in that they enable the Government to protect Australian industries from imports which are subsidised by foreign governments. As yet, Australia has not acceded to this code, apparently because its prohibition on export subsidies is likely to mean that our own Export Expansion Grants Scheme will be in conflict with the code. Perhaps the Minister might like to comment on that. The Opposition strongly supports the provision of export market development assistance in Australia but is very concerned at the very high cost of the Export Expansion Grants Scheme. I believe that a comprehensive view of export programs is urgently needed. The Government deserves to be strongly condemned for its ad hoc approach to this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I notice that the honourable member for Hunter, who has an abiding interest in this area, supports me. I thank him for that support.
—He is the only one.

—I would not say that. I think some members opposite would support me if they were game to speak up but they are curtailed by party loyalties. Recently the razor gang extended the Export Expansion Grants Scheme for a further year at a reduced rate of payment. This decision is a classic example of opportunism. There appears to have been no assessment of the scheme in the proper framework of our approach to the GATT codes, and no indication whether the scheme is cost-effective. There has been no consideration whether the $26m spent on trade commissioner services and associated trade services would be better increased rather than spending $200m on hand-outs to successful exporters. I would like to know how an exporter who has managed to get an export industry going and is achieving profits from it but is then handed a financial bonus because of that, can be of advantage to Australia. This Government has responsibility to co-ordinate these programs, to assess them properly not in the context of windy rhetoric about small government but in the proper context of our trading policy and our industrial development policy.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government exercises no such responsibility. It cuts vital services on the one hand yet thinks nothing of spending hundreds of millions of dollars on subsidies for private companies which it claims are in need of, to use its euphemistic phrase, room to grow. It does not know whether these subsidies come close to being effective in terms of their stated objectives or in relation to alternatives which involve much lower outlays. In the meantime, we hear nothing from the Government about its future policy in this vitally important area of trade relations. This is not a philosophy of small government; it is evidence of incompetent government and of a government hell-bent on taking from the poor and giving to the rich.

After hearing the debates that have gone on in this Parliament in the last week or so about the Government's attempts to introduce what it describes as small government-attempts which I might say have been lauded by all sorts of industry groups such as the Confederation of Australian Industry, chambers of manufacture and particularly rural groups-it seems to me quite strange that there has been no suggestion that hand-outs to industry should be curtailed in any way. I do not hear these industry groups suggesting that the investment allowance, the accelerated depreciation allowance or export development grants should be reduced. The only thing that they have been crying for in terms of small government is a reduction in the services required by the poor of this country. I find that rather deplorable. In summary, the Opposition indicates that it will support these Bills, notwithstanding the damage to their administration which the Government has caused and the many unanswered questions regarding trade policy which a consideration of these Bills suggests to us. I hope that my remarks may provoke some reply from the Minister on some of these questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I heard the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) ask at the beginning of his speech how the Opposition could oppose the amendments to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Bill because, after all, it was the Whitlam Government which introduced anti-dumping measures in 1975. Certainly the legislation that the House is amending tonight was introduced by the Whitlam Government in 1975 but I can remember distinctly in 1973 when the Whitlam Government first came to power that the then Minister for Customs and Excise, Senator Murphy, by unilateral action took off anti-dumping duties against European cheese which had been proven to have been dumped in Australia by the then provisions of anti-dumping codes at an earlier time. I am a little puzzled by that statement, although I am never amazed at the actions of some Labor Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Parramatta commented that generally these amendments are to update the code that was last legislated in 1975. They take into account what has been agreed to under the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade during the Tokyo round of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations. Generally that is a good thing. To me the amendments overcome some, but not all, of the deficiencies which have been shown in succeeding years since 1975. I will refer to those a little later. Some examples of the changes and updating in this legislation are: The new power whereby retrospective duties may be imposed in cases where undertakings previously given are violated; the provision for the Minister to assess amounts of subsidies in cases of goods exported from countries where governments substantially influence prices; and the criteria set out for determining the price level, whether it is the domestic price, export price, third country price or Australian price.

We have seen a recent example of the difficulty in establishing a normal selling price for a product from a country with a socialist economy. Canned ham from Romania and Yugoslavia was imported to Australia. There was difficulty in establishing a normal selling price for that product. Another provision of this Bill is that, where undertakings have been violated, retrospective countervailing duties may be imposed. The Bill also allows for the imposition of retrospective countervailing duties when massive quantities of subsidised imports over a short period have caused injury. I support all these provisions, particularly the last one. I remember very well the situation in 1973 and 1974 when massive imports of ball-bearings from Taiwan circumvented the voluntary agreement reached between the governments of Australia and Japan. The export of ball-bearings from Japan had been reduced because of the harm it was causing the ball-bearing industry then in Australia. Of course, there is no longer a ball-bearing industry as such in Australia. The major and only complete manufacturer, the ball-bearing factory at Echuca, eventually closed down. A good percentage of the companies which operate in Japan also operate in Taiwan. Those companies managed to do very nicely by circumventing the voluntary arrangement. If my memory is correct, there was no ability at that time to impose the retrospective duties which this Bill seeks to provide.

The honourable member for Parramatta referred to clause 6 of the Bill which varies some of the definitions and criteria for the imposition of duty. He referred to the fact that now injury does not only have to be shown to be caused before duties are imposed but also it may be threatened. I think this is a very good insertion. We have seen many examples when the threat of a particular product entering Australia has had the same effect as would have been caused by the product actually getting here. I am worried by sub-clause (b) of clause 6. The word 'material' is to be inserted before the word 'injury'. That appears to me to be going the opposite way. I would be very interested to hear the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) explain how material injury differs from injury and how this sub-clause is to be interpreted. I am a little worried that it may be interpreted in a negative way.

I refer to two basic weaknesses that are still apparent to me in the protective measures we are taking against unfair trading competition with Australian manufacturers or producers. The first concerns the special agreements we have with a number of countries, of which New Zealand is the principal, whereby the ordinary anti-dumping duties do not immediately apply. Paragraph 10 of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement provides a 60-day consultation period. Recently, the report of the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into cheese was finally tabled. It was presented to the Government by the IAC, I think, in March 1979. Agreement was reached between Australia and New Zealand about 12 months later. The 60-day period was extended to almost 12 months before agreement was reached on a product in respect of which dumping had been proved. This is not good enough.

There is too much leeway for a country or an industry to make use of this more flexible approach for its own advantage. New Zealand certainly did so on that occasion. There were dra- matic increases in the amounts of cheese coming into Australia. At the end of the 12-month period, which should have been only 60 days, New Zealand was able to use the higher base of its cheese exports to Australia for the new arrangement which is now in place. I hope that if we reach some new agreement with New Zealand on closer economic relations or an expanded NAFTA, the New Zealanders will not be allowed to get away with what they have got away with under special provisions when dumping has been proved. I assure honourable members that the New Zealanders do not allow that to happen in return. They have special licensing and other provisions to protect their industries.

I draw the attention of the Minister to another weakness in the Bill, that is, the ability for a producer-primary producers are the main example-to suffer the dumping of a product but be unable to appeal, apply for or be the cause of anti-dumping action to be taken because the processed product is being imported into this country. The producers of such products are suffering but because the products are being imported in processed forms they cannot make application. The processor has to make such application. As the Minister knows, the importation of sweet corn is a very good example of that problem. I hope he can give some assurance that the sourness that has been caused by the importation of sweet corn will be eliminated and that the situation will again be sweet. This problem relates particularly to New Zealand. It indicates the inflexibility in the determination of who can make an application. In this case the sweet corn producer is affected. On my understanding, some of the processors of sweet corn have a foot on both sides of the Tasman. It suits them not to make application for protection from what is clearly a dumped product. I hope that that weakness in the code of fair trade to protect Australian industry will be remedied in the very near future. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence my contribution to this debate I refer to one of the comments made by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I have a supermarket advertisement which appeared in the New Zealand Evening Post on 6 January 1981. It indicates that a 450-gram can of sweet corn was selling in New Zealand at that time for 55c. The same brand was selling in Australia for 37c. That is evidence of what the honourable member for Murray was saying. There is a gap which needs to be remedied.

SPEECH.PARA: As my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) indicated, we on this side of the House will not oppose the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill or the Customs Amendment (Securities) Bill. I will concentrate on the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill. Under this legislation there is an obligation upon us to do two things. The first is to bring our own anti-dumping legislation into line with the anti-dumping code of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It must be recalled that it was the Australian Labor Government which in 1975 brought down the comprehensive legislation that updated our anti-dumping legislation in line with the then existing GATT Anti-Dumping Code. Therefore, there is no reason in principle for us to oppose this Bill.

Given that Australia must be a trading partner of a great number of nations, the necessity for orderly marketing practices ought to be only too evident. As the trading parties are off-shore to Australia and, therefore, are not normally subject to the local laws governing their trading behaviour, it has been recognised for years that internationally binding rules are required if orderly and equitable trading relations are to obtain. That point needs to be made clear about the nature of this legislation. We are talking about fair and equitable trading relations. That could not happen unless all parties to GATT brought the anti-dumping legislation into line with the Code to which they were signatories. Obligations to do so were imposed upon all signatories to the GATT Code. As has been said, the practice of dumping is reprehensible. Whilst in the short term consumers in an importing country might benefit from dumping practices, the long term continuation of such practices will no doubt be to their disadvantage. The short term increase in the choice of goods and lower prices will be offset by the disruptive effects upon the economy of the victim country. In all cases, the competing domestic producers will be forced to reduce their prices and employment opportunities or accept lower profits.

Secondly, we ought to put this legislation through to ensure that Australian industries are given adequate protection from the dumping practices of either predatory trading nations or less scrupulous foreign business houses. Some of the business houses alluded to by the honourable member for Murray, who has disappeared from the chamber, are business houses that have a foot in both camps as it were and, therefore, are quite happy to see the situation continue because they are able to do the dumping under the lap. In principle, those members of the Government who have recently inveighed against industry protection in favour of free trade must feel rather uncomfortable with this piece of legislation. It must be stated that there is nothing intrinsically evil in government interference in the trade from one country to another. Some members of the Government would like to propagate the view that there is some evil in government oversight of industry. Without such oversight, as my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta has indicated, trading relations would become chaotic. I hope that as yet the Government has not entirely succumbed to the influence of the free traders. For example, we reject as unfair the practice of dumping and believe that we require international agreement, such as the GATT code, to enable us to police this practice. If all things were equal it might have been possible to have free trade, but the great differences that exist between ourselves and our trading partners in so many ways will make free trade a disaster for Australian industry and, as a consequence, the welfare of Australian markets, workers and families.

As we know, dumping occurs when goods are exported at a price that is less than the normal value in the country of export. The normal value is generally defined as the price of like goods sold for home consumption in the exporting country in arm's length transactions by the exporter. The definition I have just quoted to the House enables us to establish a legal bar to more obvious injurious trading practices. Our international obligations require us to agree to legislate accordingly. It is for this reason that we of the Opposition support this legislation. However, as in most areas of human relationships, there is a tendency in some instances for exceptions to rules to intrude. This is a typical area. There are some practices which, whilst not necessarily fulfilling all the criteria for being called dumping, nevertheless need to be brought to the attention of the House because they do impose hardships upon sections of Australian industry. Again, the honourable member for Murray alluded to those. The differences between them and dumping are of degree only. I refer, of course, to imports of certain goods from New Zealand.

The House would be aware that in recent days the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) has been meeting with the New Zealand Prime Minister, Mr Muldoon, to negotiate a closer economic relations agreement between the two countries. Generally the relations between our two countries have been cordial throughout our history. It is to be hoped that this relationship will continue. However, I am unable to see how this will continue without some strain if the current negotiations result in opening the access to Australian markets of New Zealand products that will undercut the Australian equivalents. Strictly speaking, this does not fulfil all the criteria for a trading practice to be termed dumping, but the combination of factors will nevertheless result in the destruction of a number of very important primary industries in this country. Two major industries are of concern to me. I refer firstly to the potato industry and then, of course, to the fat lamb industry. Both of these industries affect the livelihood of many specialist farmers in my electorate of Ballarat.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know your subject.

—It is rather unfortunate that the honourable member for Cowper knows so little about the concerns of people such as those of Ballarat. At the moment, if no cognisance is to be taken of the particular circumstances of the potato industry, for example, imports of potatoes from New Zealand would undercut the price of Australian potatoes to such an extent that the industry would be crippled. Under Australian dumping law, dumping could be said to occur when injury caused by a trading practice is seen to cause material injury and it must be demonstrated to be so. For example, losses of sales, depressed prices or retrenchments must be due principally to imports at non-competitive prices, and the injury must be demonstrated by the major proportion of local industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the above, it is impossible for the injury not to occur should potatoes be fully able to be imported from New Zealand. Why is this so? Firstly, the real cost structure of each country is very different. The contract price of potatoes grown in New Zealand is the equivalent of $A42 per tonne. In Australia the contract price is $97.60 per tonne. The lower price of New Zealand potatoes is assisted by lower wage structures and government incentives. Secondly, the variations in currency values give the advantage to New Zealand potato growers. The depressed value of the New Zealand dollar makes it worth approximately 77c in Australian currency. The Australian dollar is a more buoyant currency and, therefore, movement tends to disadvantage Australian producers even more. Thirdly, the issue of government subsidies to potato producers further widens the gap between the possible price of potatoes imported into Australia from New Zealand and the minimum price Australian producers could obtain for their produce before suffering economic injury.

In the Ballarat potato growing region alone, the loss of such an industry would place an excessive burden upon the capacity of local industries to survive. The potato growing industry will not be the only one to suffer. There are over 300 producers throughout this area and approximately 1,200 people are directly involved in one way or another in the industry. In a direct sense, the industry is worth to that area approximately $14m, and it stimulates a further $15m in local business. I am sure that I do not have to convince you, Mr Deputy Speaker, of the hardship that a policy of quasi dumping would have upon local potato producers. It should not be without interest to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in his capacity as the honourable member for Wannon, that there are many potato producers in his electorate who would also be so affected. It is very important for points such as these to be made. As I have said, the practices might not be in direct contravention of the anti-dumping law but the effects are the same. Perhaps it is because of the inadequacies of the anti-dumping law that we have.

Any dumping or quasi-dumping practices must have serious effects upon Australian producers whether they be primary producers such as potato growers or fat lamb producers, vegetable growers, processors, or the clothing, textile, footwear and engineering industries all of which are particularly vulnerable in this country. It is very important for the House to recognise that individuals, their families and the viability of towns and cities are endangered by dumping and quasi-dumping practices. Mr Deputy Speaker, I assure you that the economy of a city such as Ballarat would be rocked should the potato industry collapse as a result of the importing of potatoes produced in an economic climate different from that of Australia. Potato harvesting and packing machinery would be made redundant and so would the industries that produce that machinery. We cannot allow that sort of thing to happen. I do not have to remind the House that the multiplier effect would mean a reduction in the work force in the retail industry of rural and provincial towns. I hope that members on the National Country Party benches-for want of a more appropriate name-would show some concern about this issue. I highlight the effects of a quasi-dumping practice to bring some notes of caution to those people hell bent on liberalising our marketing arrangements and also because dumping practices in general have all these effects which are evil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to repond briefly to those honourable members who have taken part in the debate and to thank them for the effort that they have put into their speeches and the contributions that they have made. I am always surprised at the depth of knowledge of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown). His wide ramble into dumping was quite an illuminating discussion even if one or two of the facts were not quite right. But that is not too bad when we relate it to some of these things. I wish to take issue with him on one point. The great era of dumping did not arrive with E. G. Whitlam at all. In fact, if one looks at the history of events it started when Australia removed import licencing in the 1960s. As a consequence certain dumping cases were taken and the procedures that are in place today eventually grew from that. The Government has every intention of maintaining these established positions. Commerce needs to know that we will be looking to its interests in every respect. That applies under the staffing situation where adequate provisions certainly will be made in some form to ensure that the dumping provisions are carried out in the best interests of Australian commerce. The anti-dumping committee to which the honourable member for Parramatta referred was established in the steel industry-its membership reflects this-to give a fast track response to dumping in that area. Those honourable members who take some interest in the iron and steel industry and the demand and supply situation will be aware of the high characteristics of fluctuation, to say the least, that occur and the need for prompt action. This committee consists of one member from the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, one member from a BHP subsidiary, one member from an entirely independent company which has no connection with BHP, and one member from my Department. They are there to establish a prima facie case. Once that has been established they do not recommend in any way or make any determination in relation to dumping. They purely make a quick response and it then goes to the appropriate authorities to make their determinations. The Department made an effort to assist in this area which was subject to some very quick changes in overseas supply and marketing of iron and steel in particular in the new developing nations. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) as usual made--
—A very good contribution.

—He made a good contribution, as the Minister for Housing and Construction has just said. In response to the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) it is worth while saying that the provisions for trade with New Zealand are really not subject to the multilateral trade negotiations but are subject to the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. Therefore, different provisions apply in relation to NAFTA products than do to the general dumping in other areas.
—I am aware of that but it is just a pity that in fact it allows--

—It is something of which people should probably be aware. If, as it is inevitable, closer associations with New Zealand take place, one would hope that the negotiations between New Zealand and Australia would materialise at a very high officer level and a very high political level. That requires good will on both sides. Most honourable members have said that sometimes they feel there is good will in Australia but not necessarily in New Zealand.
—This problem has not been taken into account in those negotiations.

—As the honourable member for Murray has said it is a matter of grave concern to people in his electorate and the electorate of the honourable member for Ballarat as he has pointed out tonight. I wish to thank those honourable members who have taken part in the debate and I am sure they wish the Bill well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to my question without notice on 11 October 1979 (Hansard, page 1905) urging the establishment of a National Crimes Commission, in view of the appalling escalation of organised crime in this country, has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to press reports of 6 February 1980 that the Australian Federal Police Force is studying a report compiled by a group of Federal and Victorian Members of Parliament on systematic penetration of organised crime?
(2) If so, does the report-
(a) call for the establishment by the Federal Government of a National Crimes Commission to identify the leadership and structure of organised crime in Australia; and
(b) suggest a number of significant amendments to the taxation, company and takeover laws, as these amendments may be the best way to deal with syndicate leaders of organised crime?

(3) If the report is as stated, will the Attorney-General take immediate steps to ensure that the suggested amendments to taxation, company and takeover laws will include measures to block syndicate leaders of organised crime?
(4) If the study finding confirms the appalling escalation of organised crime, will the Attorney-General give urgent re-consideration to my request to establish a National Crimes Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) I understand that the report calls for the establishment of a National Crimes Commission.
(b) I understand the report suggests that organised crime can best be dealt with through taxation, company and takeover laws.
(3) The matters referred to do not fall within my administration.

(4) The Government does not propose to establish a National Crimes Commission but rather to tackle identified problems in the area of organised crime with selective investigative machinery involving the State Governments as appropriate. For example, during the past couple of years, in response to suggestions made by the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs and the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, the Australian Federal Police have joined with the police in several States to investigate specific areas of drug trafficking. Also, last year the Commonwealth joined with the Victorian Government in the establishment of a Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Federated Ships Painters and Dockers Union in relation to the activities of crime syndicates on the wharves. (2) The RAAF does not compile individual cost records of servicing carried out by its own personnel. Based on recent servicings performed by QANTAS the overall cost of services is as follows:

The annual cost for each aircraft for QANTAS servicings is therefore estimated as $527,160. However, variations to individual servicing costs do occur depending on the actual work content of each servicing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On 15 December 1980 I announced that the Government had approved the production of a further 55 Nomad aircraft, bringing the total number of aircraft authorised to date to 200.
Over 100 Nomads are operating in Australia, Papua New Guinea, the United States of America, the Philippines, Indonesia, the Marshall Islands, Guam, Samoa, the Caribbean, Chile, Surinam, Sabah.

Nomads are being used in regular passenger transport and charter operations, in various Military Command, Communication and Support Roles, in Coastal Surveillance, in Aerial Medical Roles including Flying Doctor Service, in Aerial Survey, in Geophysical Search, in Float-Plane Operations, in General Utility and Cargo Carrying Roles.
The aircraft is being operated successfully and profitably in extremes of climate which include Papua New Guinea and Alaska.
Concerning the specific matters raised by the honorable member, I am advised that:
(1) A number of factors have contributed to the slowing down of the Nomad production rate during 1980 and 1981; these include:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the editorial 'The kangaroo from the veldt' in the Australian Financial Review, 19 February 1981.
(2) Is there any substance to the allegations made in the editorial, that the Ashton joint venture is 53.6 per cent foreign-owned.

(3) Has the Government or the Foreign Investment Review Board placed any conditions on the partners in the Ashton joint venture project; and specifically, what provision was made for (a) adequate consultation with all affected Aboriginal groups and (b) assessment and control of the environmental impact of the project.
(4) What timetable has the Government set for Ashton Mining NL to achieve 51 per cent Australian equity.
(5) What will be the frequency of Ashton Mining NL's discussions with the Foreign Investment Review Board on its progress towards achieving 51 per cent Australian ownership.

(6) Did the Government give the Ashton joint venture any special consideration due to the involvement of the Malaysia Mining Corporation Berhad (MMC), a company partly owned by the Malaysian Government; if so, what was the nature of that special consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention was drawn to the editorial 'The Kangaroo from the veldt' in the Australian Financial Review of 19 February 1981 and I wrote a letter to the editor which was published in the Australian Financial Review on 24 February 1981.

(2) The Ashton joint venture comprises CRA Ltd 56.76 per cent, Ashton Mining Ltd 38.24 per cent and Northern Mining Corp NL 5 per cent. Major foreign interests hold 61.1 per cent of CRA and 60.35 per cent of Ashton Mining. Accordingly, foreign equity in the Ashton joint venture is at present 57.8 per cent. However, under the Government's naturalisation provisions of its foreign investment policy, undertakings have been given by the parties concerned that Australian ownership in CRA and Ashton Mining will be increased to 51 per cent. As a consequence, foreign equity in the Ashton joint venture will be reduced to 48.4 per cent.

(3) As the Ashton joint venture project is to be developed by two naturalising companies and an Australian company, the parties are not required to notify the Foreign Investment Review Board of proposals for development of the venture. Accordingly, there are no conditions including matters such as Aboriginal consultations and environment protection attaching to the project at this stage. However, arrangements for the marketing of product from the project could affect the equity and control arrangement for the joint venture and will be examined by the Government in terms of its foreign investment policy prior to the project proceeding to development.

(4) The Government does not specify a firm time limit for a naturalising company to meet its obligations to increase Australian equity to the required level of 51 per cent. The Government expects this level to be achieved over the shortest period consistent with sound company management.
(5) Discussions between the Foreign Investment Review Board and Ashton Mining and its major foreign shareholders will be held annually.

(6). No. The Government saw no reason why it should treat Ashton Mining differently, on the ground that it has a connection with a Malaysian Government agency, from other companies seeking naturalisation. To have done so would have involved discrimination against a company which in all respects complied with the relevant terms of the naturalisation provisions. It is the Government's objective that a naturalised or naturalising company should operate with a predominantly Australian board and should be controlled by that board. Ashton Mining was able to satisfy the Government on all aspects of these requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Nitinol is an alloy of nickel and titanium which exhibits a wide range of physical changes when subject to low level differences in temperature.

(2) Is he able to say whether research has been carried out in Japan, the USSR, the Federal Republic of Germany and China and in the United States of America by NASA, the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation, the US Navy, the US Department of Energy and the University of California at Berkeley into use of Nitinol in solid state heat engines.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the paper 'Proceedings of the Nitinol-Heat Engine Conference' edited by Goldstein and MacNamara (NSWC MP 79/441), published by the US Naval Surface Weapons Centre and the Department of Energy.
(4) Is research and development work being done on Nitinol in Australia; if so, what are the details.
(5) In view of Australia's large reserves of nickel and titanium, will he undertake to have the significance of Nitinol examined as a matter of urgency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Nitinol is an alloy of nickel and titanium. It has the interesting property that it is a 'shape memory' alloy-that is, when plastically deformed at one temperature, it will, on being heated above a specific temperature, regain its initial shape. In scientific terms this phenomenon is known as a thermo-elastic marternsitic transformation. Other alloys, including those of copper, zinc, and aluminium, display shape memory effects similar to Nitinol. However, they are much cheaper than Nitinol, are much easier to machine and fabricate and therefore find much greater use industrially. Nitinol provides a very good example of the shape memory phenomenon and is widely used in research into this phenomenon. Its high relative cost, and disadvantages vis-a-vis other alloys have meant that its industrial usage remains insignificant.

(2) Research work on Nitinol is conducted in a number of countries, including those listed. Intermittent research on shape memory alloys has been conducted in Australia over the past 20 years. None of the Australian work has been directed explicitly towards the use of Nitinol in solid state heat engines.
(3) I am aware of this publication and would be happy to provide a copy to the honourable member if he so desires.

(4) Research work on Nitinol and related alloys is being conducted in Australia in the Department of Metallurgy of the University of Wollongong, under the direction of Associate Professor N. F. Kennon. This work has been supported, in part, by grants from the ARGC ($9,000 in 1981, and $8,000 in 1980). The Australian research on Nitinol, and shape memory alloys in general, is consistent with the scale of the total Australian research effort seen in a world context. More importantly, the priorities of the Australian research community reflect its perceptions of the solubility and fruitfulness of the various research areas.
As noted in (2) above, no research is being conducted in Australia on the use of Nitinol in heat engines although CSIRO maintains a 'watching brief' on overseas developments.

(5) Technological developments which would utilize Australia's large reserves of nickel and titanium would be of significant value. However, as noted above, the current industrial use of Nitinol is negligible and it is unlikely that applications for Nitinol will be developed in the foreseeable future. An urgent examination of the significance of Nitinol could not be justified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a firm of accountants been commissioned by the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund Investment Trust to advise it on accounting policy and ways of ensuring equitable distribution of earnings between past, present, and future contributors, following the Trust's decision to invest in equities.
(2) Was a firm of actuaries commissioned to produce a similar report.

(3) If so, (a) on what basis were these investigating accountants and actuaries engaged, (b) who was responsible for the decision to appoint them and (c) were CAGEO, ACOA, or any other contributors' organisations consulted before these firms were engaged.
(4) Has any member of the Trust had any dealings with these consultants in the past through private or other interests.

(5) When are the reports expected to be completed and will they be made available to contributors' organisations and individual contributors at the same time that they are made available to (a) the Department of Finance and (b) the Trust.

(6) Does the Australian Taxation Office require non-government superannuation schemes to revalue assets regularly to ensure that contributors receive their correct share of the net worth of the fund on exit; if so, is there a similar requirement for the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Superannuation Fund Investment Trust is an independent corporate body established under the Superannuation Act 1976. As such, the Trust has sole responsibility under the Act for the management and investment of the Superannuation Fund, being required only to report annually on the management of the Fund to the Parliament through the Minister for Finance. The Chairman of the Trust has, however, provided the following answers to the honourable member's questions (1) to (6):
(3) (a) Both the accountants and actuaries were engaged on the basis of their expertise in the particular area on which the advice was being sought.

(c) The ACOA Federal Executive was made aware of the commissioning of the firms of accountants and actuaries in replies to correspondence on the subject received by the then Minister for Finance from the office of the late Senator Knight on 8 July 1980 and 18 August 1980.
(4) The firm of accountants has carried out audit and accounting advice work on behalf of the Trust since 1976.
The firm of actuaries has not previously carried out any work on behalf of the Trust.
Other than that mentioned in the foregoing, no member of the Trust has had dealings with these consultants in the past through private or other interests.

(5) The Trust is currently considering the report from the firm of accountants and the report from the firm of actuaries is expected shortly. It is a matter for the Trust, in the first instance, to complete its examination of the reports and to submit recommendations to the Minister on any changes to the accounting arrangements that it considers are warranted. When both reports are to hand, the Trust will give consideration to seeking the views of staff organisations on the issues addressed in the consultants' reports.

(6) The Commissioner of Taxation oversights the practices followed by non-government superannuation schemes to ensure that the levels of benefits provided are not excessive and that appropriate contributions are made. To this end, I understand the Commissioner has regard among other things, to the value of any investment assets owned by a superannuation fund but the basis of valuation of these assets would depend upon individual circumstances. Although the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme is not subject to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the formulation and operation of the Scheme, including the operations of the Trust, broadly follows the principles applicable to private sector schemes. Consistent with this, I understand that the Trust will have regard to private sector practice when making its recommendations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Exotic Animal Disease, New Zealand: Procedures

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to my question without notice on 25 March 1981 (Hansard, page 882), is he able to say when the New Zealand authorities first were alerted to the outbreak of suspected exotic animal disease near Timaru which subsequently led to investigation and declaration of an infected place on 11 February 1981.

(2) Is he also able to say why there was such a long delay between the declaration of the farm at 4.30 p.m. on 11 February 1981 and the official announcement at 9.30 a.m. on the following day; if so, have the New Zealand authorities been questioned about this.
(3) Are there any international arrangements covering the timing and form of these arrangements; if so, what are they.

(4) If his Department first received information from the media about the declaration, does this mean that there is no agreement between the 2 countries to immediately notify the other; if not, is this situation being rectified.
(5) Why was there a delay from 10.30 a.m. to 11.15 a.m. between the first report and the telephone call initiated by his Departmental officers at that time to New Zealand.

(6) Were precautionary measures taken at Australian airports following the unofficial news from New Zealand, and was any alert sent to the airports or a check made of incoming New Zealand planes after the 10.30 a.m. news but ahead of the confirmation; if so, what measures were taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A Ministry of Agriculture Veterinary Officer first suspected that a vesicular disease was implicated on the morning of 11 February 1981. He called in a second Veterinary Officer from the New Zealand Ministry later that morning. The conclusion was reached on the afternoon of 11 February that a vesicular disease was implicated. This led to the declaration of the property as an infected place at 4.30 p.m. New Zealand time on the same day.

(2) No. The New Zealand Government decided that foreign authorities should be notified at the same time as the Prime Ministerial announcement was made to the New Zealand people (viz. 9.30 a.m. on 12 February). The matter has been discussed with the New Zealand authorities and a Senior Veterinary Officer will visit New Zealand early in May for further discussions.

(3) Australia and New Zealand are members of the Office Internationale des Epizooties (located in Paris), the rules of which require notification of exotic diseases within 24 hours of confirmation. (This disease was never confirmed). In addition to this, an Australia/New Zealand Technical Committee on Quarantine was set up in 1966 and regular communication on quarantine matters is exchanged by annual meetings of this group. Between meetings, information is exchanged on a direct basis and may involve any of the following matters: changes in vaccination or in importation policies and, in particular, outbreaks of disease. These arrangements are on the basis of bilateral notification 'as soon as possible'.

(4) Yes. Arrangements for notification exist. See 3 above. I am advised that arrangements were made for a telex to be sent to Australia to coincide with the New Zealand Prime Minister's announcement at 9.30 a.m. on 12 February New Zealand time. I understand that the telex left the New Zealand Ministry immediately after the public announcement but, in accordance with normal New Zealand diplomatic procedure, was forwarded via the NZ High Commission in Canberra. The telex did not reach the Australian Quarantine Service until 1.45 p.m. Australian time by which time the news had been received through the media.

(5) My officers received the first reports through the media at 10.30 a.m. on 12 February Australian time. The Quarantine Division immediately established that the Department of Primary Industry had heard simultaneously of the incident via a call from Paris where the Office Internationale des Epizooties was, by chance, meeting. The call indicated that an incident had been reported in New Zealand. At 10.40 a.m., a call was placed by the Quarantine Division to the New Zealand authorities to seek confirmation. Connection was not achieved until approximately 11.15 a.m. While awaiting connection the implementation of additional quarantine precautions, was planned in case they proved to be necessary. When connection was achieved the New Zealand authorities confirmed a suspected vesicular disease outbreak and, at the same time, were advised, broadly, of precautionary measures that Australia would take.

(6) Additional precautionary measures were in place at Mascot by 11.50 a.m. (i.e. 20 minutes after completion of the call to New Zealand) and in all Australian airports by 12.30 p.m. No alert was sent to airports or any additional check of New Zealand planes implemented after the 10.30 a.m. media reports. Rather, immediate confirmatory action as outlined in (5) was taken. As indicated there, the time between placing the call to New Zealand and connection (viz 10.40 a.m. to 11.15 a.m.) was utilised to plan additional quarantine measures which may have been necessary. There was of course no way of knowing how quickly the connection to New Zealand would be made. It would have been totally irresponsible to implement restrictions before confirmation of the outbreak had been received from the source.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the provisions applying in Commonwealth legislation with respect to the appointment of industry representatives to statutory marketing corporations for primary products.
(2) Is it required that all such nominees should forgo their positions in farm organisations.
(3) Are there variations from corporation to corporation or to board; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The legislative provisions governing the appointment of industry representatives to the eleven primary industry statutory marketing authorities established by statutes which I administer are summarised below.
The appointment provisions for industry representatives are not uniform for all authorities but fall within the following broad categories:
appointed on either the nomination of an industry body/interest group or from a panel of names provided by an industry body/interest group
appointed on either the nomination of a State marketing board or State Minister
appointed upon election by a formal poll of qualified voters.

Generally speaking, the appointment provisions (see (1) above) reflect the different circumstances of each industry and the functions of the authority, including the extent to which the powers of the authority remove the rights of individual growers in respect of their products.
SUMMARY OF LEGISLATIVE PROVISIONS FOR APPOINTMENT OF INDUSTRY REPRESENTATIVES TO STATUTORY AGRICULTURAL MARKETING AUTHORITIES
Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act of 1977-Sections 19-29
Each member to represent livestock producers is appointed by me from among persons whose names are included in a list of names submitted by the Producer Consultative Group
Conflict of Interest Provision is at Section 29A (1) (2) (3)
Each member to represent the meat processors and exporters is appointed by me from among persons whose names are included in a list of names submitted by the Exporter and Abattoir Consultative Group
Australian Wheat Board Wheat Marketing Act 1979-Sections 29-35
Conflict of Interest Provision is at Section 35 (1)-(3)
Members representing wheat growers in a State are appointed by me through either of the following mechanisms
where there is a State Board (Qld, WA)-from among the members of the State Board; on the nomination of the State Board, or
if there is no State Board (NSW, Vic. or SA) after being elected by wheat growers in the State in accordance with the regulations
The finance member, the member representing flour mill owners and the member representing employees are appointed by me.
Conflict of Interest Provision is at Section 16 (2)-(4)
Members to represent woolgrowers are appointed by me on the nomination of the Wool Council of Australia
Conflict of Interest Provision is at Section 12 (1)-(4)
Members representing dairy farmers are appointed by me from among persons whose names have been submitted by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation or by another dairy farmers organisation
Members representing manufacturers of dairy produce are appointed by me from among persons whose names have been submitted by organisations of manufacturers of dairy produce
Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act 1973-Section 13
Conflict of Interest Provision is at Section 22
Each member representing apple and pear growers is appointed by me from persons nominated by the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association
Conflict of Interest Provision is at Section 28

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will quarantine precautions be taken against the B52s of the United States Air Force if and when they land in Darwin, Northern Territory: if so, what measures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Normal quarantine procedures will apply to all United States Air Force B52 aircraft arriving at Darwin, Northern Territory.

The usual quarantine measures are as follows: On arrival the aircraft is boarded by a Quarantine Officer and his assistants. The General Declaration prepared in advance by the captain of the aircraft is sighted and a visual examination made of the persons on board. The quarantine assistants disinsect both the aircraft cabin and holds. Vaccination certificates and other travel documents are examined for compliance with Australia's entry requirements.

When the Quarantine Officer is satisfied that the aircraft and all on board are not a source of infection, a certificate of pratique is granted. Until this time no goods (including refuse and unconsumed foodstuffs) can be landed and no persons are allowed to board the aircraft.

Following the granting of pratique refuse and unconsumed foodstuffs may be removed from the aircraft under quarantine supervision. Items of quarantine concern are not to be removed without the permission of the Quarantine Officer.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, South Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the state of the operating theatres at the Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, South Australia, which were built in 1942 but which have not been upgraded since.

(2) Does the small size of these theatres provide a number of serious problems, such as (a) increasing the potential for infection because it is difficult to prevent sterile drapes on the trays from being touched by staff who have to move in and out of the operating room and (b) necessitating the operating table to be placed diagonally across the room in certain major surgical procedures to allow X-ray machinery to be brought in.

(3) Are there too few theatres at the hospital which means that (a) they cannot be left to 'breathe' while being effectively cleaned between cases, (b) it is not possible to reserve at least one theatre for certain particular 'clean' cases and (c) it is frequently necessary for surgery to be performed on 'clean' cases straight after 'dirty' cases such as open bowel surgery thereby greatly increasing the likelihood of infection.
(4) Is the endoscopy room at the hospital where minor procedures are performed, often used for procedures for which it is not equipped, such as cardiac pacemaker insertion.

(5) Is the airconditioning in this room sub-standard, and does it result in the problems of (a) accumulation of dust and bacteria which cause particular concern in eye and ear surgery and (b) the likelihood that operating rooms are either too hot or too cold placing patients under anaesthesia at great risk from such temperature extremes.

(6) Are the floors of the operating theatres also sub-standard, and in particular, does the repeated lifting of the floor coverings and the pooling of water in certain areas create a situation encouraging the growth of bacteria.
(7) Have there been recent problems with the isolation of pathogenic organisms and are the measures taken only temporarily effective.
(8) Is there a hazardous communicating passage between the 2 main theatres which leads to the carriage of infection between theatres and cross-contamination.

(9) Is the recovery room far too small, being equipped for 4 patients but often having to cope with 7, so that patients have had to be left in the main corridor because no space has been available in the recovery room.

(10) Are there suitable areas for anaesthetising patients at the hospital; if not, do patients requiring local anaesthetics usually have these administered in the recovery room, next to patients who may be vomiting, coughing, et cetera thereby adding to the anxiety of the patients awaiting treatment, and are other patients undesirably exposed to the flurry and fright of being wheeled conscious into the operating theatre, against modern standards of surgical practice.
(11) Is some equipment at the hospital stored in corridors because the storage area is too small; if so, has some of this equipment been damaged because of this situation.

(12) Are surgical instruments crowded into cupboards which are totally inadequate for this purpose; if so, are there difficulties in maintenance and in the selection of particular items when they are suddenly and urgently required.

(13) Is there any area where out-patients awaiting surgery can comfortably sit and is there any suitable area where students and staff can be given instruction or teaching; if not, does this considerably limit educational possibilities.

(14) Is the development of a new operating theatre block at the hospital urgently required and paramount to the development of the hospital as a whole; if so, will the Minister approve this development as a matter of urgency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that the operating theatre block at the Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, was built in 1942. In 1963 a urology theatre was added and in 1975 the two major theatres were partially renovated to remove a number of deficiencies.
(2) (a) While the potential for infection does exist, extraordinary care is taken by the staff to preserve sterility of drapes on the trays during movement about the theatres and (b) Yes.

(3) (a) With the increase in the number of surgical cases in recent years it is necessary to maintain tighter control on theatre utilisation and ensure that sufficient time is available for staff to clean the theatres and to prevent any risk of 'dirty' cases causing infection in 'clean' cases, (b) Yes and (c) Careful and continuous monitoring of infection rates in surgical cases shows that cleaning and scheduling measures undertaken by the staff are effective and that there is no added risk to patients.

(4) Some selected procedures such as cardiac pacemaker insertion are performed in the endoscopy room. However, the surgeon undertaking these procedures ensures that precautions are taken to fully protect the patient.

(5) (a) The existing air conditioning system does create potential for infection. However, regular environmental monitoring is performed to ensure safe bacteriological conditions and (b) The existing air conditioning system does have difficulty maintaining full temperature control during heat wave conditions. Surgical sessions are cancelled when the operating theatres become too hot for surgery in order to avoid unnecessary risks to patients. The anaesthetists and theatre staff take all necessary precautions against the effects of temperature variation on patients.

(6) Problems with the theatre floor coverings have been detected in the regular and rigorous inspections of the theatres. However, preventative measures and close monitoring ensure that the potential for growth of bacteria is controlled.

(7) An organism was detected in the theatres on one occasion. However, this was quickly and effectively controlled. Continuous monitoring and adequate cleaning procedures ensure that the potential for growth of bacteria is adequately controlled.
(8) The two main operating theatres are in direct and open communication with each other, but care is taken to ensure that no cross-contamination occurs.

(9) Due to the limited size of the recovery room there are times when the number of surgical cases results in some overcrowding. However, when insufficient space is available, patients are returned to their ward where the necessary staff care is provided.

(10) Facilities for the anaesthetising of patients in the operating theatre complex are limited. However, despite this shortcoming, patients undergoing anaesthesia are not put at risk. On occasions it has been found necessary to use the recovery room for patients requiring local anaesthetic. It has also been found necessary on occasions to administer general anaesthesia to patients in the main operating theatres themselves. In these circumstances the staff are careful to minimise any possible distress to patients.

(11) Storage facilities in the operating theatre complex are inadequate and some equipment is stored in the main theatre corridors. Staff are careful to ensure that equipment is protected from damage.
(12) Equipment storage facilities are inadequate and some problems have been experienced. By careful attention to maintenance, this problem is minimised.
(13) Out-patient waiting facilities and areas for student teaching are limited within the operating theatres.
(14) New theatres are required and a proposal for replacement of the operating theatre complex is currently under consideration.
