ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Control of Pollution in the Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the Koppers timber processing firm is proposing to move to the Hume Industrial Estate; if so, what environmental controls will be applied.
(2) Are the environmental standards of the Australian Capital Territory lower than those which apply in New South Wales.
(3) What provisions exist in the Australian Capital Territory for control of (a) noise, (b) air, (c) water and (d) other forms of pollution.
(4) What powers does his Department have in the control of pollution in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In January 1980 Koppers (Aust.) Pty Ltd made formal application for the lease of a site at Hume suitable for a timber treatment and log processing plant. Negotiations are not yet concluded.

My Department and the National Capital Development Commission are aware of the potentially adverse environmental impact of such a plant. The proposal has therefore been the subject of close scrutiny and controls have been formulated to ensure that any adverse effect is minimised.
The controls cover the discharge of liquid wastes, noise emissions and air pollution. A monitoring program will be established to measure the effectiveness of the safeguards.

The controls will be embodied in the Crown Lease to ensure complete environmental protection in the interim period before the proposed Australian Capital Territory environmental protection legislation is promulgated. Adequate sanctions exist to ensure compliance with covenants of lease.

(2) While there is presently no comprehensive legislation controlling environmental pollution in the Australian Capital Territory, the need is recognised and draft legislation is being prepared based on the advice of an Inter-Departmental Committee on Environmental Quality. The standards will be similar in effect to those in force in New South Wales.
(3) The following Australian Capital Territory Ordinances and Regulations allow for limited control of forms of pollution:
the Animal Nuisance Control Ordinance 1975 covers noise emitted by animals;
the Inspection of Machinery Regulations made pursuant to the Machinery Ordinance 1949 sets noise levels above which the use of hearing protection devices is compulsory in the workplace;

the Motor Traffic Ordinance 1936 allows for the refusal of registration for a motor vehicle which emits excessive noise and provides that it is an offence to drive a motor vehicle which emits undue noise;
the Police Offences Ordinance 1930 provides that the emission of noise which causes undue disturbance is an offence;
the Small Claims Ordinance 1974 allows individuals to take action to have noise nuisance emitted by neighbours abated.

The Building Ordinance 1972 allows the Building Controller, in considering plans and specifications, to take into account whether the proposed structure makes adequate provision for the disposal of smoke, gas, fumes, and ash;

The New South Wales Smoke Abatement Act 1902, in its application to the Australian Capital Territory, provides that it is an offence for a person to use a furnace which has not been constructed so as to prevent the formation of smoke therein.
The Police Offences Ordinance 1930 provides that the dumping of dead animals and the diversion of water-courses, are offences;
The Cotter River Ordinance 1914 provides protection for the Cotter River catchment;
The Public Health (General Sanitation) Regulations made pursuant to the Public Health Ordinance 1928 provides for the protection of the water supply;
The Canberra Water Supply (Googong Dam) Act 1974 provides for the protection of that part of the Canberra water supply derived from the Googong Dam;
The Canberra Sewerage and Water Supply Regulations made pursuant to the Building and Services Ordinance 1924 provides that pollution of a stream which is part of the water supply is an offence;
The Lakes Ordinance 1976 provides that pollution of a lake and any stream, creek or river flowing into a lake is an offence.

(4) The legislation referred to in (3) is administered by the Minister for the Capital Territory apart from the Police Offences Ordinance administered by the Attorney-General, and the Public Health Ordinance administered by the Minister for Health. Various powers and procedures are available under the legislation which does apply:
Noise-The Registrar of Dogs has power under the Animal Nuisance Control Ordinance to make application to the Court for an order that an animal not be kept or that specified works be carried out.
The Chief Inspector of Machinery and Inspectors appointed under the Inspection of Machinery Regulations have power to enter any premises when machinery is in operation.

The Registrar of Motor Vehicles has power to refuse registration to a vehicle which does not comply with registration standards. The Police have normal powers to prosecute persons who operate a motor vehicle that emits undue noise.
The Police have normal powers of prosecution under the Police Offences Ordinance.
Air Pollution-The Building Controller has power to refuse approval for a structure under the Building Ordinance.
The Police or an owner or occupier of premises may bring an action under the New South Wales Smoke Nuisance Abatement Act.
Water Pollution-The Police have normal powers of prosecution under the Police Offences Ordinance;

The Capital Territory Health Commission, Medical Officers of Health and Inspectors have powers under the Public Health Ordinance and Public Health (General Sanitation) Regulations to prosecute offenders;

The National Capital Development Commission has power to plan and make provision for the prevention of pollution of water supplied or to be supplied from the Googong Dam under the Canberra Water Supply (Googong Dam) Act;
The Proper Authority appointed for the purposes of the Canberra Sewerage and Water Supply Regulations and the Minister have power to prosecute offenders;
The Minister for the Capital Territory or the Police have the power to prosecute offenders under the Lakes Ordinance.
In addition a power exists under many leases which enables a measure of control over various forms of pollution.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Re-targeting of Ballistic and Guided Missiles

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to President Carter's Directive 59 allowing re-targeting of ballistic and guided missiles to military rather than economic or population targets.

(2) Is he able to say whether this change from countervalue to counterforce or limited nuclear war strategy has been supported by increased accuracy or ice-pick capability in nuclear attacks against missile silos and missile control centres.

(3) Has the Government expressed its view on this initiation of nuclear strikes against nuclear emplacements (INSANE) policy as an alternative to the preceding mutually assured destruction (MAD) doctrine as a deterent to the arms race.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) See my answer to 18 September 1980 to Question on Notice No. 6374 (Hansard, page 1634) and my statement of 5 May 1981.

(2) Presidential Directive 59 does not constitute a change in US strategy from countervalue to counterforce. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Social Security Expenditures for OECD Countries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to provide the (a) gross national product, (b) social security expenditures and (c) the latter as a percentage of the former (defining (b) to include expenditures under public medical care systems and cash payments under public welfare programs including age, survivor, unemployment and disability insurance payments) for OECD countries; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A number of attempts have been made to compare different countries' spending on social security as a percentage of GDP or GNP.

Unfortunately such studies encounter a number of definitional and technical problems. These problems are discussed in an article 'International Comparisons of Social Security Expenditure', that appeared in Social Security Quarterly, Winter/Spring 1977, Vol. 5, No. 1.
International comparisons of social security expenditure may be misleading for a number of reasons.
comparisons generally include only direct public sector expenditure and do not include contributions towards welfare outside the public sector;
taxation concessions or deductions may be provided instead of or as well as cash payments;
other forms of subsidies towards living costs may not be included in the total of welfare expenditure;
differing economic circumstances (e.g. level of unemployment) will require differing levels of social security expenditure.

For these and other reasons international comparisons of social security expenditure are not only extremely difficult to make, but are of limited value for ascertaining the adequacy of such expenditure in meeting the welfare needs of communities.

Expenditure by OECD countries on education, income maintenance and health during the early 1960s and mid 1970s formed part of a study by the OECD in 1978 (Public Expenditure Trends, Studies in Resource Allocation, OECD, June 1978-see especially Table 6). However, the study warned that problems of data availability and their interpretation limit the conclusions which could be drawn. In addition, it was stressed that since the countries concerned differ in terms of their historical experience with public expenditure, their institutions, and their national tastes and values, caution should be exercised when basing conclusions on such international comparisons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Schools Commission recommend that the philosophy and general application of integration practice should be the subject of continuing research.
(2) If so, what provision has been made to initiate this research.
(3) How do the approaches of the various State Departments of Education differ in respect of integration of handicapped children.

(4) Does the Schools Commission advocate investigation of ways in which the Commonwealth may assist in the early identification of disabilities in children and intervention to correct disabilities where possible.
(5) Is this function being performed by ANSUA.
(6) Will the Schools Commission investigate the work of ANSUA.

(7) What activities have been undertaken during the International Year of Disabled Persons in respect of the following educational programs: (a) training of special education teachers, (b) provision of support personnel, (c) attention to the educational environment, (d) extension of the age range for the education of handicapped young people, (e) early intervention, (f) transition programs, (g) integration into regular schools, (h) provision for isolated handicapped students and (j) educational services for severely handicapped children who are homebound or who live long-term in residential institutions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) In its Report for the Triennium 1982-84 the Schools Commission has undertaken to foster research on the integration of handicapped children into regular schools.

(3) As described in the Schools Commission's Report for the Triennium 1982-84 the diverse approaches of the various State Departments of Education in respect of integration of handicapped children include:
(a) the establishment of a flexible placement system which seeks appropriate educational provision for all students;
(b) provision of appropriate education within a wide range of schooling options rather than the adoption of integration as the ultimate goal for all handicapped students;
(c) working to a policy of meeting students' needs with their peers at neighbourhood schools with as little restriction as possible;
(d) maintaining all students, except the moderately, severely and multiply handicapped in regular schools;
(e) the provision of segregated special schools which work towards preparing handicapped students for future social integration in the community.
(4) In its Report for the Triennium 1982-84 the Schools Commission undertakes to investigate ways in which the Commonwealth may assist in early intervention programs.
(6) The Schools Commission advises that its proposed investigation will include a study of the work undertaken by such organisations as ANSUA.
(7) During the International Year of Disabled Persons activities which have been undertaken in respect of the following educational programs include:

(a) Training of special education teachers-No specific activities have been undertaken by the Schools Commission. However, funding for such activities is available under the Commission's Services and Development Program.

(b) Provision of support personnel-Basically this is a matter for State education authorities. However, funding available under the Schools Commission's Special Education Program for special schools and classes, integration and the development of programs for severely handicapped children may be used for this purpose.

(c) Attention to the educational environment-Funds available to special schools under the Schools Commission's Capital Grants Program can be used for the provision and improvement of buildings and equipment.
During International Year of Disabled Persons the Schools Commission is funding:

a national co-operative study, involving government and the larger non-government education authorities, of the school facilities required to meet the needs of handicapped children in special and regular schools;
a national conference to focus on facilities required for handicapped school children.

(d) Extension of the age range for the education of handicapped young people-No Commonwealth funds are available for this purpose through Schools Commission funding. However, recommendations for such an extension have been made in the report on the national survey of special education undertaken for the Schools Commission by the Schonell Educational Research Centre.
(e) Early intervention-The Schools Commission has undertaken in its Report for the Triennium 1982-84 to investigate ways in which the Commonwealth may assist in early intervention programs.

(f) Transition programs-The Schools Commission has drawn attention in its Report for the Triennium 1982-84 to an increasing interest in transition training for adolescent students, an interest which is characteristic of most schools, including special schools. The Schools Commission supports developments in the States and Territories which include the framing of policies on work experience and vocational training; the provision of training in independent living skills and techniques; vocational counselling; and the provision of pre-vocational and vocational courses, daily living skill courses and access courses for vocational study by Colleges of Technical and Further Education.

(g) Integration into regular schools-In 1981 the Government is making available through the Schools Commission's Special Education Program $1.059 million for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools.

(h) Provision for isolated handicapped students-In its Report for the Triennium 1982-84 the Schools Commission has drawn attention to the needs of isolated handicapped children and it has made such children eligible for funding to attend neighbourhood regular schools under the integration program.

(j) Educational services for severely handicapped children who are homebound or who live long-term in residential institutions-In 1981 the Commonwealth Government has made $2.118 million available for the development of educational programs for severely handicapped children.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to (a) an article by Jan Mayman in the National Times, 15-21 March 1981 (page 4), pointing out hazards of the use of Depo-Provera as a contraceptive and (b) the reported banning of the drug in the United States of America.

(2) If so, will the Minister take steps (a) to recommend to Australian doctors that the drug not be used for Aboriginal women and (b) to ensure that special efforts be made in advising them to ensure that they (i) understand the available alternatives, (ii) have an opportunity to discuss these with an informed person who can communicate effectively with them, with time to make an informed choice, especially in view of the reported high incidence among Aborigines of diabetes and other conditions which allegedly increase the hazards of use of the drug.

(3) If the Minister will not take these actions, will he request that all users of Depo-Provera for contraception be recorded for statistical analysis of (a) safety, (b) side-effects and (c) reliability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I am informed that Depo-Provera has been available on the Australian market for many years for use in certain indications but not including use as a contraceptive. The Australian Drug Evaluation Committee which advises my colleague, the Minister for Health, on matters relating to the importation and distribution of drugs in Australia, has considered progressively available information on Depo-Provera for contraceptive use on a number of occasions. The Committee is of the opinion that this use of the drug must be regarded as investigational since there are unresolved questions related to its safety for this indication. This statement is included in the product information distributed by the Company for this drug.

As with any drug which is regarded as investigational, ethics dictate that, where the medical practitioner is of the opinion that special circumstances warrant the use of such a drug, there is a responsibility on his part both for adequately informing the patient or the guardian, and for any adverse consequences of the therapy.

In regard to 'informed consent', I appreciate that special care is required in respect of Aboriginal patients. My Department encourages additional training in cultural matters for doctors and other medical professionals who propose to work in areas where there is a significant Aboriginal population and supports the provision of orientation and in-service courses. In addition, most State Health Departments, often with Commonwealth support, employ Aboriginal Health Workers, several hundreds in all, who have important liaison roles. Both of these measures are designed to achieve the quality of communication necessary to ensure that Aboriginal patients are at ease with and have clear understanding in, their contacts with health care personnel.
(3) I have brought the honourable member's suggestion to the notice of my colleague, the Minister for Health.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States Tariff on Imports of Raw Wool

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken to obtain reductions of the United States of America tariff on imports of raw wool during the last 3 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: One of the Government's main objectives during the recent Multilateral Trade Negotiations was to obtain a substantial reduction in the wool tariff in the United States of America. The USA is the only major industrialised country to maintain a duty on raw wool imports.
The Government was successful in securing a 60 per cent reduction in the tariff on raw apparel wool-the maximum reduction that the US Administration was empowered to offer.
This reduction is being phased in over three years, from 25.5 cents per lb (clean equivalent) to 10 cents per lb. Phasing commenced on 1 January 1980 and the current rate of duty is 15 cents per lb.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What central classification committees have been appointed under the Public Service Act during the last 5 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: None. Although great use was made of these Committees in the immediate post-war years and through the 1950's, they have not been used since the early 1960's. The establishment and continuing review of employment groups in the Service, following the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decisions in the Professional Engineers' Case in 1961, the broadbanding of classification structures, and the tendency to take to arbitration those classification issues which could not be resolved by conciliation, has created a situation in which the establishment of Central classification Committees has not been warranted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to a comment in the 1979-80 Annual Report of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission that unless economies in the conduct of cases be practised by such (private legal) practitioners it is probable that State and Territory Commissions and other legal aid authorities will be obliged to rely to a greater extent on the services of salaried lawyers, especially in criminal trials.
(2) Does this trend accord with Government policy; if not, what is being done to reverse the trend.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) It has always been the Government's view that legal aid should be provided by both private legal practitioners and salaried lawyers. The legislation establishing the State and Australian Capital Territory Commissions provide accordingly. The Government, however, does maintain a continuing scrutiny of the effectiveness of existing arrangements for the provision of legal aid, so that funds can be most effectively, efficiently, and economically applied. The Government has provided funds for a cost comparison study between salaried and private lawyers. This study is expected to be completed later this year, and the results will be closely considered. It should be noted that all State and Territory Commissions are independent statutory authorities and hence it will be primarily for those Commissions to decide whether any changes should be made to existing arrangements.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Air Traffic Controllers have retired on invalidity grounds in each of the last 5 years.
(2) What was the nature of their disabilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Cardio-vascular conditions-7; Ear, nose and throat conditions-2; Eye conditions-4; Stomach and other viscera conditions-3; Neurological conditions-5; Orthopaedic conditions-5; Peripheral vascular condition-1; Psychiatric conditions-32; Insufficient information readily available to provide confident categorisation-20.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Domestic Airlines: Cost of Travel Concessions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the cost to each major Australian domestic airline of travel concessions granted to their staffs.
(2) By what percentage are domestic air fares higher than if the staff travel concessions did not apply.
(3) Has he or his Department examined the question of staff travel concessions; if so, what were the conclusions and what action resulted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is negligible cost as staff travel for both Ansett and TAA is taken on a stand-by basis or undertaken at off-peak periods.
(2) Domestic air fares are no higher because of staff travel entitlements.

(3) No. Staff travel entitlements for both Ansett and TAA are the prerogative of the Company and the Commission respectively and individual concessions are negotiated between staff members and their respective employers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What investigations were made by the Commonwealth or Tasmanian Governments into the use of commercial laundry services prior to the decision to construct a new laundry for the Launceston General Hospital.
(2) If investigations were made, who conducted them and what was the result; if there were no investigations, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Tasmanian Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in its hearings into the proposal for a group laundry at the Launceston General Hospital received oral and written submissions from the Textile Care and Rental Association of Tasmania supporting the use of commercial laundry services at Launceston. After considering the submissions and evidence and hearing evidence from the Tasmanian Department of Health Services and a special laundry consultant appointed by the Tasmanian Department of Health Services, the Committee concluded-

'The Committee does not think that commercial laundries are the right solution to future increased demand even though their premises could be expanded. It is felt that there is validity in the opinion that, as far as possible, laundry should be serviced and treated on a hospital site where there are laboratory facilities for testing bacteriological problems and adequate specialised supervision.'

The Committee went on to recommend that a new group laundry be built at Launceston. This recommendation was accepted by the Tasmanian Parliament. The conclusion and recommendation are in line with general practice adopted by Commonwealth and State health authorities for the provision of laundry services for hospitals; approximately 95 per cent of hospital laundry is handled by specialist laundries.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Smuggling of Plant Material into Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the statement in the 1979-80 Annual Report of his Department (page 19) that there appears to have been an increase in deliberate attempts to smuggle plant material into Australia, which offences were prosecuted during 1979-80.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During 1979-80 229 successful prosecutions were launched against passengers deliberately attempting to smuggle plant material into Australia.
During the six months January-June 1980 there were 126 successful prosecutions. This compared with 73 over the corresponding period during 1979.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken on the recommendation of the Commissioner for Community Relations contained in his 5th Annual Report for the year 1979-80 (page 88), that trainee teachers should remain at their studies for a further period to acquire some knowledge of a community language and culture, and thus take their place as members of a new multicultural teaching force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The recommendation in the Commissioner for Community Relations' 5th Annual Report (page 88) to extend the formal training period of trainee teachers was, in another form, considered by the National Inquiry into Teacher Education (NITE). The NITE Report recommended, inter alia, four years initial pre-service training for all teachers. This recommendation, in the light of developments in the most recent years, was not supported by the Ministers for Education meeting as the Australian Education Council in February 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a loan been made to the YMCA of Canberra Incorporated; if so, for what sum and why was it granted.
(2) What are the interest and repayment terms and what security is there in regard to the loan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A loan was made to the YMCA of Canberra for $2,171,114.31, to finance the construction of a 200 bed young people's hostel at Belconnen.

The first payment of $45,000 against the loan was made on 2 June 1975 and subsequent payments were advanced as required during the course of construction. The final payment was made on 22 February 1977. Under the terms of the lease, the first repayment instalment did not become due until 23 February 1979.

(2) Interest was chargeable at the rate of 5 per cent per annum compounded half yearly with repayments to be made six monthly over a period of 48 1/2 years. If, however, payments were made by the due date, a rebate of 1 per cent per annum was allowable on the interest rate i.e., the effective rate became 4 per cent per annum. However, the YMCA's liability in respect of the loan was extinguished in full on 2 February 1981 upon the surrender of the lease.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken by his Department on the recommendation of the Commissioner for Community Relations in his 5th Annual Report, for 1979-80, concerning the provision of public housing appropriate to the needs, values and lifestyles of Aboriginal people in all States and the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There is only one aboriginal community within the jurisdiction of the Minister for the Capital Territory, located at Wreck Bay in the Jervis Bay Territory.
20 government homes were provided at Wreck Bay during the 1940s and are occupied by members of the community on a rental basis.

In 1973 the community formed the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Housing Company Ltd to negotiate with the Commonwealth for a lease of land for the community. In 1975 the Company accepted an offer of lease, but subsequently lodged a list of additional claims rejecting the previously accepted offer.
Negotiations have continued since that time but the matter is still unresolved. Two major obstacles are the community's claims for:
freehold title (which the Commonwealth is specifically prohibited by legislation from granting in the Australian Capital Territory or Jervis Bay Territory) and
exclusive fishing rights to waters adjoining the land offered for lease.
An Ordinance was made in 1977 to enable the grant of a perpetual lease to the Company.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has over the past few years provided funds to the Company for the construction of additional houses and other improvements. When negotiations for a lease are finalised I understand that Department will assume full responsibility for funding of the Aboriginal community at Wreck Bay.

Apart from housing at Wreck Bay Government housing assistance in the Australian Capital Territory in the form of rental housing, rental rebates for government tenants on low incomes, and finance to assist with the purchase of government or private dwellings is available to Aboriginal people who live or work in the Australian Capital Territory under precisely the same conditions as it is available to other members of the Australian Capital Territory community. It is considered that such assistance is appropriate to the needs, values and life styles of Aboriginal people in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Fund Commission Land Purchases

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the 216 individual properties throughout Australia listed by the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission following the Land Need Conference of August 1978.
(2) Does the list, as viewed by the Aboriginal Land Fund commission in its Annual Report for 1978-79, provide a basis for land purchase for a long time to come.
(3) Has the list been passed on to the Australian Aboriginal Development Commission; if so, how is it being viewed by the Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Aboriginal Development Commission has asked that the individual properties listed at the Land Needs Conference of August 1978 should not be made public, because this could prejudice its negotiations to buy properties. A summary of the types of properties in each State which were listed at the Conference was published in the Annual Report of the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission for 1978-79.

(2) and (3) The documents from the 1978 Conference have been passed to the Aboriginal Development Commission. The Aboriginal Land Fund Commission and its successor body, the Aboriginal Development Commission, have regarded the needs identified by the Land Needs Conference of August 1978 as an important basis for the land acquisition program. The priorities established at the 1978 Conference have been modified, however, in the light of subsequent developments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Sports Centre at Bruce, Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is an aquatic centre to be constructed as part of stage 3 of the National Sports Centre at Bruce, Australian Capital Territory.
(2) What is unsatisfactory in the use of the Commonwealth pool at Deakin, or any other Commonwealth pool in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There has been no decision to construct an aquatic centre at the National Sports Centre at Bruce, Australian Capital Territory.

(2) The Deakin Pool, currently being used by the Australian Institute of Sport for training of its swimmers has adequate facilities for this purpose. It is, however, some distance from the Institute and the support facilities. For this reason, it is viewed as unsuitable as a training venue in the long term. Furthermore, the Deakin Swimming Pool is a public swimming facility but at those times when the pool is in use by Institute swimmers, the public is denied access to it. The same situation would arise with any other pool in the Australian Capital Territory being used as a training facility by Institute swimmers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Cultural Corporation of Australia Ltd

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the $250,000 provided towards establishment of the International Cultural Corporation of Australia Ltd. a grant or loan; if a loan, under what terms and conditions.
(2) Is future subsidising of the Corporation by the Commonwealth proposed; if so, at what levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An amount of $250,000 was provided by the Commonwealth to the Corporation in 1979-80 as a contribution. A similar contribution was provided in 1980-81.

(2) Further funding of the Corporation is subject to annual Budget consideration. However, when the Corporation was established, it was announced that the Government expected that the Corporation would gradually become self-supporting.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Film and Television School: Liability for Pension Costs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the liability of the Australian Film and Television School to the Commonwealth by way of employer contributions for increased pension costs during the period 1973 to 1976 been determined; if so, what is the liability and how will it be met; If not, when is the liability to be assessed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Australian Film and Television School meets its employer superannuation liability in accordance with the Superannuation Act 1976. Payments are made to the Commonwealth in respect of those employees who are contributors to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. The rate of contribution paid by the Australian Film and Television School and a number of other Authorities does not take account of the cost of pension up-dating. An actuarial assessment is being obtained of the extent to which the present contribution rate differs from that required to meet the full accruing superannuation liability (including the cost of up-dating). This assessment is not expected to be available for some time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of the Treasury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduces its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent, by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes. STD 'barring' on telephone extensions used by officers not having an essential or demonstrated need to make official long distance calls has been in operation in Treasury since July 1980. On these telephone extensions, officers wishing to make long distance calls must place them through switchboard operators. The officer is subsequently notified of the charges incurred in making personal calls and the cost is recouped by the Department. A large majority of Treasury telephone extensions have STD bars.
(3) Yes. It is considered that the present controls are adequate.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Defence

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent, by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The existence of telephone call monitoring devices such as the one referred to in the West Australian of 18 July 1979 is known to the Department and Telecom. Similar devices (eg ''PETRA'') are being used but are of limited usefulness because of insistence by the Telecom Unions on limiting the data provided by these devices to protect the privacy of the individual.
(2) Measures adopted by my Department to minimise use of departmental telephone services on private calls include:
granting of STD access only to a relatively few senior officers who have clearly recognisable functional requirement.

further restriction of STD access will occur following introduction of the Defence National Automatic Telephone System later this year. This system will allow direct dialling between Defence establishments using a hired tie line network;
control of trunk line and STD traffic through the Department's PABX operators in respect of the vast majority of personnel; ie those not having STD access;

frequent issue of circulars and reminders in telephone directories of the necessity to limit private calls to emergency situations. Where trunk calls are involved the costs are recovered from the callers; and
installation of STD public telephones at Defence establishments to enable personnel to make private calls at their own cost.
(3) If devices become available on the market that are more effective than those already available my Department will consider using them.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Social Security

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metrolpolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent by use of a monitoring device which recorded length time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of the Department of Social Security controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in the Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) All staff of the Department of Social Security are advised by way of standing office instructions that personal telephone calls are to be kept to a minimum and only made with prior approval of a supervisor.
Officers wishing to make a personal long distance call do so by booking the call through their local switchboard operator and are required to reimburse the Department for the cost of the call.

Because of the decentralised nature of the Department (operating out of nearly 200 locations throughout the metropolitan areas and major country centres) there is a constant need for staff to use STD facilities in the normal course of their duties. This requirement considerably complicates the arrangements necessary to bar access to STD processes. Nevertheless the Department has installed STD access barring in those offices where it is administratively practicable and cost efficient and where the switchboard equipment is compatible. As non-suitable switchboard equipment is progressively replaced, access barring will be extended.

(3) Due to the decentralised nature of the Department, it is felt that the number of monitoring devices that would need to be purchased and the staff resources that would be required to co-ordinate, investigate and report on monitored details would not be cost effective and in some instances, particularly in remote regional offices, could prove to be counter-productive.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Transport

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent, by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No I have not heard of the report mentioned by the honourable member; however, I will endeavour to obtain a copy.

(2) Personal calls made by officers of my Department are controlled by departmental Administrative Instructions which restrict local private calls to a minimum. Private trunk calls may be authorised and costs are recouped from the officer making the call. Central Office, Canberra, telephones generally are STD access barred with access being restricted to senior officers and special areas able to satisfy a rigorous test of essentiality, e.g. computer links and special operational areas. Those elements of Central Office presently located in Melbourne are accommodated in several buildings. Where technically feasible STD access has been restricted on the same scale as Canberra but some areas cannot be access barred because of the age of switchboard equipment. These areas are monitored with the Telecom Australia PETRA, (PBX Extension Traffic Recorder and Analyser) device which has been found to be effective in reducing unauthorised STD traffic.

Most Regional Offices of the Department are access barred on the same basis as Central Office. The exception is the South Australia/Northern Territory Regional Office in Adelaide where technical considerations make access barring impracticable. Monitoring equipment has been used from time to time and a new PABX due to be installed by September 1981 will allow permanent access barring on the same basis as Central Office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the purpose of the uniform allowance of 58 cents per day paid to Naval Petty Officers to meet the cost of cleaning and maintenance only.
(2) If so, is the replacement cost of new 8-button uniforms for Petty Officers to be borne by the Navy or by the Naval officer concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Uniform maintenance allowance, which is paid at a rate of 58 cents a day to Petty Officers, is provided to defray the cost of periodic replacement of items of uniform so that the member's inventory is to the approved scale of items in good order and condition.

(2) As the new uniform does not change in design or colour from the uniform it is replacing, the change-over is being effected over a period that has regard to the normal life expectancy of a uniform. The members involved will therefore be required to meet the replacement cost of the new uniforms from their uniform maintenance allowance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that his Department and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs have been co-operating to provide Health Program Grants to community-based, community-controlled Aboriginal medical services.

(2) Did the Director-General of Health say, in a letter dated 17 October 1978 to some community-controlled Aboriginal medical services, that the grants were offered to them as an alternative to bulk billing arrangements, that such an offer would be given as an option and further that there was no compulsion on a service to accept funding through the grants.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the criteria governing the availability of Health Program Grants to community-controlled Aboriginal medical services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On 17 October 1978 Health Program Grants were offered to the ten established Aboriginal controlled medical services to meet the salary and associated costs of staff involved in the clinical activities. Other costs are met by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The arrangement was introduced against the then possible non-continuance of bulk billing which would have adversely affected the Services concerned. Acceptance of a Health Program Grant precludes continuance of bulk billing for medical services and avoids double payment which would otherwise be the case. Economic restraints preclude the expansion of the arrangement to other more recently established services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What guidelines does the Government use with respect to the availability of Health Program Grants and how have they been applied in relation to 1980-81 funding from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to community-controlled Aboriginal medical services.
(2) How will it affect funding to those services who choose to continue bulk billing funding in 1981-82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In October 1978 my Department offered Health Program Grants to each of the then 10 established Aboriginal Medical Services as an alternative to bulk billing. In 1980-81 Health Program Grant funds have been made available to 8 of these services, with negotiations continuing in respect of another. These grants are to meet the salary and associated costs of staff involved in clinical activities, with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs providing the necessary funds to meet administrative and other residual costs.
(2) Services which continue to use bulk billing will need to negotiate with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in regard to the residual funding required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Australian of 8 April 1981, that Dr John MacKay has provisionally diagnosed radiation sickness in 16 persons connected with a plane crash on 4 December 1980.
(2) Has the NSW Director of Public Health Services discounted the diagnosis on the grounds that blood tests done on policemen who claimed exposure to contamination were negative.

(3) Is he able to say what tests were done, what were the results, what investigations should have been done and what tests should now be done to eliminate the possibility of radiation sickness developing.
(4) Is he able to say what evidence the policemen gave to substantiate their claims.

(5) Have steps been taken to standardise monitoring of radiation hazards in Australia and to centralise responsibility for enforcing radiation safeguards at Australian Government level; if so, what are they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However the incident referred to occurred on a highway in New South Wales when a semi-trailer carrying a mixed cargo was involved in an accident. The cargo included two radioactive sources. These sources were properly packaged, were not breached in the accident and did not constitute a radiation hazard.

(2), (3) and (4) The authority responsible for this matter is the New South Wales Health Commission which has investigated the incident thoroughly. I understand that the Commission is entirely satisfied that the radiation consequences were negligible.

(5) When radiation accidents do occur local radiation monitoring is always carried out by the appropriate State or Territory health authority. National radiation safety standards have been developed under the aegis of the National Health and Medical Research Council and are, in fact, applied uniformly throughout Australia under the relevant health legislation prevailing in each State or Territory.

My Department maintains a national registry of radiation incidents through the Australian Radiation Laboratory. Whenever a significant radiation incident occurs the relevant health authority provides a detailed summary of its history and consequences to the Australian Radiation Laboratory. The Laboratory arranges for its circulation to warn of potential circumstances which may lead to similar incidents in the future.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Access for New Zealand Butter and Cheese to the Australian Market

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he been giving consideration to a submission by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation in which they ask (a) that the Australian Government formalise at government to government level the presently existing informal agreement permitting access for New Zealand butter and cheese producers to the Australian market and (b) that the Commonwealth Government exclude dairy products from any phased reduction of trade barriers between Australia and New Zealand.
(2) If so, will he indicate (a) were and (b) in what way the Australian Government will act on those recommendations.
(3) If he will not provide this information, what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) The Government is mindful of the concern which has been expressed by Australian dairy farmers about the implications of moves towards a closer economic relationship with New Zealand including for example, the potential for trade in dairy products from New Zealand to undermine Australia's domestic marketing arrangements. Special attention is being given to such matters as the impact of dairy support and stabilization schemes in the two countries on trading opportunities for dairy products within the context of a closer economic relationship.

The Prime Minister emphasised in his statement to Parliament following his talks with Prime Minister Muldoon in March 1980 that no commitment to any specific proposal had been entered into at that stage and that no decisions would be taken until a detailed examination has been completed and there had been full consultation with interested parties including State Governments and industries.

Consultations with State Governments, farming and industry groups have been underway since April 1980 with views being sought by the Commonwealth on a number of occasions. The views of the Australian Dairy Farmers' Federation have been noted and are being borne in mind in the negotiations with New Zealand.

The guiding principle, enunciated by the Australian Government, is that it would not contemplate entering into any new trading arrangements with New Zealand except on the basis of equality of fair trading opportunities between industries in the two countries. The Prime Minister and myself have stated publicly on a number of occasions that the Government will not allow Australian agricultural industries to be adversely affected by unfair competition from New Zealand.

Senior Australian and New Zealand officials discussed closer economic relations in Wellington on 11 and 12 March 1981. This meeting was held against the background of recent consideration of the issues by Australian Ministers and separately by New Zealand Ministers. The objective of the discussions was to ensure a full understanding of ministerial attitudes on both sides and to clarify differences in position. Resolution of such differences will be necessary before details of any proposed new arrangements can be made public. I should like to emphasise that the Government has given an undertaking that no substantive decisions will be taken on this matter until full and meaningful consultations have been held with all interested parties.

Further discussions on closer trade and economic links were held 11-13 May 1981 in Wellington, New Zealand between my colleague the Minister for Trade and Resources and the New Zealand Prime Minister and senior New Zealand Ministers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation: Contributions to Bjelke-Petersen Foundation Fund

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he state in reply to a question without notice on 28 May 1979 (Hansard, page 2429) that the National Party of Queensland or any other branch of a political party in Australia will not be given any privilege under the tax law.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to recent statements made in the Queensland Parliament that the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation Fund involves schemes whereby donations up to $100,000 are paid to the fund in return for which advertisements are featured in the Foundation's journal National Outlook.
(3) Are companies or businesses which contribute to such a scheme eligible for full tax deductions.
(4) If so, does this constitute a tax loophole by which donations to political parties might be tax deductible.
(5) Does this continued practice conflict with his statement that no political party would be given any privilege under the tax law.
(6) If so, will he act to close this tax loophole and advise the National Party in Queensland of his decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Not specifically, but I am aware that from time to time there have been statements linking donations to the Fund with advertising in the journal.

(3) I am advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that, under the general deduction provisions of the income tax law, any amount outlaid by a company or a business for more than one purpose is tax deductible only to the extent that it relates to a purpose of producing assessable income or is necessarily incurred in carrying on a business to produce assessable income. I am also advised that if the circumstances are that what is really, e.g., a non-deductible gift is merely characterised as being a business outgoing, no deduction is available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the publication of the employment series 'Civilian Employees', compiled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, suspended as from April 1980; if so what is the reason.
(2) Has any decision been taken on the future publication of this series.
(3) Is there any review of this series currently being undertaken.
(4) If so, (a) what is the nature of this review and (b) when will it be completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Statistician has advised that the suspended publication of the Civilian Employees series following the release of the April 1980 issue, because the estimates, particularly on a year-to-year basis, showed a marked inconsistency with other available data.
(2), (3) and (4) A team of senior ABS officers has reviewed all aspects of the Civilian Employees series and an announcement is expected to be made in the near future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, in addition to the problems caused by the growing tax avoidance industry, another main reason for high taxation rates under this Government is the cash economy, resulting in hundreds of thousands of transactions upon which tax should be payable not being recorded.

(2) Is the Government taking action to include the taxable income of these tax evaders in the assessable net so that other law-abiding citizens can have their tax obligations reduced; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I think it must be accepted that tax evasion resulting from unrecorded transactions that go to make up the 'cash' or 'underground' economy has a bearing on the rates of income tax. The taxation laws are, of course, designed to raise a substantial portion of the revenue necessary to meet essential Government expenditure. As a general proposition, therefore, indulgence by some sections of the community in tax evasion practices, whether through participation in the cash economy or not, would increase the taxation burden borne by the general body of taxpayers who comply with the revenue laws.

I do not accept, however, the implication in the honourable Member's question that taxation rates under this Government are higher than those under previous Governments and draw his attention to the personal income tax reforms introduced by this Government since coming to power.

(2) The Commissioner of Taxation has informed me that Taxation Office enforcement programmes covering investigation and audit activities are directed essentially at the detection of unreported transactions. These activities entail examinations of the affairs of taxpayers, including those engaged in illegal activities, with a view to detecting income not disclosed in income tax returns. Special techniques are employed to detect unreported income, including a process under which the assets accumulated by a taxpayer over a period of time are quantified together with other amounts of expenditure. Such examinations have, the Commissioner said, been successful in recovering substantial amounts of tax which would otherwise have been lost to the revenue. Enforcement activities also include action to detect persons who are obliged, but who have failed, to lodge income tax returns. Experience has shown that persons found to be evading tax through non-lodgment of returns are, more often than not, participants in the cash economy.
A detailed account of the results achieved from all Taxation Office enforcement programmes was contained in the Commissioner's 59th Report to Parliament.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Following the construction of the Dartmouth Dam, Victoria, what arrangements have been made to protect the future of the Barmah and other major Australian red gum forests along the Murray River from (a) flooding in late summer and autumn when the controlled flow of the Murray is increased to provide water for South Australia, but which will endanger the future of the forests and (b) lack of natural flooding in late winter and spring when water is being stored for late summer and autumn release to South Australia, which will endanger the future of the forests.
(2) What quantity of water is required to satisfactorily flood the forests in New South Wales and Victoria, and if there is no natural flooding, from which States' quota will this water be obtained.
(3) When were the forests last satisfactorily flooded in spring and how often should these floods occur to maintain the health of the forests.
(4) Are the forests currently being flooded; if so, when were they last flooded in autumn.
(5) For how long and how often can this flooding occur in autumn before the forests are endangered.
(6) When and how will the Barmah Choke section of the River be partially by-passed or its capacity be increased to allow the post-Dartmouth autumn flows to be contained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) At the end of July last year, the River Murray Commission released for public comment a report which identifies river regulation and related forest management problems along the River Murray between Tocumwal and Echuca, associated with the Barmah-Millewa forests. The report examines a number of possible measures to alleviate the problems. Solutions to some of the problems fall outside the Commission's area of responsibility. However, I understand that submissions received from a number of individuals and organisations are under consideration prior to the Commission deciding on what future action it can take to remedy any problems.

(2) As indicated in the report, forest managers estimate that effective watering would require the maintenance at Tocumwal of a flow of at least 24,500 megalitres per day for about one month during the winter-spring period or a consumptive use of about 100,000 megalitres of water on each side of the river in any one year; at this stage, this is a matter for the decision of the State concerned.

(3) According to River Murray streamflow records maintained by the Commission, the criteria suggested in (2) above were last met in the spring of 1978. Forest interests maintain that prior to intensive regulation of the Murray River for irrigation, winter and spring flooding over most parts of the forests occurred in about 4 out of 5 years and that this regime should be restored by artificial means.

(4) No; I understand that minor flooding of relatively small areas of the forests, but sufficient to limit access, has occurred on two occasions during the current autumn season due to temporary high river flows when irrigation diversions from Lake Mulwala were temporarily interrupted because of rain. Some foresters have stated that under the prevailing dry conditions such minor flooding is beneficial to the forests.

(5) and (6) I understand that the River Murray Commission is reasonably confident that significant containment of summer/autumn flooding can be achieved and such flooding is not likely to pose any great threat to the health of the forests. I also understand that a by-pass measure proposed in the Commission's report, i.e., the use of Mulwala Canal to by-pass water around the Barmah forest reach of the river, has already been successfully put into effect. Investigations are also proceeding on the need for channel maintenance work to improve the channel carrying capacity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he satisfied that the granting of the contract for daily surveillance of the north-west coastline to the eastern States-based operator, H. C. Sleigh, will be in the best interests of both Australia's need for surveillance and the needs of north-west Australian residents for a complete aviation service.
(2) Was H. C. Sleigh told by an officer of Transport Australia early in January 1981 that they would be getting the contract.
(3) Was Trans-West told that there was still no decision on this tender process, as recently as Monday, 30 March 1981.

(4) Is it a fact that H. C. Sleigh have no agreement between themselves and Trans-West to obtain a maintenance service despite the fact that in the tender produced by H. C. Sleigh, such a service was said to be involved.
(5) Is H. C. Sleigh now endeavouring to operate the service out of Broome, WA, instead of Derby, WA, because of accommodation difficulties in Derby.
(6) If such a relocation is to be permitted will he call fresh tenders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The criteria taken into account in the selection process were those relating to the performance of the specified coastal surveillance task. I am satisfied that the most suitable offer was accepted.

(4) I understand that at the time the tender was submitted by H. C. Sleigh such an arrangement was in existence, although it was not mentioned in the tender. I understand also that the arrangement was terminated by Trans-West after the coastal surveillance contract was awarded to H. C. Sleigh. The successful tenderer has now made satisfactory alternative maintenance arrangements at no additional cost to the Commonwealth.
(5) and (6) H. C. Sleigh did seek the consent of my Department to operate from Broome rather than Derby. This request was refused.

The Company was informed that there would be no objection to aircraft and crews being based in Broome and ferried to Derby for operations provided the Company met all expenses consequent upon such a decision.
I understand that H. C. Sleigh has now decided to continue to base its operations in respect of this portion of the contract at Derby.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cost of Reducing Age for Eligibility for the Male Age Pension

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

(2) Did my question at any stage suggest a change in the means test at present in force for age pensioners aged 65.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the inspectorate functions of the Northern Zone Export Section of the Fisheries Division of his Department.
(2) How many staff were being employed in the Northern Zone Export Section as at 30 June of each year since 1975 and in what capacity was each staff member employed.
(3) How many boats were (a) inspected and (b) tested in each of the same years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The functions of the northern zone of the export fish inspection service are the same as the other zones which together form an integrated administrative scheme designed to ensure the effective deployment and organisation of export fish inspection staff on a regional basis.

The overriding objective of export inspection service is to ensure that product subject to the Exports (Fish) Regulations meets prescribed conditions and restrictions. In particular, export establishments are required to be constructed and equipped to operate in an efficient and hygienic manner; and products are required to be of an acceptable quality and accurately described. Constant monitoring of registered land based premises and registered vessels is undertaken to ensure the maintenance of standards.

(2) Prior to the formation of the export fish inspection service in 1977, all fish exports inspection duties were undertaken by meat inspectors on an ad hoc basis. A northern zone as such did not exist. The position in respect of staff employed in the northern zone as at 30 June of each year since 1977, and the capacity in which they were employed, is as follows:
Fish Exports Inspector, Grade 3 1 1 1 1 Fish Exports Inspector, Grade 2 2 2 2 2 Fish Exports Inspector, Grade 1 3 3 6 6
Since 30 June 1980 one additional Grade 2 position and three additional Grade 1 positions have been created.
(3) The number of vessels which were inspected and registered as export establishments in the area comprising the northern zone as at 19 November of each year since 1975 are as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have unlicensed foreign fishing vessels which have been prosecuted in relation to the bringing in of a foreign fishing vessel to an Australian port, used as a defence, under paragraph 13 (2) (b) of the Commonwealth Fisheries Act 1952 that the action was in accordance with a prescribed agreement between Australia and another country.
(2) Does the paragraph of the Act referred to in part (1) apply to existing agreements between Australia and other countries; if so, to which countries.
(3) Does the Joint Venture Agreement between Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild and Kailis Kaohsiung Fishing Company constitute a prescribed agreement as described in that section of the Act.

(4) Have unlicensed Taiwanese fishing vessels in the past been apprehended within the Australian Fishing Zone but evaded the penalties for summary conviction and conviction on indictment according to that section of the Act; if so, is there a need to amend this particular section of the Act to prevent unlicensed fishing vessels being sheltered in this manner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Subsidiary Agreement Between the Government of Australia and the Government of Japan Concerning Japanese Tuna Longline Fishing prescribed in Statutory Rules 1979 No. 235 makes provision for vessels licensed under section 9 of the Fisheries Act to enter specified ports. No other agreements have been entered into which permit the entry of vessels into ports under paragraph 13BA (2) (b).
(4) See (3). Also, in no prosecution of a Taiwanese fishing vessel has a defence under paragraph 13BA (2) (b) of the Commonwealth Fisheries Act 1952 been raised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Commonwealth Government approved a joint venture agreement with the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild of Taiwan, and the Kailis Kaohsiung Fishing Co., concerning the conduct of demersal pair-trawl and gillnet fishing operations in the Australian Fishing Zone effective for one year from 1 November 1980.

(2) If so, does this agreement state that the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild and the Kailis Kaohsiung Fishing Co., shall remit promptly to the Commonwealth Government or State Government or Territory concerned, all fines imposed in respect of contraventions by fishing vessels licensed under the Agreement.
(3) Does the Agreement specify the amount of the fine payable by licensed or unlicensed vessels found to be contravening the terms of the Agreement; if not, what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Government has not approved a joint venture agreement between the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild of Taiwan and the Kailis Kaohsiung Fishing Company.

Vessels of Taiwan are licensed to fish in the Australian fishing zone (AFZ) in the demersal pair-trawl and gillnet fisheries of the northwest shelf, under an Agreement between the Kaohsiung Fishing Boat Commercial Guild and the Commonwealth Government. The Agreement runs for 12 months from 1 November 1980. The Kailis Kaohsiung Fishing Company is the Australian representative of the Guild.

(2) The Agreement provides that the Guild be fully responsible for amongst other things, the payment of fines and associated expenses incurred by the Australian Government or State or Territory Government in respect of both licensed and unlicensed Taiwanese vessels convicted of offences in the AFZ.
(3) No. The Agreement does not specify fines payable. These are provided for in Commonwealth, State and Territory fisheries legislation and are matters for the courts to decide.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The pay and allowances of such members, other than pay and allowances in respect of continuous full time service, are exempt from income tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Commonwealth Government support specific programs for the education of deaf children; if so, what programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government provides support for the education of deaf children through its Special Education Program, administered by the Schools Commission.

Through this Program the Government provides support for the education of all handicapped children by supplementing the funding of government and non-government special schools and special classes in regular schools. In the case of Government schools, it does this by making block grants available to each State on condition that these grants be spent on the education of handicapped children. It leaves to the State concerned the determination of priorities within Special Education programs. Grants to declared non-government special schools, are recommended to the Commonwealth Education Minister by State Education Departments for approval. Thereafter grants are applied by the education authorities and schools concerned. Each State has programs related to the education of deaf children.

Expenditure priorities, and consequently the level of funding to be applied to supporting the education of deaf children are determined, therefore, by government and non-government education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory.

A further element of the Commonwealth Special Education Program under which deaf children may benefit is the program to assist the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. Under this program priority is to be given to the movement of as many children as possible from special to regular schools. Funds may also be used to enable isolated handicapped children to attend neighbourhood regular schools, to test new ways of fully or partially integrating handicapped children already integrated into regular schools and to facilitate the enrolment in regular primary schools of handicapped children who are beginning their formal schooling.
