(4) The Government has purchased and taken delivery of three Westinghouse radars-two for replacement of HUBCAP air defence radars and one for the TADS. The Government approved the acquisition of the remainder of the TADS in the context of the 1979-80 Budget. Tenders are now being evaluated, and the Government expects to place an order in mid 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Coastal Surveillance: Expenditure by Department of Business and Consumer Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum was (a) appropriated and (b) actually spent by his Department on coastal surveillance for (i) 1977-78; (ii) 1978-79 and (iii) 1979-80.
(2) What were the main items of expenditure and the cost attributed to each time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any members of the National Health and Medical Research Council retired from, or ceased to be active on a full-time basis, in their respective fields of expertise.
(2) What remuneration and/or allowances are paid to Council members.
(3) By what process (a) are matters relating to public health brought to the attention of the Council and (b) is advice on these matters disseminated to the general public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Only one member of the NH & MRC has retired from, or has ceased to be active on a full-time basis, in his respective field of expertise. He is Emeritus Professor R. H. Thorpe, whose appointment to the Council is on the basis of his nomination by the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations rather than by virtue of his expertise in his professional discipline. Professor Thorpe was formerly the Professor of Pharmacology at the University of Sydney.

(2) Members of Council, who are not public servants, are eligible for sitting fees and travel allowances for attendance at approved meetings, in accordance with Category 2 of the Remuneration Tribunal Determination No. 9 of 1980. They are also entitled to air transport and reimbursement for incidental expenses, incurred in attending such meetings, approved in accordance with the Audit Act.

However, recently the Government decided that, as a general principle, remuneration will not be paid to advisory committee members unless certain criteria are met. The criteria are being developed for consideration by the Government and should be available for implementation by 1 July 1981.
(3) (a) The Council's attention is drawn to matters related to public health through its Public Health Advisory Committee to which several expert committees in a variety of fields report.

(b) In regard to public health, the Council has as its main rule, expressly provided in the order-in-Council under which it is established, to advise the Commonwealth and States on matters of public health legislation and administration. Its advice on these matters is also disseminated to the public through NH & MRC Session Reports and, where appropriate, by way of Press releases and specially published documents.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say how many trans-national corporations are involved in inter-company transfer pricing between their Australian operations and operations abroad as reported in the radio program AM on 2 March 1981 and in the National Times of 1-7 March 1981.
(2) What is the extent of tax revenue to be recouped following the enactment of the proposed new version of section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to provide the information sought with any acceptable degree of accuracy. However, during the year ended 30 June 1980, formal determinations in transfer pricing cases, in accordance with section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and/or the relevant provisions of Australia's double taxation agreements, were made on nine occasions. At the end of that year, several other cases were under consideration for application of section 136 and/or the agreement provisions.

(2) No firm estimate can be placed on the tax revenue that might be recouped following the enactment of provisions to replace the existing section 260. It would necessarily require the passage of considerable time before the efficacy of such new provisions, once introduced, could be tested and determined. However, it has been estimated that taxpayer involvement in avoidance schemes that gave rise to claims for artificial losses and deductions resulted in revenue short-falls of $230m and $280m in the 1978-79 and 1979-80 financial years respectively. An allowance of $300m for tax avoidance has been incorporated in the estimates for 1980-81. These amounts relate to schemes against which specific legislative action has been or is being taken. I should add that the Commissioner of Taxation is contesting claims under these schemes and that the amount of revenue ultimately forgone because of them will only be determined upon resolution of the issues by the Courts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

(2) If so, is it intended to exempt (a) recipients of (i) age, (ii) invalid, (iii) service, (iv) widows' and (v) wives' pensions and (b) beneficiaries of (i) supporting parent benefits, (ii) unemployment benefit and (iii) student allowances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Telecom has decided to introduce a charge of $10 per annum for silent line services, to be applied from the publication date in respect of all telephone directories issued after 1st July 1981. This charge is to help offset the costs being incurred in handling Directory Assistance enquiries in relation to this type of service; (b) Telecom is introducing on a progressive basis a Call Charge Record (CCR) system which will automatically record details of subscriber dialled international calls, including the time the call is made, the number called and the cost of the call. At present, the system is being introduced at selected exchanges in the capital cities. With the introduction of the CCR system at an exchange, ISD will be provided to all subscribers connected to that exchange as a standard facility and a separate total for any ISD calls made will appear on their telephone bills. Because of this bulk billing feature, the ISD facility has been provided only to those subscribers who specifically request it.

As mentioned ISD/CCR is being progressively introduced as a standard facility and, should any subscriber wish to take less than full advantage of the telephone service, there is a standard fee of $3 per annum imposed by Telecom for restricting the service in the required way.

(2) No. The concessions made available at present to subscribers who qualify for pension entitlements are financed from appropriation to the Department of Social Security. It is considered that any further concession should be financed in a similar fashion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he approved retroactive increases in health insurance premiums so that the period of cover contracted for has been reduced unilaterally.

(2) Do advance long term premiums have a loan value at present rates of interest which brings their value close to that of later short term premiums adjusted for inflation; if so, will he correct this retrospective levy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Increases in contribution rates charged by a registered health benefits organisation are generally approved to finance higher benefit payments, thus ensuring the continued financial viability of the organisation. Increases in contributions are based on the whole membership of an organisation and not on an individual contributor basis, as is the case in other forms of general insurance. Accordingly, the date of application to all contributors of any contribution increase becomes an important factor because higher benefits usually become payable to all contributors from the same date. It is not uncommon for organisations to adjust automatically contributions paid several months in advance to take into account any increase in contribution rates. It is generally simpler for organisations to reduce the period for which advance contributions have been paid than to seek a lump sum adjustment.

(2) Organisations usually provide discounts on contributions paid in advance of up to four weeks in a year. This discount takes into account the advantages accruing to organisations from advance contributions i.e. savings in collection costs and interest earned. In the circumstances, the point raised by the honourable member should be considered in this light. The matter of the treatment of advance contributions is basically determined by organisations themselves and I would not propose to vary this arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The following procedures have been established by the Department of Housing and Construction and are operational for the recycling of waste paper:
Out of date minute paper, letterhead and other usable clean waste paper is made into pads and used for note paper.
Bulk pre-printed paper, forms and unusable material is collected by officers of the Department of Administrative Services and delivered to a recycling depot for pulping.
Cardboard and similar clean paper waste is collected by a recycling firm.
Classified material is disposed of by burning or pulping.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Have studies been made to assess the suitability of Christmas Island for location of transmitters for Radio Australia; if so, what were the major conclusions of the studies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Detailed submissions prepared by Telecom Australia concerning the suitability of Christmas Island for use as a transmitting station by Radio Australia were considered by the Independent Inquiry into Radio Australia chaired by Sir Keith Waller CBE. In Section 12.2 of its Report of December 1975, the Inquiry found that this site offered transmission advantages over Darwin and Carnarvon to certain prime target areas; however, in the light of Radio Australia's priorities, high cost, and the difficulties of operating such a station, it concluded that these advantages were not great enough to justify establishment at Christeas Island.

The Inter-Departmental Committee which considered the recommendations of the Waller Report, found that these reasons were still valid. Eventually it was decided to restore the Radio Australia facilities at Cox Peninsula.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Servicing of Jet Engine used in 'Spirit of Australia'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the jet engine used by Mr Ken Warby in his record breaking boat 'Spirit of Australia' serviced by Defence personnel; if so, (a) under what arrangements, (b) at what cost to the Commonwealth and (c) who else is receiving similar assistance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1978 agreement was reached between Mr Warby and my Department to a 'one-time' Service of the J34 engine fitted to the 'Spirit of Australia' in preparation for his attempt on the world water speed record. In recent years the J34 type engine has been used as the major training engine for engine fitters at the RAAF School of Technical Training, Wagga. These engines are stripped, rebuilt, test run, and calibrated by trainees as part of their training. As Mr Warby's engine was the only one in Australia fitted with an afterburner it provided an excellent opportunity to demonstrate and teach afterburner operations to trainees whilst at the same time directly benefiting RAAF morale.

(a) Mr Warby signed a form of indemnity in which he agreed to provide all materials required to service the engine and to indemnify the Commonwealth and its Servicemen or servants against any claims that might arise as a result of the servicing.
(b) The servicing was provided at no additional cost to the Commonwealth.
(c) Although it is RAAF policy to look for training projects of this nature to provide motivation and interest to trainees, no similar assistance of this magnitude is currently being provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Health Care Consumers' Association of the ACT is a community based organisation that aims to assist in the improvement of health and health care through consumer involvement by:
Promoting goodwill and understanding between those who render and those who use health care;
investigating the availability of health care;
educating the public on the availability of health care;
assessing from the consumer point of view, the adequacy of the health care available and drawing such assessments to the attention of appropriate individuals or groups.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a New Zealand citizen by the name of Collins recently deported to New Zealand; and if so
(2) Can such a deportation be effective and what safeguards exist to prevent re-entry to Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is assumed that the person referred to is Brett Anthony Collins.

On 4 July 1980 I signed an order under Section 13 of the Migration Act 1958 for the deportation of Mr Collins. Subsequently Mr Collins applied to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for the order to be reviewed. On 22 January 1981 the Tribunal affirmed my decision. The following day Mr Collins lodged an appeal with the Federal Court. A stay of deportation was granted on 23 January 1981 pending the hearing of the appeal.

(2) If Mr Collins is deported, administrative action will be taken to prevent his return. Past experience has shown that, by adopting false identities and abusing the travel facilitation arrangements agreed between Australia and New Zealand, some criminal deportees have attempted, or have been able, to re-enter Australia. This is one of a number of reasons which influenced the Government to decide that persons claiming the benefits of the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement will be asked to identify themselves and to satisfy officials at points of entry that they are entitled to enter Australia. Passport checks have been introduced for this purpose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What actions have been taken to overcome the limitations on manpower and financial resources for immigration control functions hindering efforts to take advantage of information available on the whereabouts of prohibited immigrations as reported on page 52 of Review '80 published by his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is engaged in a study of prohibited immigrants in Australia and of methods and procedures by which it can more effectively use its resources to control prohibited immigration. It is not desirable that details of methods and procedures be made public.

I can say, however, that I have asked the Department to take vigorous action to achieve a substantial reduction in the number of overstayed visitors, to ask potential or actual prohibited immigrants to leave Australia and, as a last resort, to effect deportation when so ordered. I have written to the State and Northern Territory Ministers responsible for immigration and ethnic affairs matters and have discussed with them the possibility of denying prohibited immigrants access to certain services provided free to Australian residents or heavily subsidised by Australian taxpayers.

During the period of the Regularisation of Status Program which operated throughout the second half of 1980 the Department's staff was directed to that program rather than to seeking out prohibited immigrants. As I have made clear, people illegally in Australia who did not take advantage of that last opportunity to regularise their immigration status or who were ineligible to apply cannot expect to be allowed to remain in Australia after the program concluded. Action to detect, apprehend and deal with prohibited immigrants has again been stepped up. The rate of detection has increased in recent weeks. In April it was a monthly record. Prosecutions for working without authority have been instituted successfully. It is expected that as a result of the action taken and under further examination it will be possible to reduce the number of prohibited immigrants in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he expand the table Deportation Orders Made on page 52 of Review '80 to show the causes for the substantially different figures in the table Deportations Carried Out on the same page of that publication.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The difference between figures in the table Deportation Orders Made on page 52 of Review '80, and the table Deportations Carried Out, is attributable to the time lag incurred in many deportations, mainly due to the following factors:

(i) deportation orders made include people whose whereabouts were not known at the time and as it takes a considerable time to locate many of them, their deportation is not necessarily carried out within the same statistical period;
(ii) orders made against criminals are not executed until the deportees complete the custodial portion of their prison sentences; and
(iii) some deportees contest the decision to order their deportation by legal challenge through the courts or through review of the decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

A further reason for the difference between orders made and deportations carried out is that it is normal practice for any fresh information or new circumstances to be considered before an order in force for some time is executed. As a consequence some deportation orders are revoked. Precise statistics are not kept.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Disruption to Australian High Frequency Radio Communication

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many complaints have been received by him and from what quarters have they originated in regard to disruption to Australian high frequency radio communication.

(2) Is it a fact that this interference (a) comes from an over-the-horizon radar system which can track objects such as aircraft which cannot be detected by conventional radar and (b) is making communications extremely difficult and sometimes impossible where (i) air to ground, (ii) ship to shore and (iii) land mobile radar links are concerned and (c) could blot out mayday distress calls and thereby threaten lives.

(3) If so, (a) what action has been taken to establish the origin of the interference and (b) has he notified the International Telecommunication Union of the United Nations Organisation of the problems being experienced in communications.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Since 1 March 1981 there has been a total of 41 complaints received of interference to services, other than amateur, in the HF bands, 4 of which can be attributed to Over the Horizon Radar and the remainder to other sources such as electrical interference, unlicensed stations and other overseas services. The complaints were received from the operators of the licensed services affected.

In addition, fifteen Amateur Stations reported interference to the amateur bands indicating the source to be from an over the horizon radar transmitter at Kiev, USSR. A further twelve amateurs reported interference to amateur bands from a variety of sources, and in some cases, the interference described could well be from other amateur stations.

My Department has received no complaints from responsible authorities concerning interference from over the horizon radar to air-to-ground, ship to shore or land mobile radio links. No interference has been observed on or near any of the safety channels which are recognised by international agreement.

2 (c) It is possible that difficulty could be experienced with distress calls if these radar transmissions are made on or adjacent to frequencies assigned for distress calls at the time a distress call is made. However, there is no evidence available within my Department to indicate that any distress calls have been impaired to the extent that a call has been lost as a result of such interference.
Departmental monitoring stations have observed OHR signals on 27.880 MHz, the frequency used for distress in the Australian Inshore Boating Radiocommunication Service (IBRS).

3 (a) My Department is aware of the general belief that the OHR signals are coming from a site or sites near Kiev in Russia. My Department's monitoring of these transmissions while not being conclusive, does not conflict with this belief.
3 (b) No. However, my Department has initiated communication with the USSR seeking their co-operation in avoiding interference to the 27.880 MHz safety channel used by the IBRS.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have reports by the Auditor-General often criticised the management of the Defence computer program and its capabilities; if so, have the problems been remedied.
(2) What stage has the installation of the Univac computer system reached.
(3) Have the Univac computers now being installed by his Department already been superseded by changed technologies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Auditor-General over the past five years has criticised the management of the Defence computing program and its capabilities in relation to:

(a) Honeywell Computer Operations-Criticism of Honeywell operations centred on reliability and maintenance of Honeywell machines and the ability to maintain an essential service until systems were transferred to Univac. These problems were addressed by the installation of an additional Honeywell H8200 in June 1978.

(b) System Development-In 1976-77 the Auditor-General commented on an apparent lack of an approved plan detailing a timetable for the transfer of systems from Honeywell to Univac. This area has since been subjected to rigorous estimating, resource and project control procedures. A Schedule of Activity and Achievement was approved in September 1977 and has been updated regularly to reflect the current position. This schedule is endorsed yearly by a high level Policy Committee. In his 1979-80 report the Auditor-General noted the continued improvements in project control and that new systems development and design methodology is planned for introduction in 1981; this is expected to result in further improvement.

(c) Mini Computers-Criticism in this area referred to slippage of target dates, apparent over manning of data preparation operator positions at the larger RAAF bases and problems of site works and accommodation. Development and implementation of systems on mini computers is now progressing substantially according to target dates. More work is being done on data preparation establishment criteria. Site modifications are done as funds allow.

(d) Micrographics-In 1977-78 the Auditor-General referred to Defence placing work with outside contractors instead of the Micrographics Service Bureau of the Australian Government Publishing Service. All micrographic output produced by Defence Computing Division is now processed by AGPS.

(2) Two mainframe computers, models 1100-82, are installed in separate locations. Each is working 10 shifts per week. A third mainframe, also an 1100-82, approved in January 1981, is expected to be installed at a third location by mid 1982.

(3) No. All hardware is current, with the exception of two leased communication controllers which are in the process of being updated. Similarly, all manufacturer's software in use is the current version.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Freight Charges for Exports to Middle East and Gulf Countries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether a period of 12 months has elapsed since the formation of the Middle East and Gulf Shipping Conference; if so, have freight charges for the export of frozen meat from Australia to the Middle East and Gulf countries increased since the establishment of the Conference.
(2) Has the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation been (a) negotiating reduced freight rates to those countries or (b) seeking alternate carriers; if so, with what success.
(3) Has the Government taken any action on the matter beyond that undertaken by the Corporation; if so, what has been achieved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) Alignment of freight rates upon formation of the Australia Middle East Gulf Conference on 1 March 1980 resulted in a substantial effective increase in the freight rate being applied by the shipping line carrying the bulk of meat cargoes to the Gulf area. Subsequently, the Conference reached agreement with the Australian Shippers Council on a 17 1/2 per cent increase in freight rates from 10 July 1980. Meat shipper representatives did not accept this increase negotiated in the Shippers Council and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC), on behalf of meat shippers, conducted separate negotiations with the Conference. No agreement emerged from those negotiations.

The outcome was that the AMLC, with the approval of the Minister for Primary Industry, invoked powers available in its Act and set a maximum freight rate providing for a 12 1/2 per cent increase in meat freight rates from 4 July 1980. Subsequent discussions between AMLC and the Conference on 8 December 1980 resulted in agreement by both parties to a further 5 per cent increase in meat freight rates to apply for one year from 1 January 1981.

As a result of these arrangements, shippers of refrigerated meat had the benefit for six months of a 5 per cent lower freight rate than otherwise would have applied. Additionally, there will be no further increase in the Conference base rates during 1981.

(b) The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation has kept the matter of available capacity and alternative carriers under constant review. The Corporation has from time to time met with representatives of lines serving the Middle East region other than those of the Australia Middle East Gulf Conference. It is understood that these non-conference lines have achieved a reasonable degree of success and have attracted a sizeable proportion of the refrigerated meat volume being lifted to Middle East destinations.

(3) The AMLC has responsibility under its enabling legislation, the AMLC Act 1977, to negotiate freight rates and other conditions of carriage on behalf of the meat industry with Conference Lines and other carriers. The Act provides for Ministerial approval for shipping arrangements made by the Corporation. In the Government's view the AMLC has discharged this responsibility satisfactorily to date.
In addition, the Government is represented at freight rate negotiations between the Australian Shippers Council and Conference Lines under the provisions of Part 10 of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say what is the scale of the current military exercises in Indonesia.
(2) Are there any Australian observers present.
(3) Are there any Australian observers in East Timor observing the military exercises there.
(4) Is he also able to say whether, as reported in the Indonesian Press, the East Timorese exercises represent the preliminaries to a major offensive against Fretelin forces.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The recent major Indonesian joint exercise, which was held in eastern Indonesia from 18 March to 1 April, involved the deployment of some 35,000 men together with naval ships and aircraft. The exercise was conducted in three separate locations in eastern Indonesia-Timor, Maluku, and Irian Jaya. The exercise was part of a continuing program of exercises being held throughout Indonesia aimed at upgrading the defensive capability of Indonesia's armed forces. The previous exercise in 1980 was conducted in the First National Defence Area Command which covers Sumatra and West Kalimantan.

(2) and (3) The Australian Defence Attache, together with a number of other military attaches from other countries resident in Jakarta, observed all parts of the exercise at the invitation of the Indonesian Government.

(4) Matters relating to security in the Indonesian province of East Timor are the direct domestic responsibility of the Indonesian Government, and it is not for me to speculate on Indonesian Government intentions. I am able to say, that the Defence Attache's report of the Timor segment of the exercise contained no indication that the exercise was anything more than an exercise. However, it is possible that Fretelin guerilla remnants continue to be active in parts of the province and it would be expected that Indonesian forces conduct operations against them.

Statement to employees in the vinyl chloride industry
Vinyl Chloride-Australian Code of Safe Practice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the concern being expressed by Micronesian leaders over the Reagan Administration's delay in considering an agreement on the future political status of Micronesia.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to the fact that this concern has been intensified because of the Reagan Administration's failure to re-appoint Mr Peter Rosenblatt, the head of the United States of America negotiating team for 3 1/2 years, thus delaying the notification of the formula known as the Compact of Free Association.
(3) What is the Australian Government's attitude towards Micronesian independence and is it prepared to place pressure on the Reagan Administration to speed up the process towards independence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that a number of Micronesian spokesmen have expressed concern that the Compact of Free Association might be delayed following the decision of the United States Administration to review United States policy on ending the Trusteeship.

(2) I am also aware that Mr Rosenblatt submitted his resignation as Head of the United States Delegation to the Micronesian Political Status Negotiations to the incoming President. This action is normal procedure for holders of executive office in the United States after the election of a new President. A successor to Mr Rosenblatt has not yet been appointed by the new Administration, and the negotiations remain suspended for the time being. However, the failure to appoint a new Head of the United States Delegation need not necessarily delay the endorsement of the Compact of Free Association, although it does appear probable that termination of the Trusteeship this year will not be achieved.

(3) The Australian Government looks forward to the successful conclusion of the long process of negotiation which will settle the political status of the Micronesian entities. We have noted that the process has involved, and will continue to involve, extensive consultation with the peoples of the islands. I see no reason for Australia to make the sort of representations to the United States on this issue suggested by the honourable member.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does his Department still anticipate having Job Bank, its proposed automated system of vacancy receipt and dissemination, operational on a national basis by August 1984, as indicated in the Request for Tenders issued for the supply of equipment for the Job Bank system.
(2) If not, what changes have been made to the timetable, and why have these been made.
(3) Is Job Bank to be introduced initially in Adelaide on a trial basis.

(4) Do the tenders for the supply of computer equipment for Job Bank so far received by his department include separate quotes for the supply of equipment for the Adelaide operation and for the complete national system, or do they refer only to a national system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) The tenderers have responded to the request for tenders for a national system, as described in the specification of Job Bank.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he give consideration to allowing the cost of personal medical alert systems such as Vital Call to be made tax deductible in the interests of achieving effective savings in the provision of hospital or nursing home beds by allowing patients to be supervised effectively at home.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The cost of medical alert systems such as Vital Call which, it is understood, are primarily designed for use by elderly persons, is expenditure of a private or domestic nature which is not deductible for income tax purposes.

While the advantages of such a system for use in many situations are appreciated, the benefit that a taxation deduction might provide would depend upon the taxable income of the person involved. Persons in receipt of higher incomes and least in need of financial assistance would benefit from a deduction while, for example, elderly persons with incomes below the amount at which tax becomes payable would obtain no benefit at all. In view of this, it is doubtful whether the income tax system is an appropriate means of providing relief to the users of such systems.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Reduction of Staff and Functions: Department of Communications

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Com- munications, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he provide a detailed list of the (a) numbers of staff and (b) functions to be eliminated in all areas of his Department that are located in the Australian Capital Territory, when the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions are implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There were no functions eliminated from the Department in the Australian Capital Territory. However, one of the Committee's recommendations was that a review should be undertaken by the Public Service Board to examine the scope for staff savings in rationalising areas of the Department responsible for policy advice in the field of broadcasting. This review is yet to be undertaken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the performance of the McDonnell Douglas F-18 has been significantly downgraded because of design deficiencies.
(2) Is is a fact that the F-18 is no longer capable of a significantly higher level of performance than the General Dynamics F-16.
(3) Has the price difference between the 2 aircraft remained constant despite the narrowing of the performance gap.
(4) Do either of the aircraft currently meet the requirements set out by the Australian Defence Force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) On 4 December 1980 I informed the House that the Government had reluctantly decided, on the basis of sound professional and technical advice, to postpone selection of the new tactical fighter aircraft until further data on both contending aircraft was available for evaluation. Until analysis of all the necessary information is completed, and the Government's decision on final selection made public, it would be premature for me to answer these questions or others like them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the nature of the additional travel to the value of $.245m provided for in the 1980-81 supplementary estimates.
(2) Does this figure represent a further assessment visit to the United States of America in relation to the new tactical fighter (NTF) program.
(3) What new developments have occurred in the development of the 2 remaining contenders for this role which were not able to be assessed by previous assessment teams.
(4) Have any modifications been made to the F-16's radar and all weather performances.
(5) Has the F-18 program been suspended pending a review of the program by the United States Secretary of Defense as has been publicly reported in the USA.
(6) How many senior personnel who were involved with earlier assessment teams have been replaced or are no longer with (a) the project or (b) his Department.
(7) Are any additional funds to be used to provide new team members with familiarisation briefing in the USA with respect to the 2 aircraft.
(8) Has there been any increases or reduction in civil and RAAF personnel attached full time or part time to the NTF project in (a) Australia and (b) the USA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 4 December 1980 I informed the House that the Government saw no alternative but to await evaluation of further data around mid 1981 before adopting any view as to the relative merits of selection of either aircraft, the F-16 or F/A-18 for Australia's new Tactical Fighter. That position has not changed. Additional funding for travel by officers of my Department was required to enable the necessary further evaluations to be carried out.

(3) and (4) Until analysis of all the necessary information is completed and the Government's decision on the final selection made public, it would be premature for me to answer these questions or others like them.
(6) On the assumption that senior personnel equate to Group Captain (Clerk Class 11/equivalent) and above, the answer is as follows:
(1) replaced-one Group Captain, (Note that the replacement has had previous experience with the Project).
(2) no longer with the project-one Group Captain (post disestablished).
(3) no longer with the Department of Defence-Nil.
(b) Higher Defence Staff-following the 180 evaluation Deputy Secretary C, Mr D. H. Eltringham was appointed the Permanent Head of the former Department of Productivity.
(7) No. All visits to the United States by officers responsible for assessment are for purposes of evaluation, not for purposes of familiarisation.

(8) (a) There has been a reduction of two RAAF personnel and an increase of one civilian attached full time to the NTF project in Australia. However, one of the two RAAF posts was transferred to the USA for full-time project activities. This produced an increase of one full-time RAAF post in the USA. There were no increases in full-time civilian posts in the USA.

(b) With regard to part time activities related to the NTF project there have been a number of specialist teams involved in the 1981 phase of the evaluation. While the same total number of people as in 1980 have been and will be involved in part-time duty in the USA, the requirement for specialists in particular areas of investigation has resulted in an increase in the requirement for what may be broadly termed scientific specialists. For this reason there will be an increase of three civilians and a decrease of three RAAF personnel when compared to the 1980 evaluation mission.
